positions.statement: Kant's official definition: a proposition is analytic if nothing is contained in the predicate which is not contained in the subject
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant's official definition of "analytic" is this: a proposition is analytic if "nothing is contained in the predicate which is not contained in the subject."

positions.statement: Quine identified two problems with Kant's definition of analyticity
positions.verbatim_quote: As Quine pointed out, there are two problems with Kant's definition of analyticity.

positions.statement: The notion of containment is left at a metaphorical level
positions.verbatim_quote: First, the notion of containment is "left at a metaphorical level." Physical objects can contain other physical objects; but meanings don't contain meanings, at least not in the same sense.

positions.statement: Kant's formulation only applies to statements having subject-predicate form
positions.verbatim_quote: Second, Kant's formulation only applies to statements having subject-predicate form. So it isn't immediately obvious how to apply it to statements not having that form, for example: A=A or if p implies q, then p implies anything that q implies.

positions.statement: Kant's formulation can be adapted by focusing on whether concepts guarantee truth
positions.verbatim_quote: But it isn't hard to adapt Kant's formulation to meet these two objections. Consider the proposition: a+b is larger than a. This proposition is composed of various concepts – a+b, larger than, and so on. By themselves, the structures of these concepts guarantee that a+b is larger than a is true.

positions.statement: For Kant, a proposition is analytic exactly if it is conceptually true
positions.verbatim_quote: These facts suggest that, for Kant, a proposition is analytic exactly if it is "conceptually true", i.e. exactly if it holds entirely in virtue of facts about the structures of concepts.

positions.statement: Kant's description of A=A as analytic supports the conceptual truth interpretation
positions.verbatim_quote: Consider the proposition A=A. Kant describes this very proposition as analytic. But in so doing, he is not being true to his official definition of analyticity, namely "the predicate is contained in the subject".

positions.statement: A proposition is synthetic a priori if it is known non-empirically but its truth is not guaranteed by conceptual structures
positions.verbatim_quote: A proposition is a priori if it is known in some way other than through empirical work. A proposition is synthetic if its truth is not guaranteed by the structures of the concepts composing it. A proposition is synthetic a priori if it has both these properties.

positions.statement: According to Kant, 7+5=12 and 'a straight line is the shortest distance between two points' are synthetic a priori truths
positions.verbatim_quote: According to Kant, the propositions 7+5=12 and a straight line is the shortest distance between two points are synthetic a priori truths.

positions.statement: Contrary to Kant, both 7+5=12 and the straight line proposition appear to be analytic
positions.verbatim_quote: But it very much seems that, contrary to what Kant says, both of these propositions are analytic.

positions.statement: The truth of 7+5=12 is guaranteed by the constitutions of the concepts involved
positions.verbatim_quote: The truth of 7+5=12 seems to be guaranteed by the constitutions of the concepts 7, 5, +, and so on.

positions.statement: Arthur Pap's argument shows that 7+5=12 should be analytic given Kant's premises
positions.verbatim_quote: We find support for this line of thought in argument given by Arthur Pap. 1+1=2 is clearly analytic, as Kant himself acknowledges. 7+5=12 can be shown to follow analytically from 1+1=2 along with some other premises that Kant would regard as analytic.

positions.statement: Analyticity is hereditary with respect to logical consequence
positions.verbatim_quote: Anything that follows analytically from an analytic proposition is itself analytic: the property of analyticity is hereditary with respect to the relation of logical consequence.

positions.statement: Kant's reasoning about 7+5 becomes fuzzy due to unclear use of 'concept'
positions.verbatim_quote: But at this point, Kant's reasoning becomes fuzzy. The fuzziness is due to the fact that Kant is not clear, either in his thinking or in his exposition, about whether he is using the term "concept" in the logical, or the psychological sense; he goes back and forth.

positions.statement: Kant infers from psychological facts about concept-grasping to logical facts about concepts themselves
positions.verbatim_quote: From this Kant apparently infers that the concept 7+5 is entirely distinct from the concept =12. But this inference involves a muddle of the two meanings of the word "concept".

positions.statement: Kant's argument requires a principle of conceptual transparency
positions.verbatim_quote: For Kant to make his case, he needs to appeal to some principle like the following: the structure of concepts (in the objective sense) of the word can be read off of the way in which they are represented in our minds.

positions.statement: The transparency principle presupposes anti-realism about concepts
positions.verbatim_quote: That principle presupposes that concepts are completely transparent: you cannot grasp a concept without at once grasping everything definitive of it. There is no more to them than meets the eye. Their esse lies in their percipi. It thus seems to me that the principle in question presupposes, and is probably motivated by, a kind of anti-realism or psychologism with regard to concepts.

positions.statement: Synthetic a priori propositions raise difficult questions about what makes them true
positions.verbatim_quote: The very existence of synthetic a priori propositions raises difficult questions. Such propositions do not hold wholly in virtue of facts about the structures of concepts. At the same time, they do not hold in virtue of the kinds of facts that can be discovered through empirical investigation. There thus doesn't seem to be anything left to make them true.

positions.statement: According to Kant, we learn mathematical truths through acts of imagination
positions.verbatim_quote: How do you know that 7+5=12? Not through conceptual analysis. Not through the senses. You learn it through an act of the imagination. You imagine seven objects laid next to five other objects, and then see that the resulting aggregate comprises exactly 12 objects.

positions.statement: Kant uses 'intuition' to refer to para-sensory imaging experiences, not conceptual insights
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant refers to images of this sort as "intuitions." So it is through "intuition" that you learn the truth of 7+5=12. It must be made clear that Kant is not using this term in the way it is used today. These days, philosophers usually use the term to refer to a putative insight into concepts ("my intuition is that killing someone is morally worse than passively allowing him to die"). This is not what Kant means. By "intuition" Kant means an act of imaging: a kind of para-perception.

positions.statement: Kantian intuitions show representational necessity, not conceptual or empirical necessity
positions.verbatim_quote: So, for Kant, these para-perceptual experiences show neither empirical truth nor conceptual necessity. What they show is representational necessity. They show us facts, not about the world or about concepts, but about how we must sense-perceive the world.

positions.statement: Intuitions show what we can and cannot represent in imagery
positions.verbatim_quote: These para-perceptual experiences show us what we can and cannot represent in imagery. We cannot form an image of a straight line between two points that is longer than some other line between those two points. We cannot form an image of four apples that isn't also an image of two apples and two other apples.

positions.statement: For Kant, representational necessities are psychological rather than conceptual
positions.verbatim_quote: In Kant's view, these necessities are really of a psychological nature. Our "forms of thought" are such that we must see the world (literally see it) as being such that, in it, parallel lines don't meet, a straight line is the shortest distance between two points, two objects coupled with two other objects make four objects, and so on.

positions.statement: There is no room in Kant's picture for synthetic a priori truth or knowledge thereof
positions.verbatim_quote: Is there any room in this picture for synthetic a priori truth or for knowledge thereof? Both questions must be answered with a "no".

positions.statement: Psychological compulsion to see things a certain way doesn't prove they are that way
positions.verbatim_quote: Given only that we are psychologically compelled to see the world as being such that, in it, thus and such is the case, it doesn't follow that thus and such really is the case. A psychotic may be psychologically compelled to see pink elephants, but that doesn't mean there are pink elephants.

positions.statement: Kant admits intuitions only tell us about the phenomenal world, not the noumenal world
positions.verbatim_quote: Actually, Kant himself admits this. These intuitions, he says, tell us about the "phenomenal" world, not the "noumenal" world. By Kant's own definition, the "phenomenal world" is just the world as it appears to us: it is how we see the world. The "noumenal" world is the actual world.

positions.statement: On Kant's view, intuitions give us no knowledge of the external world or concepts
positions.verbatim_quote: So, on Kant's view, intuitions don't tell us anything about the spatiotemporal world and they don't tell us anything about concepts. Thus, given only that intuition tells us that a straight line is the shortest distance between two points, we simply have no reason to believe that straight line is the shortest distance between two points.

positions.statement: Kant's system makes supposedly a priori truths into empirical truths
positions.verbatim_quote: So on Kant's view, followed to its logical conclusion, for us to know whether 7+5 really equaled 12, we'd have to learn some fact about the non-mental, non-platonic world (which, for reasons that are internal to Kant's system, Kant says we cannot do). 7+5=12 thus becomes a kind of empirical truth.

positions.statement: Kant failed to distinguish different epistemological roles of mental imagery
positions.verbatim_quote: What led Kant astray was a failure to distinguish the different roles that mental imagery can play in the acquisition of knowledge. Kant noted that mental imagery is a kind of para-perception. He concluded from this that, when mental imagery is involved in the discovery of some truth, that truth is synthetic – like those truths that we use perception to discover.

positions.statement: Determining the minimum number of sides a solid can have involves conceptual analysis via imagery
positions.verbatim_quote: If somebody asks me "what is the minimum number of sides a solid can have?", I base my answer on a mental image that I produce. I imagine trying to produce a solid out of four sides, then note that it doesn't work, then try to do the same thing with five sides, and note that it does work. But surely the fact that a solid has to have a minimum of five sides is not synthetic.

positions.statement: Mental imagery can serve different epistemic roles - conceptual analysis vs. empirical observation
positions.verbatim_quote: mental imagery can sometimes serve as a vehicle for conceptual analysis. But it can also play a very different epistemic role. Suppose I want to find out facts about my own psychology. Suppose, for example, that I want to find out whether I can imagine a 17-sided figure. Here I will, of course, generate mental imagery, and attend to the content of that imagery. But in this case, the imagery is not serving as a vehicle for conceptual analysis.

positions.statement: Knowledge about representational limitations is a posteriori
positions.verbatim_quote: For Kant, you learn that you can't represent parallel lines as intersecting by noting that you cannot imagine it; you observe your own mental imagery. So you learn this putative fact about your representational powers through a kind of self-observation, and not through any kind of conceptual analysis. This knowledge turns out to be quite a posteriori.

positions.statement: Leibniz argued that mathematical demonstrations don't derive their cogency from diagrams
positions.verbatim_quote: But I do not agree with you what seems to be your [Locke's] view, that some kind of general certainty is provided in mathematics by "particular demonstrations" concerning the diagram that has been drawn. You must understand that geometers do not derive their proofs from diagrams, although the expository approach makes it seem so. The cogency of the demonstration is independent of the diagram, whose only role is to make it easier to understand what is meant and to fix one's attention.

positions.statement: Peacocke's distinction between access and justification applies to mental imagery
positions.verbatim_quote: When you come to know a logical truth by way of your having a proof of it, you may need to perceive the inscription of the proof, and you may need various perceptual capacities to appreciate that it is a proof. But the justification for your belief in the logical truth is the proof itself. Perceptual experience gives access to the proof, which provides an experience-independent justification for accepting its conclusion.

positions.statement: Transcendental necessity is either psychological or conceptual necessity
positions.verbatim_quote: In the end, "transcendental" necessity reduces either to mere psychological necessity or to conceptual necessity. We cannot coherently think of a world where triangles have two sides or where 2+2=3. That is because propositions like 2+2=3 and triangles have two sides are conceptually false and consequently draw a limit to what we can conceive of.

positions.statement: Conceptual necessities impose limits on visual representation
positions.verbatim_quote: What cannot be conceived cannot be perceived. Conceptual necessities thus impose sharp limits on how the world can be visually represented. So it is clear how conceptual falsity translates into representational impossibility.

positions.statement: There is an incoherence in Kant's thinking about mathematical propositions
positions.verbatim_quote: There is an incoherence in Kant's thinking more radical than any mentioned so far. He rightly wants to hold that propositions like 7+2=9 and the area of a (Euclidean) triangle is ½ the base×height are a priori. But he also says that we sense-perceive the world as being such that these propositions are true in it.

positions.statement: Mathematical propositions don't describe the spatiotemporal world
positions.verbatim_quote: But, as Frege clearly stated, 7+2=9 doesn't say anything about the spatio-temporal world; it doesn't say that if you hold up two fingers and then hold up seven fingers, nine fingers are on display. For there could, in principle, be a causal law that falsified just that sort of statement – a law that didn't allow more than five fingers to be simultaneously on display in a certain region.

positions.statement: Kant's position requires mathematical propositions to be both descriptive and non-descriptive of the world
positions.verbatim_quote: So Kant's position is self-undermining. He needs mathematical propositions to be two things at once. They must be descriptive of the world: they must say something about beams of light. But they must also not be descriptive of the world: they must not be capable of falsification by anything having to do with beams of light and the like.

positions.statement: If a proposition is necessary, it doesn't describe the empirical world
positions.verbatim_quote: But there is an inference from P is necessarily true to P doesn't describe the empirical world (in any way at all). If P is necessary, then P's being true in world 1 doesn't distinguish world 1 from world 2 or from world 897. P therefore doesn't say anything about the world that distinguishes it from other possible worlds.

positions.statement: Kant's conception of analyticity is too narrow, and this is the fundamental error in his system
positions.verbatim_quote: Ultimately, there is one thing wrong with Kant's view: his conception of analyticity is much too narrow. Everything else that is wrong about Kant's position can be traced back to this one mistake. A corollary is that everything that is wrong about his system can be corrected by correcting this one mistake.

positions.statement: Kant grants analytic status only to trivial propositions like 'circles are round'
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant grants analytic status only to propositions like (a) circles are round. He denies analytic status to propositions like (b) a circle is a class of points equidistant from a given point in a plane.

positions.statement: Hard analytic truths are logically but not psychologically incoherent to deny
positions.verbatim_quote: Let us set say that (b) and (e) are "hard analytic", and let us say that (a) and (h) are "easy analytic". It is hard to know that (b) and (e) are true. It is not hard to know (a) and (h) are analytic; a grasp of those propositions by itself suffices for a knowledge of their truth.

positions.statement: What Kant calls synthetic a priori truths are actually hard analytic truths
positions.verbatim_quote: What Kant refers to as "synthetic a priori" truths are nothing other than what we are describing as hard analytic truths. What Kant refers to as analytic truths are what we are describing as easy analytic truths.

positions.statement: Recognizing hard analytic truths eliminates the need for psychologistic analysis
positions.verbatim_quote: Once it is recognized that (b) and (e) are analytic, albeit hard analytic, we must say that they hold entirely in virtue of facts about the concepts that compose them; and there is no longer any temptation to say that they are made true by facts about the mind. So that obliterates any possible warrant that might otherwise be had by Kant's psychologistic analysis of those propositions.

positions.statement: Kant's main concern is understanding how the world must be structured for coherent experience to be possible
positions.verbatim_quote: We have experience; we have sequences of thoughts and perceptions that cohere. The world is intelligible to us. We sense-perceive it and about it. Up to a point, our perceptions and thoughts are accurate. In Kant's view, given the very fact that these things are true, we can deduce certain things about the structure of the world.

positions.statement: Transcendental conditions are necessarily satisfied by any world containing entities with coherent thoughts
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant refers to those conditions as "transcendental": they are the conditions that are necessarily satisfied by any world in which there are entities that have coherent, if not always accurate, thoughts and representations.

positions.statement: A transcendental argument has the form: given experience of a certain kind, the world must have certain features
positions.verbatim_quote: A "transcendental argument" is one having the form: given only that we have experiences of such and such a kind, it follows that the world must have thus and such features.

positions.statement: There is a hard analytic connection between beings capable of metaphysical questions and propositions about world structure
positions.verbatim_quote: I will argue that there is an analytic connection – a hard analytic connection, but an analytic connection no less – between the proposition there exist beings who have the cognitive wherewithal to raise metaphysical questions and propositions concerning the structure of the world itself.

positions.statement: A world without causation would comprise nothing enduring
positions.verbatim_quote: Imagine a world where there is no causation, where there are merely sequences of events. Such a world would comprise nothing enduring. This is because persistence is itself a causal notion. If something persists, there is ipso facto a causal sequence of some kind.

positions.statement: Coherent ideation requires persistence, which requires causation
positions.verbatim_quote: Where there is no persistence, there is no coherent ideation. For surely, as a matter of necessity, a coherent thought process involves some kind of persistence. So given only the fact that there are beings who have the ability to raise questions about anything, let alone about the necessary preconditions for experience, it follows that causal relations do not consist in mere sequences of events, but in internal relations of some kind.

positions.statement: This transcendental argument relies on analytic connections, not synthetic a priori truths
positions.verbatim_quote: But notice that this transcendental argument turns on the existence of entirely analytic connections among propositions; no "synthetic a priori" is involved. Given the very concept of a rational thought process, it follows that analytically there are causal relations among events.

positions.statement: Hume's induction problem: past experience cannot justify future expectations without circular reasoning
positions.verbatim_quote: Suppose that such and such has always happened in the past. How does our knowledge of that fact warrant our believing that such and such will happen in the future? The warrant is not deductive. Given only that such and such happened before time t, there is no logical contradiction in saying that it won't happen after t.

positions.statement: Justifying induction requires the principle that the future resembles the past, but this is itself empirical
positions.verbatim_quote: To have an empirical justification for that inference, we'd have to know that, in general, the future resembles the past and that, consequently, knowledge of the past gives us a rational basis for beliefs about the future. But that is itself an empirical thesis, whose only possible justification lies in our past experience.

positions.statement: Hume's causation problem: there are no logical connections between distinct events
positions.verbatim_quote: Given two distinct states of affairs, one is not guilty of self-contradiction if one affirms the existence of the one but denies the existence of the other. Since causality holds between distinct states of affairs, there is no strictly logical connection between cause and effect.

positions.statement: Causal forces cannot be empirically justified because we only perceive events, not connections
positions.verbatim_quote: We perceive events and regularities among events. If they exist, forces are connections among events, and are not events themselves. What we perceive gives us a basis for believing that certain kinds of events are likely to accompany certain other kinds of events. But what we perceive does not give us any basis for perceiving that things altogether different from events are likely to accompany events.

positions.statement: Hume's position must be qualified: logical relations hold between propositions, not events
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume says that given any two distinct events, there is no strictly logical connection between them. This must be qualified. Logical relations hold, not between states of affairs, but between pieces of information. Typically, these pieces of information are held to be sentences or propositions.

positions.statement: Whether propositions about events are logically connected depends on how we describe the events
positions.verbatim_quote: But this last statement, in its turn, is true only when subject to a heavy qualification. Depending on how we describe A and B, a proposition affirming the existence of the one might entail one affirming the existence of the other.

positions.statement: That simple descriptions don't entail each other doesn't prove events lack internal connections
positions.verbatim_quote: For similar reasons, given only that (*) doesn't entail (**), we cannot infer that A and B have only a contingent relation to each other. What we can infer is either that A is only contingently related to B or that (*) and (**) leave out the relevant data. I believe that (*) and (**) leave out the relevant data, and that the relation between A and B is in no way contingent.

positions.statement: There are no instantaneous states of affairs
positions.verbatim_quote: Are there instantaneous states of affairs? Is there anything that exists in three, but not in four, dimensions? Of course, we sometimes speak about instantaneous states of affairs. But, it is now generally held, such talk is elliptical for talk of arbitrarily short, non-instantaneous states of affairs.

positions.statement: Talk of instantaneous properties is elliptical for limit-statements about intervals
positions.verbatim_quote: When we say that such that such and such is what obtains at a given instant t, we mean that what obtains during smaller and smaller intervals containing t approximates arbitrarily well to such and such.

positions.statement: There are no strictly non-dynamic spatiotemporal properties
positions.verbatim_quote: But exactly similar considerations warrant the view that there can no instantaneous temperature, mass, color, shape, spin, and so on. There are no strictly non-dynamic spatiotemporal properties – no property such that possession of it doesn't involve movement.

positions.statement: No complete description of any state of affairs can avoid temporal duration
positions.verbatim_quote: A corollary is that there is no complete description of any state of affairs that does not say what happens over a stretch of time.

positions.statement: Complete descriptions of events must include descriptions of subsequent events
positions.verbatim_quote: In that case, a complete description of the occurrences during int would include a description of occurrences happening after int. So a complete description of the relevant mass-energy displacement (the relevant electron-jump or whatnot) would include a description of some later event E.

positions.statement: If complete descriptions include subsequent events, this shatters Hume's view of no necessary connections
positions.verbatim_quote: This would have two consequences. First it would mean that any description of any given event would include a description of subsequent events. That by itself would shatter Hume's view that there is no necessary connection between any event and any subsequent event.

positions.statement: There would be logical connections between events connected by continuous series
positions.verbatim_quote: By this reasoning, there is a strictly logical connection between (complete descriptions of) any two events that are connected by a continuous series of events.

positions.statement: Payment of bonuses enormously improves productivity without any doubt
positions.verbatim_quote: Does the payment of bonuses really improve productivity? Yes, enormously, without any doubt.

positions.statement: Bonuses work differently for creative versus low-level workers - talent must be rewarded while low-level workers are less motivated by bonuses
positions.verbatim_quote: If you are dealing with low level workersboozers who are putting rocks in a bagthen not so much, since they are more interested in how little they can do and get by than they are in moving forward. But with talentgotta reward it.

positions.statement: A consistent set of sentences can be extended to a maximal consistent set through a specific construction
positions.verbatim_quote: Let S be a consistent statement set, and let s1 be an arbitrary statement not in S. If s1 is consistent with S, then the union of S and s1 is consistent; otherwise, the union of S and not s1 is consistent.

positions.statement: The distinction between good and bad clients is utterly sharp and predictable
positions.verbatim_quote: The line good between clients and dirty clients is utterly sharp. There are good clients who are annoying and may even be bad people in some contexts, but they pay and they are honest about what you have done for them.

positions.statement: Bad clients reveal themselves quickly through dishonesty about work performed
positions.verbatim_quote: The dirty clients lie about what you done-and they show their true colors pretty much right away (after one or two meetings, sometimes one or two minutes).

positions.statement: Social media influencers provide value by facilitating information flow
positions.verbatim_quote: Social media facilitates the flow of information, and social media influencers can help people benefit from that increased flow

positions.statement: Starting a startup straight out of college is advisable if you have a legitimate business idea
positions.verbatim_quote: If you have a legitimate business idea, then you have more answers than just about anyone you come across, and you should go for it.

positions.statement: People in miserable jobs tend to discourage others from pursuing good business ideas
positions.verbatim_quote: if you ask other people if your idea is good, they are likely to say no if it is good and yes if it is bad, because they are stuck at miserable jobs and want you to be stuck with them.

positions.statement: Facebook demonstrates that ideas that seem bad on paper can still succeed
positions.verbatim_quote: Considered on paper, is Facebook a good idea? Probably not, but it worked, and thats the end of it.

positions.statement: Several scientific paradoxes were later proven logical, including framework invariance of speed of light
positions.verbatim_quote: 1. Framework invariance of speed of light 2. Non-additivity of length and mass 3. Existence of unconscious 4. Absence of deterministic model of quantum phenomena

positions.statement: Species-level fitness is often opposite to individual-level fitness
positions.verbatim_quote: Species level fitness often opposite of individual level fitness (cows as a species highly successful, even though any given cow is heading to the slaughter house; genius members of homo sapiens very successful even though the genius subpopulation is proving not so good at keeping itself going)

positions.statement: Procuring/pimping doesn't deserve its bad reputation when conducted properly
positions.verbatim_quote: procuring, meaning being a pimp or madam. those professions, when conducted properly, minimize the spread of disease and provide healthy outlets for energies that are otherwise expressed neurotically.

positions.statement: It is absolutely acceptable for a man to hit a woman in self-defense without qualifications
positions.verbatim_quote: Is it ever acceptable for a man to hit a woman in self-defense? Absolutely. 100%. No qualifications.

positions.statement: Mathematical logic is sterile and poorly taught, which explains lack of interest
positions.verbatim_quote: Mathematical logic is a bit sterile, and thats probably what youre picking up on. Plus, the people who teach it are kind of in the weeds, in terms of ability-level and vision.

positions.statement: No single case exists of an anomaly being definitively resolved by two incompatible hypotheses
positions.verbatim_quote: Identify a single case of a given anomaly being definitively resolved by two incompatible hypotheses. No such case exists.

positions.statement: Nothing mathematically proven is false, though there are counterintuitive models of axioms
positions.verbatim_quote: Short answer-no: since nothing proven is false. Long answer-there have turned out to be models of axioms that seem self-evidently false.

positions.statement: Non-Euclidean geometry provides models where the parallel axiom is false and describes actual space
positions.verbatim_quote: There are models in which the parallel axiom (parallels dont intersect) is false, and one of those models describes actual space.

positions.statement: Macroeconomics is social psychology insofar as it relates to commercial behavior
positions.verbatim_quote: Macroeconomics is social psychology, in so far as the latter relates to commercial behavior.

positions.statement: Randomness is not more important than effort and talent in determining life outcomes
positions.verbatim_quote: How important is randomness in life? Is it more important than effort and talent? Absolutely not. It is is very hard to keep someone down if he has talent and character.

positions.statement: Standardized tests are efficient for approximate knowledge but limited for individuals
positions.verbatim_quote: Standardized tests are extraordinarily efficient and are indicated in contexts where only very approximate knowledge is necessary or where knowledge about whole populations (e.g. people who may have been exposed to toxins leading to psychological impairments) are necessary. With individuals, they are of limited use

positions.statement: Bad thoughts about Allah occur because religious tyranny constrains freedom
positions.verbatim_quote: You think bad thoughts about Allah because you want to be free and somebody is using religious tyranny to constrain you. Accept that, and your intrusive thoughts about Allah will vanish.

positions.statement: All people understand mathematics; mathematical talent is about operationalizing this understanding in new contexts
positions.verbatim_quote: I think that all people do understand it. What we refer to as mathematical talent is about being able to operationalize mathematical intelligence outside of those contexts in which it is automatically operational.

positions.statement: School does not provide the tools needed for adulthood
positions.verbatim_quote: Does school give us the tools we need in our adulthood? No it doesnt. It doesnt give us the requisite technical skills. Nor does it give us the requisite understanding of the economy or of its psychological underpinnings.

positions.statement: Simply viewing websites cannot lead to arrest; transactional engagement is required
positions.verbatim_quote: you have to make a purchase or otherwise engage the website in a transactional manner. otherwise no.

positions.statement: It is a moral obligation to visit morally questionable websites to resist bureaucratic control
positions.verbatim_quote: you should actually see it as your moral obligation to visit as many morally questionable websites as possible , since not doing so means conceding moral legitimacy to blockhead bureaucrats and moralizing phonies.

positions.statement: It is not essential to study the same subject for PhD as for master's thesis
positions.verbatim_quote: absolutely not. my masters thesis was on definite descriptions, and my doctoral thesis was on legal positivism.

positions.statement: Being able to financially destroy someone through marriage is morally wrong but legal
positions.verbatim_quote: Being able to destroy somebody financially simply because you were married to them.

positions.statement: Thoughts of hurting a cat are the mind's way of indicating sexual needs
positions.verbatim_quote: You want to hurt your cat-your minds way of telling you that you need to pound some p*ssy. Not hard to decrypt.

positions.statement: Men and women cannot be friends because they want different things from each other
positions.verbatim_quote: Because men dont want friendship from women, and women dont want friendship from men. Men want sex and love (in that order) from women, and women want love and sex (in that order) from men.

positions.statement: OCD can recrudesce at any point but is unlikely to originate after adolescence
positions.verbatim_quote: It can certainly recrudesce at any juncture in life. But it is not likely to come into existence after adolescence.

positions.statement: Identity has a fixed true self; what is fluid is how one lives out this true self
positions.verbatim_quote: What is fluid is how your live out your true self, not what your true self is.

positions.statement: Teachers will be the next major job replaced by robots
positions.verbatim_quote: The next big oneteachers. Most of that is best automated.

positions.statement: Philosophers abandoned logical atomism because physical simplicity doesn't equal conceptual simplicity
positions.verbatim_quote: Two reasons. (1) Physical simplicity doesnt equate to conceptual simplicity. (2) Whether a given statement is to be regarded as complex, and how exactly it is to be regarded as complex, depends on the dialectical context.

positions.statement: There are no ultimate foundational truths because any truth entails and is entailed by infinitely many others
positions.verbatim_quote: Any given truth is entailed by infinitely many others and itself entails infinitely many truths. And since a statements entailment-relations (what it entails and what it entails it) reflect its structure, there are no ultimate, foundational truths.

positions.statement: Men can mature emotionally in the sense of learning how their welfare connects to others
positions.verbatim_quote: If by mature, you mean learn how their own welfare is tied to that of other people, including, in some cases, that of their significant other, then, not so sadly, the answer, once again, is yes.

positions.statement: Someone's weaknesses are found by comparing what they are to what they want to be
positions.verbatim_quote: Know what they are and what they want to be. If they fall short, that is their weakness. If they dont, they have no weaknesses.

positions.statement: Women would design the perfect woman for men to be like an actual woman in the first 18 months
positions.verbatim_quote: Like an actual woman during the first 18 months of the relationship.

positions.statement: Being a member of a set does not imply being a subset
positions.verbatim_quote: No, at least not in general. You are a member of the set of people, but you are not a set or therefore a subset.

positions.statement: Formal study of economics at any level is a waste of time
positions.verbatim_quote: The formal study of economics at any level is the very definition of a waste of time.

positions.statement: Academic economics involves useless models with zero predictive power that rewire the brain destructively
positions.verbatim_quote: when you study economics in a classroom, all you are doing is doing monkey math that relates to monkey models that have zero predictive or explanatory power and will just rewire your brain in a way that makes it useless to everybody, especially employers.

positions.statement: Pan-handlers are more likely to predict economic outcomes than economists
positions.verbatim_quote: If you ask a pan-handler and an economist what will happen to the local (or national or international) economy in one week/month/year/decade, the pan-handler is more likely to be right.

positions.statement: Descartes claimed ideas cannot be false when considered solely in themselves because truth requires an external referent
positions.verbatim_quote: Truth is a relationship between idea and external referent. Descartes is saying that he will discard the referent; and in the absence of said referent, it cannot be said whether or not the idea is true or false.

positions.statement: The genius paradox is that intellectual advantage is outweighed by social disadvantage
positions.verbatim_quote: Your intellectual advantage is outweighed by your social disadvantage.

positions.statement: Psychosis involves garbling mental representations while dissociation suppresses emotional accompaniments
positions.verbatim_quote: Psychosis involves a garbling or scrambling of ones mental representations of external reality... Dissociation does not necessarily involve such distortions; it involves a suppression of the emotional accompaniments of ones representations of the world

positions.statement: The most dangerous question in philosophy is whether political solutions can address biological or cultural problems
positions.verbatim_quote: The most dangerous question in philosophy is whether there can be political solutions to biologically or culturally rooted problems.

positions.statement: Zeno's paradox shows motion presupposes prior motion, leading to the conclusion nothing moves
positions.verbatim_quote: In order to travel a distance of n yards, it is necessary to travel a distance of n/10 yards... (i) one cannot travel any distance at all without already having traveled some smaller distance. Consequently, (ii) Any given motion presupposes a prior motion... (v) Nothing moves.

positions.statement: Mills' solution to Zeno's paradox fails because it eliminates continuity of identity
positions.verbatim_quote: If you are obliterated and some person who is exactly like you appears a moment later right next to where you were standing, that person isnt you.

positions.statement: Russell's solution fails because it doesn't explain how the first step can be taken
positions.verbatim_quote: Zeno is asking how a given object can take that first step... Russell hasnt answered that question. He has only made the irrelevant point that if a given object can move that first inch, then it can, after an infinite series of further motions, move a second inch.

positions.statement: The actual solution to Zeno's paradox is that all position is relative and motion is systemic change
positions.verbatim_quote: All position is relative position. Therefore, changes in position are changes in relative position... What we think of as a case of motion on the part of a given object xi is really a change undergone by x1xn collectively.

positions.statement: Gödel was not influenced by Wittgenstein because they held opposite views on mathematical realism
positions.verbatim_quote: He was not. Godel an arch-Platonist and arch-realist about mathematical entities... Wittgenstein, by contrast, was a radical anti-realist. His position was that mathematical truths are pure conventionsmere games.

positions.statement: Logic as taught is a heap of artifacts that fails to automate thought effectively
positions.verbatim_quote: logic, as it is taught in philosophy and even in math departments, is a heap of artifacts. supposedly the discipline is meant to discover ways to automate thought, but the algorithms it produces to that end require more thought to use than they succeed in automating.

positions.statement: Academic papers are useless because nobody reads them and they contain no meaningful content
positions.verbatim_quote: Yes. Nobody reads them. Ever. Unless theyre looking for a lead-in for their own never-to-be-read (because not worthy of being read) recycle-job.

positions.statement: Incompleteness implies mechanical but not absolute undecidability
positions.verbatim_quote: Incompleteness implies mechanical but not absolute undecidability. For a statement-set to be incomplete is for there to be no recursion that generates it.

positions.statement: One must necessarily be a Platonist to believe in mathematics or logic
positions.verbatim_quote: One must necessarily be a Platonist. There is no way to replace references to numbers, mathematical operations, or other mathematical structures with references to spatiotemporal entities.

positions.statement: Physical operations alter operands while mathematical operations do not
positions.verbatim_quote: Proof is that any physical alteration alters the operands, whereas no arithmetical operation does so. (Rocks are altered when moved; numbers are not altered when added.)

positions.statement: High IQ university graduates strongly tend to out-earn IQ-comparable non-graduates
positions.verbatim_quote: High IQ university graduates strongly tend to out-earn IQ-comparable non-graduates.

positions.statement: Low IQ vocationally trained non-graduates strongly tend to out-earn IQ-comparable college graduates and non-graduates without vocational training
positions.verbatim_quote: Low IQ vocationally trained non-graduates strongly tend to out-earn IQ-comparable college graduates and non-graduates without vocational training.

positions.statement: Medium-IQ graduates marginally tend to out-earn IQ-comparable vocationally trained non-graduates, but vocationally trained non-graduates have dramatically higher levels of fulfillment
positions.verbatim_quote: Medium-IQ graduates marginally tend to out-earn IQ-comparable vocationally trained non-graduates, with the qualification that that medium-IQ vocationally trained non-graduates have dramatically higher levels of fulfillment.

positions.statement: Non-vocationally trained non-graduates are at the bottom of the hierarchy
positions.verbatim_quote: Non-vocationally trained non-graduates are at the bottom of the hierarchy.

positions.statement: College is a sham that will become obsolete due to digital resources
positions.verbatim_quote: College is a sham, and within a few years, judicious use of already existing digital resources will see to it that it is a distant memory.

positions.statement: An incompleteness theorem is one that shows there is no recursive definition of a given statement-class
positions.verbatim_quote: An incompleteness theorem is one to the effect that there is no recursive definition of a given statement-class.

positions.statement: The first incompleteness theorem was Cantor's proof that there is no recursive definition of the class of truths about real numbers
positions.verbatim_quote: The first such theorem was that there is no recursive definition of the class of truths of the form x is a real number. This was proved by George Cantor in the 1870s, and the proof involved a technique known as diagonalization.

positions.statement: Godel tried to create a recursive definition of arithmetical truths, failed, then proved it was impossible using diagonalization
positions.verbatim_quote: Fifty years later, Godel tried to come up with a recursive definition of the class of arithmetical truths. He couldnt and then decided to prove that no such definition was possible. He succeeded. His proof involved an exotic form of diagonalization.

positions.statement: Nothing flies in the face of logic but is still true, because contradictions between facts and logic mean the wrong logic is being used
positions.verbatim_quote: Nothing, since contradictions between facts and logic means that the wrong logic is being used.

positions.statement: Deductive reasoning yields insight but not knowledge
positions.verbatim_quote: It yields insight but not knowledge.

positions.statement: Post hoc ergo propter hoc fallacy: Jim got sick after showing up to work, therefore going to work caused his sickness
positions.verbatim_quote: Jim got sick after he showed up to work. Therefore, going to work is what caused Him to get sick.

positions.statement: Correlation-causation fallacy: atheists are statistically more intelligent, therefore atheism is a sign of intelligence
positions.verbatim_quote: Statistically, people who believe in God are on average less intelligent than atheists. Therefore, atheism is a sign of intelligence.

positions.statement: False linear extrapolation fallacy: one pill makes you twice as good, therefore ten pills make you ten times better
positions.verbatim_quote: Taking one pill makes you twice as good. Therefore, taking 10 pills makes you feel 10 times better.

positions.statement: Abductive reasoning is simply hypothesis-formation
positions.verbatim_quote: Abductive reasoning is simply hypothesis-formation.

positions.statement: Abductive reasoning example: cheese disappearing with mouse-sized bites and footprints leads to hypothesis that a mouse is eating the cheese
positions.verbatim_quote: Your cheese is vanishing. You notice an increasing number of mouse-size bites out of your hunk of cheddar cheese and an increasing number of mouse-size footprints in vicinity of said cheese. You hypothesize, i.e. abductively reason, that a mouse is eating your cheese. This is abductive inference.

positions.statement: Abductive reasoning has innumerable benefits over deduction because you cannot deduce many empirical conclusions
positions.verbatim_quote: As for its benefits over deduction, they are innumerable. You cannot deduce that a mouse is eating your cheese.

positions.statement: Deductive reasoning works when conclusions are analytically contained in premises, but not for empirical hypotheses
positions.verbatim_quote: If you can know that x is a triangle, you can deduce that x has three sides, since x is a triangle is analytically incompatible with x does not have three sides. But a mouse is not eating my cheese is not analytically compatible with the aforementioned data.

positions.statement: It is impossible to create a logical system without modus ponens because it is essential for inference
positions.verbatim_quote: Not possible. Modus ponens is basically to the effect that you can infer it if it follows. Without it, you are in dry dock, inference-wise.

positions.statement: Alternative formulations of modus ponens don't eliminate it since they rely on definitional equivalences
positions.verbatim_quote: Of course, you can always tinker with the way it is expressed. Instead of saying ((P->Q) &P)->Q, you can say: -((-P or Q)&Q)&-Q) But given that P->Q is definitionally equivalent with -P or Q, this isnt exactly a way to get rid of modus ponens.

positions.statement: When MBA holders succeed as entrepreneurs, it's not due to business school learning

positions.statement: MBA jobs provide security but destroy your soul with meaningless corporate work

positions.statement: Socrates tried to improve the world by making it more logical, while Jesus tried to make it more emotional and less legalistic

positions.verbatim_quote: All that matters is the relationship between antecedent and consequent. The truth-values of antecedent and consequent are irrelevant, with the qualification that, if the conditional is true, then the consequent cannot be false if the antecedent is true.

positions.verbatim_quote: By the same token, even if both antecedent and consequent are true, the conditional may be false. For example, if Warren Buffet is from Nebraska, then Warren Buffet is a billionaire is a false conditional with a true antecedent and a true consequent.

positions.statement: Consistency is a consequence of truth, not vice versa

positions.statement: Sartre's main message 'existence precedes essence' is the right message for our time and all times

positions.statement: Universities are not threatened by low retention and graduation rates because they sell degrees, not instruction
positions.verbatim_quote: universities are in no way threatened by low retention-rates and graduation-rates

positions.statement: Universities cannot improve educational quality without endangering their existence

positions.statement: Retention rate is the percentage of students who stay after the first year
positions.verbatim_quote: A university's retention rate is the percentage of students who stay after the first year

positions.statement: Graduation rate is the percentage of students who graduate within six years of enrollment
positions.verbatim_quote: A university's graduation rate is the percentage of students who graduate within six years of enrollment

positions.statement: Universities have financial reasons to want high retention but not necessarily high graduation rates
positions.verbatim_quote: From a financial perspective, a university has relatively cogent reasons to want a high retention rate: when a student doesn't enroll for a second year, that university loses business, and it doesn't when he does. A university has less strong reasons to want a high graduation rate. If a student comes back year after year and never graduates, the university makes more money than it does if he graduates

positions.statement: Great Basin College has extremely low rates but remains financially stable
positions.verbatim_quote: Great Basin College in Nevada has a retention rate of 4% and a graduation rate of 0%, but it is not in financial trouble

positions.statement: Universities would lose their customer base if they made changes to improve retention
positions.verbatim_quote: If a university made the systemic changes to itself necessary to improve retention rates, it would lose most of its existing customer-base

positions.statement: Universities sell degrees, not instruction or services
positions.verbatim_quote: Universities pay people for degrees. That is what universities sell, and that is what people pay them for; and with relatively minor qualifications, that is all that people pay them for

positions.statement: The fundamental difference between universities and open market companies is what they sell
positions.verbatim_quote: There is one very important difference between universities and OMC's. OMC's sell products and services. That is what people pay them for. That is all they pay them for. That is not what people pay universities for

positions.statement: A hypothetical William & Mary that improved instruction but stopped giving degrees would see enrollment plummet
positions.verbatim_quote: William & Mary magically improves the quality of its instruction 100% and it cuts its tuition in half: but it stops issuing degrees. So whatever it is that one can currently learn at William & Mary about physics, psychology or any other subject, one can now learn twice as well for half as much money. But one cannot get a degree in that subject from William & Mary. Under these circumstances, William & Mary's enrollment rate would plummet, possibly to zero

positions.statement: Degrees function as necessary credentials for professional opportunities regardless of actual learning
positions.verbatim_quote: Max is a mathematical genius who has completely mastered his discipline... But he doesn't have a college degree, and he has never attended college. What can Max do professionally? He cannot be a professor. He cannot publish in academic journals. He cannot be a high-school teacher

positions.statement: College degrees provide access to white-collar employment regardless of intelligence or competence
positions.verbatim_quote: Jane is a person of average or marginally above intelligence who has a degree in psychology. Tammy is exactly as intelligent as Jane, both psychologically and otherwise, but does not have a college degree. For Jane, the possibilities are endless... But what about Tammy? What are her options? She cannot become a licensed therapist. She cannot work for a corporation, except in a menial capacity

positions.statement: College attendance is rational even when outcomes are uncertain because degrees provide options
positions.verbatim_quote: People with degrees have options, and people without degrees don't. People with useful degrees from high-prestige institutions have many very good options; people with useless degrees from low prestige institutions have fewer options and they are not as good—but they are still good in absolute terms, and they are still plentiful. People without degrees do not have options

positions.statement: Students don't want high-quality demanding instruction since they're paying for degrees
positions.verbatim_quote: since they are paying for degrees, they want to have to jump through as few hoops as possible to get those degrees

positions.statement: Enrollment rates matter for university finances, not retention or graduation rates
positions.verbatim_quote: it isn't retention rates that matter: it is enrollment rates. If enough people enroll, then the university is financially ok

positions.statement: Universities with extremely low retention rates can operate profitably by targeting marginal students
positions.verbatim_quote: Suppose that a university's target-customer is somebody who desperately wants a college degree but, in terms of finances or intellect, is just on the cusp on of being able to complete a college degree. It may well that for every hundred such people who enroll, only four are able to make it to the second year

positions.statement: Universities have distinctive business models that prevent rapid organizational change
positions.verbatim_quote: An OMC can turn on a dime. It can replace its entire labor force. It can start making new products. It can fire its CEO... But universities sell degrees—nothing else

positions.statement: Universities depend on providing instruction that is just good enough to maintain degree prestige
positions.verbatim_quote: the ideal situation for a university is when its degrees have prestige and as few people as possible are actually giving them that prestige

positions.statement: Most students want well-paid jobs with poorly defined functions rather than useful employment
positions.verbatim_quote: What most college students want, at least if their eventual careers are any indication, is to be relatively useless and employed

positions.statement: Advanced economies can support large populations of unproductive workers
positions.verbatim_quote: In economies of scale, there is enormous division of labor, and only a small percent of the population actually has to produce. The more advanced an economy is, the greater the percentage of people in it who can be useless

positions.statement: College dropouts often make rational decisions based on cost-benefit analysis
positions.verbatim_quote: When people drop out, it is usually (not always) because it isn't worth it for them to stay

positions.statement: Knowledge management cannot help universities because they depend on poor internal communications
positions.verbatim_quote: Unlike OMC's, universities actually depend on poor internal communications

positions.statement: Knowledge Management explains how institutions must organize to optimize information flow
positions.verbatim_quote: KM explains how institutions must be organized if knowledge-exchanges that must occur are to occur

positions.statement: University departments remain isolated to protect professors from scrutiny
positions.verbatim_quote: if a philosophy professor teamed up with an economics professor, that philosophy professor could (and probably would) be called out economics students who were not under his thumb

positions.statement: The solution is to create new educational institutions rather than reform existing universities
positions.verbatim_quote: if one wants to improve education and to make money doing so, there is at the current an enormous opportunity. Right now is the perfect time to make education affordable, fast, effective, and also (for the owner of the educational service in question) extremely lucrative

positions.statement: DMO will be a results-based online university that sells competence rather than prestige
positions.verbatim_quote: The most important fact about DMO is that students pay for results, not services. Therefore, a degree from DMO must be proof of competence. DMO does not sell prestige; it sells competence

positions.statement: Organizations that sell results have well-defined objectives enabling good knowledge management
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowledge-management is possible when the organization in question has definite objectives, and when it does not have definite objectives, knowledge-management is as difficult as those objectives are vague

positions.statement: Service organizations depend on poor knowledge management to maintain inefficiencies
positions.verbatim_quote: When people within a given organization have an incentive to block communications within it, information tends to be blocked, and people within service organizations tend to have such incentives

positions.statement: Education must be digitized whenever possible for efficiency and cost reduction
positions.verbatim_quote: when education can be digitized, it must be digitized... since doing so saves time and money and makes it easy for purchase custom-made education from the best instructors at the lowest possible price

positions.statement: At DMO, instructors are paid directly by students based on performance, not by the institution
positions.verbatim_quote: students must negotiate prices directly with instructors, and payments must go straight to the instructor. The instructor will give a percentage of his earnings to DMO in exchange for use of the platform, business volume, credibility, instructional materials, and the like

positions.statement: DMO will use independent examination-based accreditation rather than instructor grading
positions.verbatim_quote: At DMO, instructors do not issue grades. There are no grades. There are accreditations. Accreditations are attained by taking examinations. These examinations are graded anonymously (by computer, whenever possible). They are designed and administered by independent third parties

positions.statement: DMO will convert liberal arts students to STEM through 'lite' science degrees
positions.verbatim_quote: Its primary solution will be to offer lite science degrees: lite-physics, lite-math; math for computer scientists; lite biology. In this way, DMO gets people out of the doldrums of the liberal arts and into STEM

positions.statement: DMO will be non-discriminatory and service all students unlike traditional universities
positions.verbatim_quote: DMO has the first business model. Other universities have the second... If universities really sold instruction—in other words, if they made their money by seeing to it that people left them more competent than they came to them---they would want as many customers as possible

positions.statement: DMO can offer multiple degree levels because individual courses have guaranteed meaning
positions.verbatim_quote: the greater the guarantee that a given course has meaning, and the greater the degree of specificity as to what meaning is, the fewer courses a student will have to take in order for that student to be recognized as having merit

positions.statement: Students must be able to test out of courses to ensure instructors provide value rather than gatekeeping
positions.verbatim_quote: DMO always offers students the ability to 'test out.' In other words, a student can get a given accreditation just by passing the examination in question: no time need be spent 'in class.'... As long as students have the option of testing out, it is guaranteed that students only pay instructors for actual instruction

positions.statement: The inverted payment pyramid at DMO creates lean and functional operations
positions.verbatim_quote: At a conventional university, the money flows down. Students pay the university; the university pays instructors. The result: expensive and bad education. At DMO, the money flows up

positions.statement: DMO will eliminate disciplines without practical value or objective assessment
positions.verbatim_quote: Disciplines that have no practical value should either be jettisoned or modified so to have practical value... Disciplines that do not admit of objective assessments should either be jettisoned or modified so to admit of such assessments

positions.statement: Student evaluations should be minimized in favor of performance-based instructor assessment
positions.verbatim_quote: The use of student evaluations should be minimized or eliminated. Student input should concern professionalism of instructor. The instructor's merit should be determined by student-performance, not by opinion or sentiment

positions.statement: DMO hiring will be based solely on proven success with student outcomes
positions.verbatim_quote: Hirings are to be made exclusively on proven or probable success helping students pass accreditation exams. Therefore, publications are irrelevant to hiring decision, and so are letters of reference

positions.statement: Existing universities cannot and should not be reformed
positions.verbatim_quote: There is little hope of reforming unviersities. They don't want to be reformed, and they don't stand to gain by being reformed

positions.statement: Universities depend on inefficiency and poor knowledge management for their business model
positions.verbatim_quote: universities depend for their very existences on poor knowledge management... Universities fall into this category. They do provide some legitimate services, but these only account for a fraction of their revenue, the rest coming from overpriced ancillary services

positions.statement: Universities have vague and incoherent objectives that prevent effective knowledge management
positions.verbatim_quote: Their objectives are therefore vague and incoherent, and it is correspondingly unclear what kind of information university-employees should make one another aware of

positions.statement: The solution is creating new results-based educational services rather than reforming universities
positions.verbatim_quote: The right way to provide the public with better instruction is to create a new kind of educational service that is results-based and whose revenue is hewed to its pedagogical efficacy
