positions.verbatim_quote: Colors are mind-dependent but not mental.

positions.statement: The empiricist puts headaches in the same category as concern for one's child's welfare, but this is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: The empiricist puts headaches in the same category as concern for one's child's welfare, but this is false.

positions.statement: Emotions are not merely "sentiments" equivalent to bodily sensations.
positions.verbatim_quote: Emotions are not merely "sentiments" equivalent to bodily sensations.

positions.statement: Meanings are identical with sets of properties.
positions.verbatim_quote: Meanings are identical with sets of properties.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein's view that "meaning is use" is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wittgenstein's view that "meaning is use" is false.

positions.statement: If expression-tokens were nothing but bursts of noise, there could be linguistic activity on planets without sentient life (reductio).
positions.verbatim_quote: If expression-tokens were nothing but bursts of noise, there could be linguistic activity on planets without sentient life (reductio).

positions.statement: Attempts to scientize psychology have typically been attempts to empiricize it.
positions.verbatim_quote: Attempts to scientize psychology have typically been attempts to empiricize it.

positions.statement: Freud and Chomsky succeeded in scientizing certain sub-domains of psychology.
positions.verbatim_quote: Freud and Chomsky succeeded in scientizing certain sub-domains of psychology.

positions.statement: There is unconscious ideation.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is unconscious ideation.

positions.statement: There is ideation that is not only unconscious but subpersonal.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is ideation that is not only unconscious but subpersonal.

positions.statement: People can rationalize and deceive themselves.
positions.verbatim_quote: People can rationalize and deceive themselves.

positions.statement: People can repress knowledge they wish they didn't have.
positions.verbatim_quote: People can repress knowledge they wish they didn't have.

positions.statement: People can be internally conflicted, and internal conflict is a battle between conscious and unconscious conceits.
positions.verbatim_quote: People can be internally conflicted, and internal conflict is a battle between conscious and unconscious conceits.

positions.statement: Repressed emotions may be expressed as symptoms.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repressed emotions may be expressed as symptoms.

positions.statement: The concept of repression is coherent despite seemingly cogent arguments against it.
positions.verbatim_quote: The concept of repression is coherent despite seemingly cogent arguments against it.

positions.statement: A psychopath is someone who doesn't have a conscience and never had one.
positions.verbatim_quote: A psychopath is someone who doesn't have a conscience and never had one.

positions.statement: A sociopath is someone who had a conscience but ceased to have one.
positions.verbatim_quote: A sociopath is someone who had a conscience but ceased to have one.

positions.statement: Sociopathogenesis involves implementing a certain sort of rationalization.
positions.verbatim_quote: Sociopathogenesis involves implementing a certain sort of rationalization.

positions.statement: Sociopaths are people who "sell out" and "die inside."
positions.verbatim_quote: Sociopaths are people who "sell out" and "die inside."

positions.statement: The pre-sociopath has values, internal conflict, capacity to love, and grasps non-instrumental goodness.
positions.verbatim_quote: The pre-sociopath has values, internal conflict, capacity to love, and grasps non-instrumental goodness.

positions.statement: The sociopath lacks values, internal conflict, capacity to love, and grasp of non-instrumental goodness.
positions.verbatim_quote: The sociopath lacks values, internal conflict, capacity to love, and grasp of non-instrumental goodness.

positions.statement: Psychopathy is a kind of perpetual infantilism.
positions.verbatim_quote: Psychopathy is a kind of perpetual infantilism.

positions.statement: Linguistic competence enhances cognitive competence.
positions.verbatim_quote: Linguistic competence enhances cognitive competence.

positions.statement: There is nothing to thinking other than manipulating symbols (rejected position).
positions.verbatim_quote: There is nothing to thinking other than manipulating symbols (rejected position).

positions.statement: Anything thinkable with symbols is thinkable without them (alternative position, also problematic).
positions.verbatim_quote: Anything thinkable with symbols is thinkable without them (alternative position, also problematic).

positions.statement: One must figure out what is meant by complex expressions; meaning cannot be directly determined by convention for complex expressions.
positions.verbatim_quote: One must figure out what is meant by complex expressions; meaning cannot be directly determined by convention for complex expressions.

positions.statement: Without linguistic competence, a creature could not think discursively at the level of Adam Smith's Wealth of Nations.
positions.verbatim_quote: Without linguistic competence, a creature could not think discursively at the level of Adam Smith's Wealth of Nations.

positions.statement: Linguistic competence is constitutively, not merely causally, related to cognitive competence.
positions.verbatim_quote: Linguistic competence is constitutively, not merely causally, related to cognitive competence.

positions.statement: It is a conceptual necessity, not an idiosyncrasy of human psychology, that certain cogitations need linguistic vehicles.
positions.verbatim_quote: It is a conceptual necessity, not an idiosyncrasy of human psychology, that certain cogitations need linguistic vehicles.

positions.statement: There is subpersonal thought underlying conscious, pre-conscious, and repressed ideation.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is subpersonal thought underlying conscious, pre-conscious, and repressed ideation.

positions.statement: Subpersonal cognitive operations mediate vision, language-comprehension, and musical ability.
positions.verbatim_quote: Subpersonal cognitive operations mediate vision, language-comprehension, and musical ability.

positions.statement: Your mind figures out how to convert sensory disturbances into visual images, but not you (your self).
positions.verbatim_quote: Your mind figures out how to convert sensory disturbances into visual images, but not you (your self).

positions.statement: It would be viciously regressive to say the self carried out cognitive operations underlying sense-perception.
positions.verbatim_quote: It would be viciously regressive to say the self carried out cognitive operations underlying sense-perception.

positions.statement: Perception is not mere sensation; perceptions are articulated sensations.
positions.verbatim_quote: Perception is not mere sensation; perceptions are articulated sensations.

positions.statement: Articulations of perception correspond to conceptual knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: Articulations of perception correspond to conceptual knowledge.

positions.statement: Subpersonal, non-iconic ideation becomes hewed to sequences of expression-images.
positions.verbatim_quote: Subpersonal, non-iconic ideation becomes hewed to sequences of expression-images.

positions.statement: Pleasant affects alert us to certain structural features in works of art.
positions.verbatim_quote: Pleasant affects alert us to certain structural features in works of art.

positions.statement: Congenial phenomenology alerts us to positive properties like truthfulness and validity in expression-image series.
positions.verbatim_quote: Congenial phenomenology alerts us to positive properties like truthfulness and validity in expression-image series.

positions.statement: The nucleus of one's self is consciousness.
positions.verbatim_quote: The nucleus of one's self is consciousness.

positions.statement: We don't grasp universals except by way of linguistic symbols (at the personal level).
positions.verbatim_quote: We don't grasp universals except by way of linguistic symbols (at the personal level).

positions.statement: Our minds can grasp universals non-linguistically at the subpersonal level.
positions.verbatim_quote: Our minds can grasp universals non-linguistically at the subpersonal level.

positions.statement: Berkeley conflated images with concepts using the word "idea" for both.
positions.verbatim_quote: Berkeley conflated images with concepts using the word "idea" for both.

positions.statement: Images are not concepts; universals are grasped through conception.
positions.verbatim_quote: Images are not concepts; universals are grasped through conception.

positions.statement: Empiricism cannot countenance non-image-mediated thought.
positions.verbatim_quote: Empiricism cannot countenance non-image-mediated thought.

positions.statement: Concepts are not constituents of consciousness but are access-conscious.
positions.verbatim_quote: Concepts are not constituents of consciousness but are access-conscious.

positions.statement: Empiricism is inimical to the idea of invisible structure.
positions.verbatim_quote: Empiricism is inimical to the idea of invisible structure.

positions.statement: A sentence is meaningful if it attributes some property to some object.
positions.verbatim_quote: A sentence is meaningful if it attributes some property to some object.

positions.statement: Expressions like "the absolute is one" contain undefined terms and therefore say nothing until those terms are defined.
positions.verbatim_quote: Expressions like "the absolute is one" contain undefined terms and therefore say nothing until those terms are defined.

positions.statement: Russell, Tarski, and other logicians were wrong that there are meaningless bona fide sentences.
positions.verbatim_quote: Russell, Tarski, and other logicians were wrong that there are meaningless bona fide sentences.

positions.statement: Alleged antinomies are either false or are sentence-schemata, not actual sentences.
positions.verbatim_quote: Alleged antinomies are either false or are sentence-schemata, not actual sentences.

positions.statement: Russell's Paradox does not demonstrate a counterexample to the Axiom of Comprehension.
positions.verbatim_quote: Russell's Paradox does not demonstrate a counterexample to the Axiom of Comprehension.

positions.statement: The expression "the property of not being a member of itself" does not have a referent; it only appears to have a sense.
positions.verbatim_quote: The expression "the property of not being a member of itself" does not have a referent; it only appears to have a sense.

positions.statement: K₁ ("K is a member of itself") fails to encode a proposition because "itself" doesn't refer to anything.
positions.verbatim_quote: K₁ ("K is a member of itself") fails to encode a proposition because "itself" doesn't refer to anything.

positions.statement: The occurrence of "itself" in Russell's paradox lacks a sense.
positions.verbatim_quote: The occurrence of "itself" in Russell's paradox lacks a sense.

positions.statement: The rules of English semantics are not at fault for apparent paradoxes.
positions.verbatim_quote: The rules of English semantics are not at fault for apparent paradoxes.

positions.statement: When "self" functions anaphorically, it is eliminable.
positions.verbatim_quote: When "self" functions anaphorically, it is eliminable.

positions.statement: Type Theory (TT) is self-defeating because it is given by a sentence that violates its own stricture.
positions.verbatim_quote: Type Theory (TT) is self-defeating because it is given by a sentence that violates its own stricture.

positions.statement: There are two classes of antinomies: meaningless ones and false ones.
positions.verbatim_quote: There are two classes of antinomies: meaningless ones and false ones.

positions.statement: "This sentence is false" tokens are neither true nor false, not both true and false.
positions.verbatim_quote: "This sentence is false" tokens are neither true nor false, not both true and false.

positions.statement: The semantic rules of English do not permit the construction of sentences that violate the Law of Non-Contradiction.
positions.verbatim_quote: The semantic rules of English do not permit the construction of sentences that violate the Law of Non-Contradiction.

positions.statement: Natural languages are not defective in the way logicians have alleged.
positions.verbatim_quote: Natural languages are not defective in the way logicians have alleged.

positions.statement: What a sentence-token affirms depends on what its parts refer to (principle of compositionality).
positions.verbatim_quote: What a sentence-token affirms depends on what its parts refer to (principle of compositionality).

positions.statement: Sentence-types are not individuated by the physical properties of their tokens.
positions.verbatim_quote: Sentence-types are not individuated by the physical properties of their tokens.

positions.statement: Meaning cannot be use.
positions.verbatim_quote: Meaning cannot be use.

positions.statement: There are meaningful expressions that are never used literally and infinitely many that aren't used at all.
positions.verbatim_quote: There are meaningful expressions that are never used literally and infinitely many that aren't used at all.

positions.statement: Once you know what an expression means, you won't acquire new knowledge about that meaning by acquiring additional knowledge of how that word is used.
positions.verbatim_quote: Once you know what an expression means, you won't acquire new knowledge about that meaning by acquiring additional knowledge of how that word is used.

positions.statement: To say anything, one must produce words intentionally; involuntary utterances are not speech.
positions.verbatim_quote: To say anything, one must produce words intentionally; involuntary utterances are not speech.

positions.statement: In order for anything to mean anything, there must be semantic rules.
positions.verbatim_quote: In order for anything to mean anything, there must be semantic rules.

positions.statement: Duly rule-governed usage of an expression is governed by, and therefore doesn't constitute, its meaning.
positions.verbatim_quote: Duly rule-governed usage of an expression is governed by, and therefore doesn't constitute, its meaning.

positions.statement: Concepts are the meanings of predicates, not psychological entities.
positions.verbatim_quote: Concepts are the meanings of predicates, not psychological entities.

positions.statement: To know that "number" is the word whose usage one is to study, one must already grasp the concept of number.
positions.verbatim_quote: To know that "number" is the word whose usage one is to study, one must already grasp the concept of number.

positions.statement: Semantic analysis (what linguists do) must not be confused with conceptual analysis (what philosophers do).
positions.verbatim_quote: Semantic analysis (what linguists do) must not be confused with conceptual analysis (what philosophers do).

positions.statement: Words are not individuated strictly by the acoustical properties of their tokens.
positions.verbatim_quote: Words are not individuated strictly by the acoustical properties of their tokens.

positions.statement: Two sounds being tokens of the same word requires same meaning, sufficient acoustic similarity, and bona fide speech.
positions.verbatim_quote: Two sounds being tokens of the same word requires same meaning, sufficient acoustic similarity, and bona fide speech.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein's view that meanings don't exist has been refuted.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wittgenstein's view that meanings don't exist has been refuted.

positions.statement: Platonic objects, if they exist, are not useless for explaining understanding.
positions.verbatim_quote: Platonic objects, if they exist, are not useless for explaining understanding.

positions.statement: Knowing a rule and knowing how to apply it are not separate achievements requiring infinite regress.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowing a rule and knowing how to apply it are not separate achievements requiring infinite regress.

positions.statement: Rule-following is not a strictly psychological phenomenon.
positions.verbatim_quote: Rule-following is not a strictly psychological phenomenon.

positions.verbatim_quote: The difference between someone who understands why F(13) = 169 and someone who believes it spuriously is not psychological.

positions.statement: Thinking is not a psychological process in the sense Wittgenstein supposed.
positions.verbatim_quote: Thinking is not a psychological process in the sense Wittgenstein supposed.

positions.statement: Knowledge of how to apply a rule is built into knowledge of that rule.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowledge of how to apply a rule is built into knowledge of that rule.

positions.statement: Chomsky's distinction between competence and performance resolves apparent problems about rule application.
positions.verbatim_quote: Chomsky's distinction between competence and performance resolves apparent problems about rule application.

positions.statement: Competence is ability; performance is the ability to deploy ability.
positions.verbatim_quote: Competence is ability; performance is the ability to deploy ability.

positions.statement: There is no gulf between knowing a principle and knowing how to apply it under given circumstances.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no gulf between knowing a principle and knowing how to apply it under given circumstances.

positions.verbatim_quote: Given only a person's psychological condition, it is completely indeterminate what that person is thinking (Wittgenstein's false conclusion).

positions.statement: Working with different functions is not psychologically identical.
positions.verbatim_quote: Working with different functions is not psychologically identical.

positions.statement: No accompaniments of rule-following are necessary or sufficient for that act of compliance.
positions.verbatim_quote: No accompaniments of rule-following are necessary or sufficient for that act of compliance.

positions.verbatim_quote: When Wittgenstein refers to "accompaniments" of thought, he refers only to phenomenology, ignoring propositional attitudes.

positions.statement: Propositional attitudes are not constituents of consciousness.
positions.verbatim_quote: Propositional attitudes are not constituents of consciousness.

positions.statement: The deployment of a propositional attitude is not constitutive of consciousness.

positions.statement: Consciousness is to thinking what a driver is to events under his car's hood.

positions.statement: Phenomenologically consecutive images are likely to be ratiocinatively disjoint.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein failed to distinguish access-consciousness from phenomenal consciousness.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wittgenstein failed to distinguish access-consciousness from phenomenal consciousness.

positions.statement: Private language is not impossible; Wittgenstein's argument fails.
positions.verbatim_quote: Private language is not impossible; Wittgenstein's argument fails.

positions.statement: It isn't always other people who penalize those who misuse words.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein confuses language-misuse with language-shift.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein is a hard-core empiricist.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wittgenstein is a hard-core empiricist.

positions.verbatim_quote: Groups of appropriately interrelated zombies do not collectively think (contra Brandom).

positions.verbatim_quote: Empiricists cannot grant the existence of propositions.

positions.statement: If propositions don't exist, translation becomes inexplicable.
positions.verbatim_quote: If propositions don't exist, translation becomes inexplicable.

positions.statement: Quine's view that no sentence is a translation of any sentence is desperate and false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Quine's view that no sentence is a translation of any sentence is desperate and false.

positions.verbatim_quote: We sometimes only need experience of one instance to make reliable generalizations.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein's contention that philosophical argumentation is misconceived was a post hoc attempt to legitimate his wanting arguments.

positions.statement: Quine and Wittgenstein, operating independently, reached the same radically counterintuitive conclusion about interpreting others.

positions.statement: Knowledge of one's propositional attitudes is access-conscious, not consciousness-constitutive.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowledge of one's propositional attitudes is access-conscious, not consciousness-constitutive.

positions.statement: Definitions are not analytic; they describe empirical facts about linguistic usage.
positions.verbatim_quote: Definitions are not analytic; they describe empirical facts about linguistic usage.

positions.statement: There are deep analytic truths that are primitive and cannot fail to be primitive.
positions.verbatim_quote: There are deep analytic truths that are primitive and cannot fail to be primitive.

positions.verbatim_quote: Some analytic truths are absolutely primitive; others are absolutely non-primitive.

positions.statement: 7 + 5 = 12 is not analytic in the sense that one knows it by analyzing constituent concepts.
positions.verbatim_quote: 7 + 5 = 12 is not analytic in the sense that one knows it by analyzing constituent concepts.

positions.statement: Arithmetical truths are known through pure reason, not sense-perception.
positions.verbatim_quote: Arithmetical truths are known through pure reason, not sense-perception.

positions.statement: Kant's view that mathematical truths are synthetic a priori is flawed.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant's view that mathematical truths are synthetic a priori is flawed.

positions.verbatim_quote: Kant erroneously made mathematics a branch of psychology.

positions.statement: Kant's use of "transcendental" obfuscates his actual psychologistic view.

positions.statement: Knowledge that one can or cannot imagine something is empirical and a posteriori.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowledge that one can or cannot imagine something is empirical and a posteriori.

positions.statement: Hume conflated knowledge of abstracta with introspective knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume conflated knowledge of abstracta with introspective knowledge.

positions.statement: One cannot know the self through sense-perception or any inwardly-directed analogue thereof.
positions.verbatim_quote: One cannot know the self through sense-perception or any inwardly-directed analogue thereof.

positions.statement: Hume's argument that there is no self fails because it assumes introspective knowledge is the only non-empirical knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume's argument that there is no self fails because it assumes introspective knowledge is the only non-empirical knowledge.

positions.statement: Introspection is conceptual, not sensory or para-sensory, in nature.
positions.verbatim_quote: Introspection is conceptual, not sensory or para-sensory, in nature.

positions.statement: Knowledge of one's conscious condition is empirical as a conceptualization of experience, like a scientific theory.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowledge of one's conscious condition is empirical as a conceptualization of experience, like a scientific theory.

positions.statement: Having a mental image is not introspecting; introspecting involves noting that one is having such an image.
positions.verbatim_quote: Having a mental image is not introspecting; introspecting involves noting that one is having such an image.

positions.statement: Animals must have concepts given they have sense-perceptions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Animals must have concepts given they have sense-perceptions.

positions.statement: Animals' minds grasp abstracta even though the animals themselves do not.
positions.verbatim_quote: Animals' minds grasp abstracta even though the animals themselves do not.

positions.statement: Dogs and snakes are capable of conceptual ideation at the subpersonal level.
positions.verbatim_quote: Dogs and snakes are capable of conceptual ideation at the subpersonal level.

positions.statement: The Chomskyan unconscious is impersonal; the Freudian unconscious is personal.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Chomskyan unconscious is impersonal; the Freudian unconscious is personal.

positions.statement: There is no intrinsic difference between a propositional attitude that is repressed and one that isn't.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no intrinsic difference between a propositional attitude that is repressed and one that isn't.

positions.statement: There are intrinsic differences between personal and subpersonal strata of mentation.
positions.verbatim_quote: There are intrinsic differences between personal and subpersonal strata of mentation.

positions.statement: One must distinguish self from mind, and the part of mind with which one identifies from another unconscious part.
positions.verbatim_quote: One must distinguish self from mind, and the part of mind with which one identifies from another unconscious part.

positions.statement: There are two very different kinds of unconsciousness: personal (Freudian) and impersonal (Chomskyan).
positions.verbatim_quote: There are two very different kinds of unconsciousness: personal (Freudian) and impersonal (Chomskyan).

positions.statement: Chomsky's position that there is subpersonal mentation is de rigueur given obvious facts.
positions.verbatim_quote: Chomsky's position that there is subpersonal mentation is de rigueur given obvious facts.

positions.statement: Husserl failed to see the bearing of his non-empiricism on his attempts to scientize psychology.
positions.verbatim_quote: Husserl failed to see the bearing of his non-empiricism on his attempts to scientize psychology.

positions.statement: One cannot drain introspections of all conceptual articulations; phenomenological bracketing is impossible.
positions.verbatim_quote: One cannot drain introspections of all conceptual articulations; phenomenological bracketing is impossible.

positions.statement: Perception cannot be described except on the assumption that it is veridical.
positions.verbatim_quote: Perception cannot be described except on the assumption that it is veridical.

positions.statement: Qua student of the mind, one cannot be a strict empiricist.
positions.verbatim_quote: Qua student of the mind, one cannot be a strict empiricist.

positions.statement: Science is not about sticking to the facts but about organizing facts by positing hidden structures.
positions.verbatim_quote: Science is not about sticking to the facts but about organizing facts by positing hidden structures.

positions.statement: Dennett and Churchland's eliminativism about the mental, if cogent, would establish the non-existence of the non-mental as well.
positions.verbatim_quote: Dennett and Churchland's eliminativism about the mental, if cogent, would establish the non-existence of the non-mental as well.

positions.statement: Paraperception is sub-personal truth-awareness embodied in personal object-awareness.
positions.verbatim_quote: Paraperception is sub-personal truth-awareness embodied in personal object-awareness.

positions.statement: The delight one takes in listening to a Bach fugue embodies subpersonal awareness of truths about structural properties of sounds.
