positions.statement: Subpersonal awarenesses are expressed at the personal level in the form of phenomenological episodes.
positions.verbatim_quote: Subpersonal awarenesses are expressed at the personal level in the form of phenomenological episodes.

positions.statement: There is such a thing as subpersonal mentation.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is such a thing as subpersonal mentation.

positions.statement: Subpersonal knowledge is never transferred from one mental stratum to another.
positions.verbatim_quote: Subpersonal knowledge is never transferred from one mental stratum to another.

positions.statement: Conscious knowledge of subpersonal processes is merely an analogue of those processes, not a duplicate.
positions.verbatim_quote: Conscious knowledge of subpersonal processes is merely an analogue of those processes, not a duplicate.

positions.statement: The conscious conceit implanted by the psychoanalyst is a bona fide duplicate of its repressed counterpart.
positions.verbatim_quote: The conscious conceit implanted by the psychoanalyst is a bona fide duplicate of its repressed counterpart.

positions.statement: Subpersonal knowledge described by Chomsky et al. is qualitatively very different from its conscious analogues.
positions.verbatim_quote: Subpersonal knowledge described by Chomsky et al. is qualitatively very different from its conscious analogues.

positions.statement: Sub-personal processes are not strictly physiological; they embody intelligence and are not purely reflexive (contra Searle).
positions.verbatim_quote: Sub-personal processes are not strictly physiological; they embody intelligence and are not purely reflexive (contra Searle).

positions.statement: The English language is a collection of rules.
positions.verbatim_quote: The English language is a collection of rules.

positions.statement: Semantic rules of the form "x refers to y" are highly complex.
positions.verbatim_quote: Semantic rules of the form "x refers to y" are highly complex.

positions.statement: People absorb and apply linguistic rules without the slightest difficulty.
positions.verbatim_quote: People absorb and apply linguistic rules without the slightest difficulty.

positions.statement: Linguistic competence is naturally characterized as mastery of semantic rules.
positions.verbatim_quote: Linguistic competence is naturally characterized as mastery of semantic rules.

positions.statement: The rules of linguistic competence are not access-conscious.
positions.verbatim_quote: The rules of linguistic competence are not access-conscious.

positions.statement: Linguistic rules are either access-unconscious in some deeper sense or they don't exist; the latter view is not viable.
positions.verbatim_quote: Linguistic rules are either access-unconscious in some deeper sense or they don't exist; the latter view is not viable.

positions.statement: There is no viable purely physiological characterization of linguistic competence.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no viable purely physiological characterization of linguistic competence.

positions.statement: If you have conscious, discursive knowledge of word meanings, that knowledge wouldn't operate quickly enough for real-time language comprehension.
positions.verbatim_quote: If you have conscious, discursive knowledge of word meanings, that knowledge wouldn't operate quickly enough for real-time language comprehension.

positions.statement: Mentality and consciousness are not identical.
positions.verbatim_quote: Mentality and consciousness are not identical.

positions.statement: Propositional attitudes cannot be constituents of consciousness.
positions.verbatim_quote: Propositional attitudes cannot be constituents of consciousness.

positions.statement: When propositional attitudes are "conscious," it is in the sense that they are access-conscious.
positions.verbatim_quote: When propositional attitudes are "conscious," it is in the sense that they are access-conscious.

positions.statement: There is no a priori reason why anything access-conscious must be so.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no a priori reason why anything access-conscious must be so.

positions.statement: Any given consciousness must be distinct from its object.
positions.verbatim_quote: Any given consciousness must be distinct from its object.

positions.statement: Distinct objects are such that the existence of one is not logically dependent on the existence of the other.
positions.verbatim_quote: Distinct objects are such that the existence of one is not logically dependent on the existence of the other.

positions.statement: There is no a priori reason why propositional attitudes must be access-conscious.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no a priori reason why propositional attitudes must be access-conscious.

positions.statement: It is coherent to suppose that consciousness might have trouble accessing a given propositional attitude.
positions.verbatim_quote: It is coherent to suppose that consciousness might have trouble accessing a given propositional attitude.

positions.statement: It often takes considerable intellectual resources to be consciously aware of what one believes.
positions.verbatim_quote: It often takes considerable intellectual resources to be consciously aware of what one believes.

positions.statement: Even if beliefs aren't repressed, one may lack the wherewithal to conceptualize them properly.
positions.verbatim_quote: Even if beliefs aren't repressed, one may lack the wherewithal to conceptualize them properly.

positions.statement: It's one thing to have cognitive wherewithal for first-order representations; quite another to correctly conceive of that wherewithal.
positions.verbatim_quote: It's one thing to have cognitive wherewithal for first-order representations; quite another to correctly conceive of that wherewithal.

positions.statement: Without meta-cognitive wherewithal, one can't know what one's propositional attitudes are.
positions.verbatim_quote: Without meta-cognitive wherewithal, one can't know what one's propositional attitudes are.

positions.statement: Searle's view (SV) that mentality is identical with consciousness is logically false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Searle's view (SV) that mentality is identical with consciousness is logically false.

positions.statement: Searle is a dispositionalist about non-consciousness-constitutive mental entities.
positions.verbatim_quote: Searle is a dispositionalist about non-consciousness-constitutive mental entities.

positions.statement: Dispositionalism doesn't model the data.
positions.verbatim_quote: Dispositionalism doesn't model the data.

positions.statement: If beliefs were merely dispositions, knowledge-constitutive beliefs would be nothing more than arbitrary opinions.
positions.verbatim_quote: If beliefs were merely dispositions, knowledge-constitutive beliefs would be nothing more than arbitrary opinions.

positions.statement: Non-occurrent mental structures are functioning as mental entities between bouts of generating conscious states and behaviors.
positions.verbatim_quote: Non-occurrent mental structures are functioning as mental entities between bouts of generating conscious states and behaviors.

positions.statement: Searle's view commits the quantifier-shift fallacy.
positions.verbatim_quote: Searle's view commits the quantifier-shift fallacy.

positions.statement: There are infinitely many sentences one understands and infinitely many derived semantic rules.
positions.verbatim_quote: There are infinitely many sentences one understands and infinitely many derived semantic rules.

positions.statement: The a priori likelihood of two speakers' psychologies being perfectly aligned to their respective physiologies is small.
positions.verbatim_quote: The a priori likelihood of two speakers' psychologies being perfectly aligned to their respective physiologies is small.

positions.statement: Medical science individuates brain-centers on the basis of their presumptive cognitive functions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Medical science individuates brain-centers on the basis of their presumptive cognitive functions.

positions.statement: Brain-physiology is done in light of knowledge of psychophysical concomitances.
positions.verbatim_quote: Brain-physiology is done in light of knowledge of psychophysical concomitances.

positions.statement: Mozart's and Beethoven's musical competencies differ physiologically much more than they do cognitively.
positions.verbatim_quote: Mozart's and Beethoven's musical competencies differ physiologically much more than they do cognitively.

positions.statement: Cognitive processes are realized by physiological processes, but psychological relations between physiological events cannot be understood in physiological terms.
positions.verbatim_quote: Cognitive processes are realized by physiological processes, but psychological relations between physiological events cannot be understood in physiological terms.

positions.statement: Hume grants that causal statements are sometimes true but holds they only describe regularity-instantiation.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume grants that causal statements are sometimes true but holds they only describe regularity-instantiation.

positions.statement: Hume's analysis (HC) doesn't distinguish actual from epiphenomenal causality.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume's analysis (HC) doesn't distinguish actual from epiphenomenal causality.

positions.statement: Day doesn't cause night, even though night regularly follows day.
positions.verbatim_quote: Day doesn't cause night, even though night regularly follows day.

positions.statement: We know intuitively what causes what before looking for regularities.
positions.verbatim_quote: We know intuitively what causes what before looking for regularities.

positions.statement: Constant conjunctions tip us off to continuities, to causal mechanisms.
positions.verbatim_quote: Constant conjunctions tip us off to continuities, to causal mechanisms.

positions.statement: It's the mechanism, the continuity, that is the sine qua non of causality.
positions.verbatim_quote: It's the mechanism, the continuity, that is the sine qua non of causality.

positions.statement: To the extent an investigator's methodology is empiricist, he is blind to the invisible.
positions.verbatim_quote: To the extent an investigator's methodology is empiricist, he is blind to the invisible.

positions.statement: Empiricist philosophers of science deny that anything makes anything happen.
positions.verbatim_quote: Empiricist philosophers of science deny that anything makes anything happen.

positions.statement: Hume's analysis assumes changes consist of events, but they don't.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume's analysis assumes changes consist of events, but they don't.

positions.statement: The spatiotemporal world doesn't consist of discrete events.
positions.verbatim_quote: The spatiotemporal world doesn't consist of discrete events.

positions.statement: The world has an analogue, not a digital structure.
positions.verbatim_quote: The world has an analogue, not a digital structure.

positions.statement: The redistributions of mass-energy that constitute change do not have a digital structure.
positions.verbatim_quote: The redistributions of mass-energy that constitute change do not have a digital structure.

positions.statement: Observation represents change as seamless, not as consisting of discrete parts.
positions.verbatim_quote: Observation represents change as seamless, not as consisting of discrete parts.

positions.statement: One who witnesses continuity knows he is witnessing causation.
positions.verbatim_quote: One who witnesses continuity knows he is witnessing causation.

positions.statement: The world doesn't consist of truths; it consists of facts.
positions.verbatim_quote: The world doesn't consist of truths; it consists of facts.

positions.statement: Truths hold in virtue of facts but aren't identical with facts.
positions.verbatim_quote: Truths hold in virtue of facts but aren't identical with facts.

positions.statement: Events are nominalizations of truths, not constituents of the external world.
positions.verbatim_quote: Events are nominalizations of truths, not constituents of the external world.

positions.statement: Spatiotemporally coincident events with different modal properties would entail some region of space-time isn't self-identical.
positions.verbatim_quote: Spatiotemporally coincident events with different modal properties would entail some region of space-time isn't self-identical.

positions.statement: Hume's analysis of causation involves a failure to distinguish facts from truths.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume's analysis of causation involves a failure to distinguish facts from truths.

positions.statement: There can be no spatiotemporal changes without causal changes because spatiotemporal changes are causal changes.
positions.verbatim_quote: There can be no spatiotemporal changes without causal changes because spatiotemporal changes are causal changes.

positions.statement: Notions such as displacement and occupancy are to be understood in causal terms.
positions.verbatim_quote: Notions such as displacement and occupancy are to be understood in causal terms.

positions.statement: Hume assumes the concepts of precedence in time and adjacency in space can be understood in non-causal terms, but they cannot.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume assumes the concepts of precedence in time and adjacency in space can be understood in non-causal terms, but they cannot.

positions.statement: A "Hume world" without causation is impossible because any instance of persistence or occupancy is an instance of causation.
positions.verbatim_quote: A "Hume world" without causation is impossible because any instance of persistence or occupancy is an instance of causation.

positions.statement: If a ball's state at t isn't responsible for its state at t*, there are no grounds for saying they constitute one ball.
positions.verbatim_quote: If a ball's state at t isn't responsible for its state at t*, there are no grounds for saying they constitute one ball.

positions.statement: There is a transcendental argument for the existence of instances of causation.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is a transcendental argument for the existence of instances of causation.

positions.statement: Genidentical thought-episodes are the relata of bona fide instances of causation.
positions.verbatim_quote: Genidentical thought-episodes are the relata of bona fide instances of causation.

positions.statement: There is no such thing as a conceptually innocent observation-report.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no such thing as a conceptually innocent observation-report.

positions.statement: If purged of theoretical commitments, observation-reports would be stilted and useless.
positions.verbatim_quote: If purged of theoretical commitments, observation-reports would be stilted and useless.

positions.statement: Goodman's puzzle shows that explanation isn't about finding regularities and subsuming events under them.
positions.verbatim_quote: Goodman's puzzle shows that explanation isn't about finding regularities and subsuming events under them.

positions.statement: Certain regularities are broken and explanatorily useless; they are discontinuity-generators.
positions.verbatim_quote: Certain regularities are broken and explanatorily useless; they are discontinuity-generators.

positions.statement: Good regularities destroy more discontinuities than they create.
positions.verbatim_quote: Good regularities destroy more discontinuities than they create.

positions.statement: Hyper-continuities make a regularity good, not vice versa.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hyper-continuities make a regularity good, not vice versa.

positions.statement: We are interested in regularities only insofar as they are hyper-continuity-conducive.
positions.verbatim_quote: We are interested in regularities only insofar as they are hyper-continuity-conducive.

positions.statement: There is change; change in the manner of change; change in the manner of the manner of change; and so on.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is change; change in the manner of change; change in the manner of the manner of change; and so on.

positions.statement: What we typically refer to as changelessness are conditions of high-order changelessness teeming with lower-order changes.
positions.verbatim_quote: What we typically refer to as changelessness are conditions of high-order changelessness teeming with lower-order changes.

positions.statement: Data supports regularity-generating mechanisms; it doesn't directly support regularities.
positions.verbatim_quote: Data supports regularity-generating mechanisms; it doesn't directly support regularities.

positions.statement: Probability is not a statistical but an explanatory notion.
positions.verbatim_quote: Probability is not a statistical but an explanatory notion.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein's argument against other minds assumes probability is statistical, which is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wittgenstein's argument against other minds assumes probability is statistical, which is false.

positions.statement: The "axiom of diversity" is easily explained and shouldn't be an axiom.
positions.verbatim_quote: The "axiom of diversity" is easily explained and shouldn't be an axiom.

positions.statement: Explanatory probability is a causal notion.
positions.verbatim_quote: Explanatory probability is a causal notion.

positions.statement: Empiricists deny anything makes anything happen, so they cannot distinguish statistical from explanatory probability.
positions.verbatim_quote: Empiricists deny anything makes anything happen, so they cannot distinguish statistical from explanatory probability.

positions.statement: The "problem of the priors" cannot be solved on statistical grounds; it has to be solved on grounds of causality and continuity.
positions.verbatim_quote: The "problem of the priors" cannot be solved on statistical grounds; it has to be solved on grounds of causality and continuity.

positions.statement: Selves are not identical with the mental activity they mediate.
positions.verbatim_quote: Selves are not identical with the mental activity they mediate.

positions.statement: It isn't because two segments of a thought process belong to the same mind that they constitute one unbroken thought process; causation creates unity.
positions.verbatim_quote: It isn't because two segments of a thought process belong to the same mind that they constitute one unbroken thought process; causation creates unity.

positions.statement: It is because thought-segments cohere that they belong to some one mind.
positions.verbatim_quote: It is because thought-segments cohere that they belong to some one mind.

positions.statement: The self consists of awareness-mediating enduring structures underlying mental activity.
positions.verbatim_quote: The self consists of awareness-mediating enduring structures underlying mental activity.

positions.statement: What unites a cryogenically frozen brain with its reactivated state is the persistence of a single structure that mediates ideation.
positions.verbatim_quote: What unites a cryogenically frozen brain with its reactivated state is the persistence of a single structure that mediates ideation.

positions.statement: It is possible for all constituents of a given system to fall within its scope.
positions.verbatim_quote: It is possible for all constituents of a given system to fall within its scope.

positions.statement: There are two ways a system can be organized: horizontally and vertically.
positions.verbatim_quote: There are two ways a system can be organized: horizontally and vertically.

positions.statement: Nothing makes anything happen (NC) is Hume's legacy to the philosophy of science, but it is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Nothing makes anything happen (NC) is Hume's legacy to the philosophy of science, but it is false.

positions.statement: The Deductive-Nomological (DN) analysis of explanation follows from the empiricist analysis of causation.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Deductive-Nomological (DN) analysis of explanation follows from the empiricist analysis of causation.

positions.statement: DN fails because there are infinitely many antecedents of any event that instantiate infinitely many universal generalizations.
positions.verbatim_quote: DN fails because there are infinitely many antecedents of any event that instantiate infinitely many universal generalizations.

positions.statement: Natural laws support counterfactuals, but advocates of DN cannot coherently say this.
positions.verbatim_quote: Natural laws support counterfactuals, but advocates of DN cannot coherently say this.

positions.statement: To show that x is an instance of a regularity is to show it is one member of a whole class of events we can't explain.
positions.verbatim_quote: To show that x is an instance of a regularity is to show it is one member of a whole class of events we can't explain.

positions.statement: Regularities are but shadows cast by underlying causal mechanisms.
positions.verbatim_quote: Regularities are but shadows cast by underlying causal mechanisms.

positions.statement: Psychology explains by rationalizing; physicists do not, but both seek causal mechanisms.
positions.verbatim_quote: Psychology explains by rationalizing; physicists do not, but both seek causal mechanisms.

positions.statement: Physical and psychological explanations share the property of seeking causal mechanisms.
positions.verbatim_quote: Physical and psychological explanations share the property of seeking causal mechanisms.

positions.statement: Most psychological "explanations" fail DN's criteria, but this discredits DN, not those explanations.
positions.verbatim_quote: Most psychological "explanations" fail DN's criteria, but this discredits DN, not those explanations.

positions.statement: A given event E₁ can cause E₂ even if, given E₁'s occurrence, there was less than 100% chance of E₂'s occurrence.
positions.verbatim_quote: A given event E₁ can cause E₂ even if, given E₁'s occurrence, there was less than 100% chance of E₂'s occurrence.

positions.statement: Philosophy is the discipline that delineates the structures of the categories in terms of which we think about the world.
positions.verbatim_quote: Philosophy is the discipline that delineates the structures of the categories in terms of which we think about the world.

positions.statement: We understand the world through categories (event, cause, thing, mind, perception, belief, knowledge, language, truth, value-judgment, law, justice, etc.).
positions.verbatim_quote: We understand the world through categories (event, cause, thing, mind, perception, belief, knowledge, language, truth, value-judgment, law, justice, etc.).

positions.statement: These categories are seldom objects of thought, even though we cannot think without them.
positions.verbatim_quote: These categories are seldom objects of thought, even though we cannot think without them.

positions.statement: We are adept at using categories but have difficulty making explicit the conditions that govern them.
positions.verbatim_quote: We are adept at using categories but have difficulty making explicit the conditions that govern them.

positions.statement: Self-understanding is not the mind's primary function.
positions.verbatim_quote: Self-understanding is not the mind's primary function.

positions.statement: The idea of a mind that thinks about nothing other than itself is incoherent.
positions.verbatim_quote: The idea of a mind that thinks about nothing other than itself is incoherent.

positions.statement: Any case of self-awareness is necessarily derivative of, and of lesser quality than, some more fundamental sort of understanding.
positions.verbatim_quote: Any case of self-awareness is necessarily derivative of, and of lesser quality than, some more fundamental sort of understanding.

positions.statement: Philosophy is the analysis of the preconditions of all knowledge—the analysis of analysis, the logic of logic, the science of science.
positions.verbatim_quote: Philosophy is the analysis of the preconditions of all knowledge—the analysis of analysis, the logic of logic, the science of science.

positions.statement: Philosophical knowledge is metaknowledge—knowledge about knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: Philosophical knowledge is metaknowledge—knowledge about knowledge.

positions.statement: The philosopher wants to know the laws governing the laws—what it would even make sense to claim to hold.
positions.verbatim_quote: The philosopher wants to know the laws governing the laws—what it would even make sense to claim to hold.

positions.statement: The philosopher is to the physicist what the physicist is to the engineer.
positions.verbatim_quote: The philosopher is to the physicist what the physicist is to the engineer.

positions.statement: Pre-Fregean philosophers (with some exceptions) mistakenly thought they were studying the most general features of the actual world.
positions.verbatim_quote: Pre-Fregean philosophers (with some exceptions) mistakenly thought they were studying the most general features of the actual world.

positions.statement: Frege showed that philosophers' interest in the actual is subordinate to their interest in the possible.
positions.verbatim_quote: Frege showed that philosophers' interest in the actual is subordinate to their interest in the possible.

positions.statement: Analytic philosophers figure out what there could be by analyzing statements.
positions.verbatim_quote: Analytic philosophers figure out what there could be by analyzing statements.

positions.statement: Statements that make sense describe possible realities; those that don't, don't.
positions.verbatim_quote: Statements that make sense describe possible realities; those that don't, don't.

positions.statement: Frege's key insight: logical form ≠ grammatical form.
positions.verbatim_quote: Frege's key insight: logical form ≠ grammatical form.

positions.statement: When people have an obviously correct belief that seems to have an absurd consequence, they often accept the absurdity and develop ad hoc hypotheses rather than questioning whether the absurdity really follows.
positions.verbatim_quote: When people have an obviously correct belief that seems to have an absurd consequence, they often accept the absurdity and develop ad hoc hypotheses rather than questioning whether the absurdity really follows.

positions.statement: Philosophical insight is acquired not by doing parascience or positing entities, but by analyzing meanings and clarifying statements.
positions.verbatim_quote: Philosophical insight is acquired not by doing parascience or positing entities, but by analyzing meanings and clarifying statements.

positions.statement: "Nothing is a square circle" does not attribute a property to a non-entity; it states that the set of squares doesn't overlap with the set of circles.
positions.verbatim_quote: "Nothing is a square circle" does not attribute a property to a non-entity; it states that the set of squares doesn't overlap with the set of circles.

positions.statement: The concept of "non-entities" or "subsistent entities" (Brentano, Meinong) is absurd—such philosophers were ontologizing when they should have been analyzing.
positions.verbatim_quote: The concept of "non-entities" or "subsistent entities" (Brentano, Meinong) is absurd—such philosophers were ontologizing when they should have been analyzing.

positions.statement: Hallucinations do not require the existence of non-existent objects; they have for their content an existence-claim that nothing satisfies.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hallucinations do not require the existence of non-existent objects; they have for their content an existence-claim that nothing satisfies.

positions.statement: Scientific puzzles involve acquiring new data; philosophical puzzles are purely conceptual and result from confusion, not ignorance.
positions.verbatim_quote: Scientific puzzles involve acquiring new data; philosophical puzzles are purely conceptual and result from confusion, not ignorance.

positions.statement: Scientific breakthroughs have two components: (i) new raw data and (ii) new conceptual modeling of already-known data.
positions.verbatim_quote: Scientific breakthroughs have two components: (i) new raw data and (ii) new conceptual modeling of already-known data.

positions.statement: Philosophical puzzles are not solved by generating new raw data—they result from failure to draw the right inferences.
positions.verbatim_quote: Philosophical puzzles are not solved by generating new raw data—they result from failure to draw the right inferences.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein was wrong to claim that all philosophical puzzles are linguistic in nature.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wittgenstein was wrong to claim that all philosophical puzzles are linguistic in nature.

positions.statement: There are philosophical puzzles that have nothing to do with language.
positions.verbatim_quote: There are philosophical puzzles that have nothing to do with language.

positions.statement: Propositions are not sentences; propositions are the things meant by sentences.
positions.verbatim_quote: Propositions are not sentences; propositions are the things meant by sentences.

positions.statement: Propositions exist independently of human beings; they are not human creations, whereas sentences are.
positions.verbatim_quote: Propositions exist independently of human beings; they are not human creations, whereas sentences are.

positions.statement: Propositions are properties; truth is instantiatedness.
positions.verbatim_quote: Propositions are properties; truth is instantiatedness.

positions.statement: The world was a certain way before we were around, so propositions (as ways the world is) exist independently of our beliefs.
positions.verbatim_quote: The world was a certain way before we were around, so propositions (as ways the world is) exist independently of our beliefs.

positions.statement: Analytic philosophy (broadly construed) is philosophy done in the careful, clear-headed, systematic way that Frege approached problems.
positions.verbatim_quote: Analytic philosophy (broadly construed) is philosophy done in the careful, clear-headed, systematic way that Frege approached problems.

positions.statement: The claim that one can know something only by being causally affected by it (e.g., Fodor's position regarding knowledge of mathematical truths) is absurd in the extreme.
positions.verbatim_quote: The claim that one can know something only by being causally affected by it (e.g., Fodor's position regarding knowledge of mathematical truths) is absurd in the extreme.

positions.statement: The fact that 1+1=2 is non-spatiotemporal; nothing outside space-time can bear causal relations to anything.
positions.verbatim_quote: The fact that 1+1=2 is non-spatiotemporal; nothing outside space-time can bear causal relations to anything.

positions.statement: The dispute over causal theories of knowledge is not linguistic—it concerns whether an agreed-upon meaning is true.
positions.verbatim_quote: The dispute over causal theories of knowledge is not linguistic—it concerns whether an agreed-upon meaning is true.

positions.statement: No philosophical assertions are empirical; observation cannot tell you whether one statement is inconsistent with another.
positions.verbatim_quote: No philosophical assertions are empirical; observation cannot tell you whether one statement is inconsistent with another.

positions.statement: The question of whether law requires morality (legal positivism vs. anti-positivism) is to be resolved through logical, not empirical, analysis.
positions.verbatim_quote: The question of whether law requires morality (legal positivism vs. anti-positivism) is to be resolved through logical, not empirical, analysis.

positions.statement: Logical positivism (LP) holds that meaningful statements are either tautologies or empirical.
positions.verbatim_quote: Logical positivism (LP) holds that meaningful statements are either tautologies or empirical.

positions.statement: LP is self-refuting: it is neither a tautology nor empirically verifiable, so by its own criterion it is meaningless.
positions.verbatim_quote: LP is self-refuting: it is neither a tautology nor empirically verifiable, so by its own criterion it is meaningless.

positions.statement: There are non-empirical truths that have nothing to do with anyone's linguistic practices.
positions.verbatim_quote: There are non-empirical truths that have nothing to do with anyone's linguistic practices.

positions.statement: Strictly observational grounds cannot support theoretical statements like Newton's physics directly—only in conjunction with specific factual claims.
positions.verbatim_quote: Strictly observational grounds cannot support theoretical statements like Newton's physics directly—only in conjunction with specific factual claims.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein's acknowledgment that the Tractatus is meaningless by its own standards is self-contradictory; to understand something is to see its meaning.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wittgenstein's acknowledgment that the Tractatus is meaningless by its own standards is self-contradictory; to understand something is to see its meaning.

positions.statement: Empiricism is self-refuting: if true, there are no grounds for believing it; if there are grounds, it is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Empiricism is self-refuting: if true, there are no grounds for believing it; if there are grounds, it is false.

positions.statement: Russell's argument against naïve realism ("if true, is false; therefore false") rests on spurious reasoning—we do observe external objects, not merely effects upon ourselves.
positions.verbatim_quote: Russell's argument against naïve realism ("if true, is false; therefore false") rests on spurious reasoning—we do observe external objects, not merely effects upon ourselves.

positions.statement: The greenness, hardness, and coldness of physics are identical with those of daily observation; physics tells us what these properties are.
positions.verbatim_quote: The greenness, hardness, and coldness of physics are identical with those of daily observation; physics tells us what these properties are.

positions.statement: The concept of confirmation is incoherent unless non-empirical knowledge is granted (Goodman's grue argument).
positions.verbatim_quote: The concept of confirmation is incoherent unless non-empirical knowledge is granted (Goodman's grue argument).

positions.statement: Induction does not have a strictly observational basis; there must be non-observational grounds for preferring certain properties over others in inductive inference.
positions.verbatim_quote: Induction does not have a strictly observational basis; there must be non-observational grounds for preferring certain properties over others in inductive inference.

positions.statement: It is utterances, not sentences per se, that are tautologies—tautologousness depends on how the auditor learned the meanings of expressions.
positions.verbatim_quote: It is utterances, not sentences per se, that are tautologies—tautologousness depends on how the auditor learned the meanings of expressions.

positions.statement: One knows the meanings of expressions descriptively; two different descriptions can pick out the same thing.
positions.verbatim_quote: One knows the meanings of expressions descriptively; two different descriptions can pick out the same thing.

positions.statement: All entailment is not formal entailment (contra Wittgenstein's Tractatus).
positions.verbatim_quote: All entailment is not formal entailment (contra Wittgenstein's Tractatus).

positions.statement: "Brown is a circle" entails "Brown is a two-dimensional figure," but this is not a formal entailment—it is a non-tautologous, non-empirical truth.
positions.verbatim_quote: "Brown is a circle" entails "Brown is a two-dimensional figure," but this is not a formal entailment—it is a non-tautologous, non-empirical truth.

positions.statement: The concept of a logically perfect language is incoherent.
positions.verbatim_quote: The concept of a logically perfect language is incoherent.

positions.statement: If a logically perfect language existed, it would be expressively inferior to natural languages.
positions.verbatim_quote: If a logically perfect language existed, it would be expressively inferior to natural languages.

positions.statement: For each analytic truth a logically perfect language could express, there would be infinitely many it could not express.
positions.verbatim_quote: For each analytic truth a logically perfect language could express, there would be infinitely many it could not express.

positions.statement: Knowing that a formal entailment is valid requires knowing that some informal entailment is valid; there are infinitely many informally valid inferences for each formally valid one.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowing that a formal entailment is valid requires knowing that some informal entailment is valid; there are infinitely many informally valid inferences for each formally valid one.

positions.statement: There cannot be strictly observation-based knowledge that an object's length is given by an irrational number (Hempel's argument).
positions.verbatim_quote: There cannot be strictly observation-based knowledge that an object's length is given by an irrational number (Hempel's argument).

positions.statement: Modern physics depends on assumptions (that magnitudes can assume irrational values) for which there cannot be strictly observational grounds.
positions.verbatim_quote: Modern physics depends on assumptions (that magnitudes can assume irrational values) for which there cannot be strictly observational grounds.

positions.statement: Strict empiricism is inconsistent with the fact that modern physics is a source of knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: Strict empiricism is inconsistent with the fact that modern physics is a source of knowledge.

positions.statement: Euclid's axioms (1)–(5) are statement-forms, not statements proper, and some interpretations of them are false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Euclid's axioms (1)–(5) are statement-forms, not statements proper, and some interpretations of them are false.

positions.statement: The parallel postulate is not true or false of anything—it is a statement-form.
positions.verbatim_quote: The parallel postulate is not true or false of anything—it is a statement-form.

positions.statement: Arithmetical truth cannot be formalized: any formal characterization of arithmetic is either inconsistent or incomplete.
positions.verbatim_quote: Arithmetical truth cannot be formalized: any formal characterization of arithmetic is either inconsistent or incomplete.

positions.statement: The possible worlds analysis of counterfactuals (Lewis, Kment, Stalnaker) is completely preposterous.
positions.verbatim_quote: The possible worlds analysis of counterfactuals (Lewis, Kment, Stalnaker) is completely preposterous.

positions.statement: We don't know anything about other universes; any knowledge of them would be parasitic on knowledge of counterfactual truths.
positions.verbatim_quote: We don't know anything about other universes; any knowledge of them would be parasitic on knowledge of counterfactual truths.

positions.statement: Counterfactuals are grammatical variants of ordinary causal or logical statements.
positions.verbatim_quote: Counterfactuals are grammatical variants of ordinary causal or logical statements.

positions.statement: "Someone" is not in the same semantic category as "John" or "Ethel"—it does not refer to an individual.
positions.verbatim_quote: "Someone" is not in the same semantic category as "John" or "Ethel"—it does not refer to an individual.

positions.statement: "Someone smokes" does not attribute the property of smoking to a non-specific individual; it states that the property of being a smoker is instantiated.
positions.verbatim_quote: "Someone smokes" does not attribute the property of smoking to a non-specific individual; it states that the property of being a smoker is instantiated.

positions.statement: There is no such thing as an "ambiguous person" or "non-specific entity"—to posit such things is to twist reality to conform to grammatical assumptions.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no such thing as an "ambiguous person" or "non-specific entity"—to posit such things is to twist reality to conform to grammatical assumptions.

positions.statement: The word "someone" is not ambiguous; it has one meaning.
positions.verbatim_quote: The word "someone" is not ambiguous; it has one meaning.

positions.statement: Analytic philosophers solve problems by clarifying statements, not by ontologizing (positing entities not previously believed to exist).
positions.verbatim_quote: Analytic philosophers solve problems by clarifying statements, not by ontologizing (positing entities not previously believed to exist).

positions.statement: When analytic philosophers do ontologize, they posit only abstract, non-spatiotemporal entities—never spatiotemporal denizens like persons or tables.
positions.verbatim_quote: When analytic philosophers do ontologize, they posit only abstract, non-spatiotemporal entities—never spatiotemporal denizens like persons or tables.

positions.statement: Properties exist; their existence is validated by obviously true statements (e.g., "Bob and Sally are both intelligent").
positions.verbatim_quote: Properties exist; their existence is validated by obviously true statements (e.g., "Bob and Sally are both intelligent").

positions.statement: Properties are not identical with spatiotemporal entities; you will never encounter intelligence per se in space-time.
positions.verbatim_quote: Properties are not identical with spatiotemporal entities; you will never encounter intelligence per se in space-time.

positions.statement: The essence of the mental is intentionality (non-derivative representationality), as Brentano held.
positions.verbatim_quote: The essence of the mental is intentionality (non-derivative representationality), as Brentano held.

positions.statement: Perception is description—seeing Larry involves seeing that various properties are instantiated.
positions.verbatim_quote: Perception is description—seeing Larry involves seeing that various properties are instantiated.

positions.statement: Perceptions represent objects by encoding existence-claims that those objects satisfy.
positions.verbatim_quote: Perceptions represent objects by encoding existence-claims that those objects satisfy.

positions.statement: The content of a perception is given by an existence-claim, not by a semantically simple symbol.
positions.verbatim_quote: The content of a perception is given by an existence-claim, not by a semantically simple symbol.

positions.statement: Hallucinations are representational not because they pick out non-existent objects, but because they encode false existence-claims.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hallucinations are representational not because they pick out non-existent objects, but because they encode false existence-claims.

positions.statement: Thoughts about non-existent things (e.g., an even prime greater than two) involve thinking false existence-claims.
positions.verbatim_quote: Thoughts about non-existent things (e.g., an even prime greater than two) involve thinking false existence-claims.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein's view that philosophical problems arise only when sentences are misused is incorrect.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wittgenstein's view that philosophical problems arise only when sentences are misused is incorrect.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein's Tractatus holds that philosophical statements violate hidden syntactic rules; the Investigations holds they result from using words in non-standard ways—both positions are wrong.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wittgenstein's Tractatus holds that philosophical statements violate hidden syntactic rules; the Investigations holds they result from using words in non-standard ways—both positions are wrong.

positions.statement: One cannot learn about concepts by studying word usage unless one can already grasp the concept independently of the word.
positions.verbatim_quote: One cannot learn about concepts by studying word usage unless one can already grasp the concept independently of the word.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein's thesis that "meaning is use" is incoherent.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wittgenstein's thesis that "meaning is use" is incoherent.

positions.statement: If two expressions could only differ in meaning by being used differently, then any two sentences that have never been used would have the same meaning—which is absurd.
positions.verbatim_quote: If two expressions could only differ in meaning by being used differently, then any two sentences that have never been used would have the same meaning—which is absurd.

positions.statement: Conceptual role semantics (CRS)—the thesis that two sentences have the same meaning iff used the same way—is indefensible.
positions.verbatim_quote: Conceptual role semantics (CRS)—the thesis that two sentences have the same meaning iff used the same way—is indefensible.

positions.statement: Someone who utters a sentence does so because she knows semantic rules assign a certain proposition to those words and she wishes to express that proposition.
positions.verbatim_quote: Someone who utters a sentence does so because she knows semantic rules assign a certain proposition to those words and she wishes to express that proposition.

positions.statement: Carnap's view that for a lecture to concern triangles is for the word "triangle" to occur in the lecture is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Carnap's view that for a lecture to concern triangles is for the word "triangle" to occur in the lecture is false.

positions.statement: The very essence of logical positivism is the denial of meaning (propositions).
positions.verbatim_quote: The very essence of logical positivism is the denial of meaning (propositions).

positions.statement: It is not up to us whether meanings (propositions) are correct, even though it is up to us what our symbols mean.
positions.verbatim_quote: It is not up to us whether meanings (propositions) are correct, even though it is up to us what our symbols mean.

positions.statement: Logical truths are never sentences; they are always propositions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Logical truths are never sentences; they are always propositions.

positions.statement: Propositions are never conventionally true; linguistic conventions are known empirically, but what those conventions express is not itself empirical.
positions.verbatim_quote: Propositions are never conventionally true; linguistic conventions are known empirically, but what those conventions express is not itself empirical.

positions.statement: Logical positivists were unanimous in denying the existence of propositions and meanings generally.
positions.verbatim_quote: Logical positivists were unanimous in denying the existence of propositions and meanings generally.

positions.statement: Sentences like "the universe is a perfect unity" are not meaningless because they are non-empirical; they are meaningless because key terms are undefined—they are statement-forms, not statements.
positions.verbatim_quote: Sentences like "the universe is a perfect unity" are not meaningless because they are non-empirical; they are meaningless because key terms are undefined—they are statement-forms, not statements.

positions.statement: Once undefined terms are defined, previously "meaningless" sentences become meaningful and true or false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Once undefined terms are defined, previously "meaningless" sentences become meaningful and true or false.

positions.statement: A sentence is meaningful if it attributes some property to some object; it is meaningless if it does not attribute any property to anything.
positions.verbatim_quote: A sentence is meaningful if it attributes some property to some object; it is meaningless if it does not attribute any property to anything.

positions.statement: Any non-compound sentence either says of some individual that it has some property or says that two or more individuals are interrelated in a certain way.
positions.verbatim_quote: Any non-compound sentence either says of some individual that it has some property or says that two or more individuals are interrelated in a certain way.

positions.statement: All sentences (relational, compound, negative, quantified) can be reduced to the form ‹x has phi›.
positions.verbatim_quote: All sentences (relational, compound, negative, quantified) can be reduced to the form ‹x has phi›.

positions.statement: The picture theory of meaning—that sentences are "pictures" of the facts they describe—is either trivially true or incoherent.
positions.verbatim_quote: The picture theory of meaning—that sentences are "pictures" of the facts they describe—is either trivially true or incoherent.

positions.statement: If the picture theory means that sentences share structural features with the facts they describe, it is dubiously coherent.
positions.verbatim_quote: If the picture theory means that sentences share structural features with the facts they describe, it is dubiously coherent.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein's claim that "what can be shown, cannot be said" is obviously false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wittgenstein's claim that "what can be shown, cannot be said" is obviously false.

positions.statement: Contrary to Wittgenstein, we can identify the logical forms of our own utterances; we do it whenever we put the meanings of words into words.
positions.verbatim_quote: Contrary to Wittgenstein, we can identify the logical forms of our own utterances; we do it whenever we put the meanings of words into words.

positions.statement: No language can state all of its own semantic rules—there is a proof of this.
positions.verbatim_quote: No language can state all of its own semantic rules—there is a proof of this.

positions.statement: The claim that truth is indefinable is false if it means we cannot say what it is for a proposition to be true; it is true if it means no language can state all of its own semantic rules.
positions.verbatim_quote: The claim that truth is indefinable is false if it means we cannot say what it is for a proposition to be true; it is true if it means no language can state all of its own semantic rules.

positions.statement: The sub-disciplines of philosophy (mind, language, epistemology, logic, metaphysics, science, ethics, political philosophy, religion, formal logic) overlap considerably.
positions.verbatim_quote: The sub-disciplines of philosophy (mind, language, epistemology, logic, metaphysics, science, ethics, political philosophy, religion, formal logic) overlap considerably.

positions.statement: The question "do we think in words?" belongs to both the philosophy of mind and the philosophy of language.
positions.verbatim_quote: The question "do we think in words?" belongs to both the philosophy of mind and the philosophy of language.

positions.statement: Philosophical logic studies bearing-relations among sentences and propositions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Philosophical logic studies bearing-relations among sentences and propositions.

positions.statement: Metaphysics studies the nature of possibility, necessity, causal relations, identity, and the conditions something must meet to exist.
positions.verbatim_quote: Metaphysics studies the nature of possibility, necessity, causal relations, identity, and the conditions something must meet to exist.

positions.statement: The philosophy of science studies the logical structure of scientific endeavor and its results.
positions.verbatim_quote: The philosophy of science studies the logical structure of scientific endeavor and its results.

positions.statement: There may be a fundamental difference between explanations in the physical sciences and explanations in the psychological sciences.
positions.verbatim_quote: There may be a fundamental difference between explanations in the physical sciences and explanations in the psychological sciences.

positions.statement: Whether a system is deterministic or not may depend on how it is described—determinism may be a logical property of statements, not of events (Nagel's view).
positions.verbatim_quote: Whether a system is deterministic or not may depend on how it is described—determinism may be a logical property of statements, not of events (Nagel's view).

positions.statement: Formal logic studies formal truth and attempts to formalize informal analytic truth insofar as possible.
positions.verbatim_quote: Formal logic studies formal truth and attempts to formalize informal analytic truth insofar as possible.

positions.statement: A sentence is formally true if every sentence of the same form is true.
positions.verbatim_quote: A sentence is formally true if every sentence of the same form is true.

positions.statement: Open-sentences (statement-forms) are neither true nor false; only their instances (when variables are replaced with constants) are true or false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Open-sentences (statement-forms) are neither true nor false; only their instances (when variables are replaced with constants) are true or false.

positions.statement: Mathematical logicians try to identify open-sentences that are true under all their interpretations, thereby formalizing analytic truth.
positions.verbatim_quote: Mathematical logicians try to identify open-sentences that are true under all their interpretations, thereby formalizing analytic truth.

positions.statement: Some classes of true statements (e.g., arithmetical statements) that one would expect to be formalizable turn out not to be—arithmetical truth cannot be formalized.KUCZNSKI KANT ANALOG DIGITAL POSITION STATEMENT
positions.verbatim_quote: Some classes of true statements (e.g., arithmetical statements) that one would expect to be formalizable turn out not to be—arithmetical truth cannot be formalized.KUCZNSKI KANT ANALOG DIGITAL POSITION STATEMENT

positions.statement: Kant’s arguments about causation and induction are spurious.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant’s arguments about causation and induction are spurious.

positions.statement: Hume’s analyses of causation and induction are fallacious.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume’s analyses of causation and induction are fallacious.

positions.statement: Kant erroneously assumes all non-empirical truths are trivial.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant erroneously assumes all non-empirical truths are trivial.

positions.statement: Kant’s reasoning can be turned into cogent arguments with terminological changes.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant’s reasoning can be turned into cogent arguments with terminological changes.

positions.statement: Kant’s premises entail that there are virtually no a priori truths.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant’s premises entail that there are virtually no a priori truths.

positions.statement: Kant confuses the psychological and logical meanings of “concept.”
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant confuses the psychological and logical meanings of “concept.”

positions.statement: Mental imagery can serve as a vehicle for conceptual analysis.
positions.verbatim_quote: Mental imagery can serve as a vehicle for conceptual analysis.

positions.statement: Mental imagery can also be an object of empirical study.
positions.verbatim_quote: Mental imagery can also be an object of empirical study.

positions.statement: Kant’s views on synthetic a priori truths reflect his conflation of psychology with logic.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant’s views on synthetic a priori truths reflect his conflation of psychology with logic.

positions.statement: Kant’s claims about causality, personal identity, and rationality are fundamentally correct.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant’s claims about causality, personal identity, and rationality are fundamentally correct.

positions.statement: Kant’s reasoning must be “de-psychologized” to be valid.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant’s reasoning must be “de-psychologized” to be valid.

positions.statement: A proposition is a non-linguistic entity expressed by a sentence.
positions.verbatim_quote: A proposition is a non-linguistic entity expressed by a sentence.

positions.statement: Kant’s definitions of “analytic” and “a priori” are flawed.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant’s definitions of “analytic” and “a priori” are flawed.

positions.statement: Analyticity should be understood as conceptual necessity.
positions.verbatim_quote: Analyticity should be understood as conceptual necessity.

positions.statement: Kant’s use of “containment” in defining analyticity is metaphorical and inadequate.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant’s use of “containment” in defining analyticity is metaphorical and inadequate.

positions.statement: Kant’s definition of analyticity fails for non-subject-predicate statements.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant’s definition of analyticity fails for non-subject-predicate statements.

positions.statement: For Kant, analytic = conceptually true.
positions.verbatim_quote: For Kant, analytic = conceptually true.

positions.statement: Synthetic a priori truths, for Kant, are known a priori but not grounded in concepts alone.
positions.verbatim_quote: Synthetic a priori truths, for Kant, are known a priori but not grounded in concepts alone.

positions.statement: 7+5=12 is analytic, not synthetic.
positions.verbatim_quote: 7+5=12 is analytic, not synthetic.

positions.statement: A straight line is the shortest distance between two points is analytic.
positions.verbatim_quote: A straight line is the shortest distance between two points is analytic.

positions.statement: Arthur Pap’s argument shows Kant is inconsistent in regarding 7+5=12 as synthetic.
positions.verbatim_quote: Arthur Pap’s argument shows Kant is inconsistent in regarding 7+5=12 as synthetic.

positions.statement: Kant’s argument that 7+5=12 is synthetic confuses psychological grasp with conceptual content.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant’s argument that 7+5=12 is synthetic confuses psychological grasp with conceptual content.

positions.statement: Kant presupposes anti-realism or psychologism about concepts.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant presupposes anti-realism or psychologism about concepts.

positions.statement: Intuition for Kant is a para-perceptual act of imaging.
positions.verbatim_quote: Intuition for Kant is a para-perceptual act of imaging.

positions.statement: Intuition reveals representational necessity, not empirical or conceptual truth.
positions.verbatim_quote: Intuition reveals representational necessity, not empirical or conceptual truth.

positions.statement: Intuition does not give knowledge of the external world.
positions.verbatim_quote: Intuition does not give knowledge of the external world.

positions.statement: Intuition gives at most a posteriori knowledge of how we must perceive.
positions.verbatim_quote: Intuition gives at most a posteriori knowledge of how we must perceive.

positions.statement: On Kant’s view, mathematical truths become empirical if followed to their conclusion.
positions.verbatim_quote: On Kant’s view, mathematical truths become empirical if followed to their conclusion.

positions.statement: Kant’s system implies we cannot know noumenal truths.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant’s system implies we cannot know noumenal truths.

positions.statement: Learning geometry through imagery is still conceptual analysis.

positions.statement: Kant fails to distinguish imagery as vehicle for analysis vs. imagery as empirical object.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant fails to distinguish imagery as vehicle for analysis vs. imagery as empirical object.

positions.statement: Leibniz correctly noted that diagrams are aids to reasoning, not sources of geometric truth.
positions.verbatim_quote: Leibniz correctly noted that diagrams are aids to reasoning, not sources of geometric truth.

positions.statement: Peacocke’s distinction between access to proof and justification applies to imagery.
positions.verbatim_quote: Peacocke’s distinction between access to proof and justification applies to imagery.

positions.statement: Transcendental necessity reduces to psychological or conceptual necessity.
positions.verbatim_quote: Transcendental necessity reduces to psychological or conceptual necessity.

positions.statement: Representational limits must be grounded in conceptual impossibilities.
positions.verbatim_quote: Representational limits must be grounded in conceptual impossibilities.

positions.statement: Kant’s position is incoherent: mathematical propositions must describe and not describe the world simultaneously.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant’s position is incoherent: mathematical propositions must describe and not describe the world simultaneously.

positions.statement: Necessary truths do not describe the empirical world.
positions.verbatim_quote: Necessary truths do not describe the empirical world.

positions.statement: Kant’s mistake is an overly narrow conception of analyticity.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant’s mistake is an overly narrow conception of analyticity.

positions.statement: Some analytic truths are “hard analytic” (non-obvious conceptual truths).

positions.statement: Transcendental arguments are cogent if rephrased in terms of hard analyticity.
positions.verbatim_quote: Transcendental arguments are cogent if rephrased in terms of hard analyticity.

positions.verbatim_quote: There is an analytic connection between rational thought and causal order.

positions.statement: Causation is necessary for coherent thought.

positions.statement: Persistence is a causal notion.

positions.statement: Kant-style arguments can settle questions about scientific explanation.

positions.statement: Kant’s solutions falsely presuppose the world is a mental creation.

positions.statement: Hume’s argument about induction presupposes a digital view of events.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume’s argument about induction presupposes a digital view of events.

positions.statement: All spatiotemporal descriptions are causal.

positions.statement: Talk of points and instants is elliptical for talk of arbitrarily small events.
positions.verbatim_quote: Talk of points and instants is elliptical for talk of arbitrarily small events.

positions.statement: There is no possible causal connection without actual causal processes.

positions.statement: Hume’s belief in ex nihilo events is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume’s belief in ex nihilo events is false.

positions.statement: Continuity is a causal phenomenon.

positions.statement: Our grounds for induction are perceptual, not propositional.

positions.statement: Sensory data is analogue; propositions are digital models of it.

positions.statement: Propositions are poor models of perceptual data.

positions.statement: Induction is justified by analogue logic, not propositional logic.

positions.statement: Logical relations also hold among non-digital (analogue) data.

positions.statement: The identification of logic with sentence logic is false.

positions.statement: W either has no effect or a slight negative effect on the trajectory of the RP slope.

positions.statement: If W were the operative decision, the graph would inflect upward after W.

positions.statement: W's role, judging by the data, is to curb the causally effective process rather than initiate it.

positions.statement: Compatibilism holds that freedom is compatible with determinism and may even require it.

positions.statement: Indeterminism threatens freedom; determinism seems to be a prerequisite for freedom.

positions.statement: Thoughts that lack causal basis in pre-existing psychological structures would be mere intrusions, not exercises of agency.

positions.statement: The experiment was designed to maximize the role of consciousness in the relevant action.

positions.statement: The claim that Libet confuses correlation with causation is unsupported by evidence.

positions.statement: Distal intentions are extremely unlikely to be more consciousness-based than proximal intentions.

positions.verbatim_quote: Sellars destroyed the "myth of the given" and began a revolution in epistemology.

positions.statement: Foundationalism used to be the orthodoxy; anti-foundationalism is now the orthodoxy because of Sellars.

positions.verbatim_quote: Sellars is not denying that external realities are given to us through sense-perceptions.

positions.verbatim_quote: Sellars attacks the idea that perception makes us aware of external states without cooperation of preexisting empirical knowledge.

positions.statement: The given—sensory experience considered apart from background knowledge—is not epistemic.
positions.verbatim_quote: The given—sensory experience considered apart from background knowledge—is not epistemic.

positions.verbatim_quote: The epistemic significance of a quale is not fixed; it is a variable function of background empirical knowledge.

positions.statement: Raw sensations by themselves do not have a fixed message about the outside world.
positions.verbatim_quote: Raw sensations by themselves do not have a fixed message about the outside world.

positions.verbatim_quote: There are two myths of the given: (i) what is given is epistemic; (ii) what is given is representational.

positions.statement: What is false is not the belief that there is a given, but that the given is epistemic or representational.
positions.verbatim_quote: What is false is not the belief that there is a given, but that the given is epistemic or representational.

positions.verbatim_quote: Sellars leaves implicit the needed generalizations of his argument.

positions.verbatim_quote: Background knowledge is operative even when we are not consciously aware of its role.

positions.statement: The view that self-deception is conceptually incoherent is demonstrably false.
positions.verbatim_quote: The view that self-deception is conceptually incoherent is demonstrably false.

positions.statement: There are two distinct kinds of repression (repression₁ and repression₂).
positions.verbatim_quote: There are two distinct kinds of repression (repression₁ and repression₂).

positions.statement: There are correspondingly two kinds of self-deception, as a corollary of there being two kinds of repression.
positions.verbatim_quote: There are correspondingly two kinds of self-deception, as a corollary of there being two kinds of repression.

positions.statement: Repression₁ involves inaction—a deliberate, conscious intention not to follow up on suggestive leads.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repression₁ involves inaction—a deliberate, conscious intention not to follow up on suggestive leads.

positions.statement: Repression₁ involves suspecting but not knowing, and wanting to keep it that way.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repression₁ involves suspecting but not knowing, and wanting to keep it that way.

positions.statement: Repression₁ involves not exercising due diligence in interpreting existing evidence or generating new evidence.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repression₁ involves not exercising due diligence in interpreting existing evidence or generating new evidence.

positions.statement: Repression₁ does not involve driving an already-formed belief into the unconscious.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repression₁ does not involve driving an already-formed belief into the unconscious.

positions.statement: Repression₁ involves abstaining from doing things that would generate evidence making acceptance of a belief de rigueur.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repression₁ involves abstaining from doing things that would generate evidence making acceptance of a belief de rigueur.

positions.statement: The customary conception of repression (CCR) is erroneous.
positions.verbatim_quote: The customary conception of repression (CCR) is erroneous.

positions.statement: Suspicion is not knowledge, and there is nothing paradoxical about not wanting to pursue suspicions one suspects would lead to unwanted knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: Suspicion is not knowledge, and there is nothing paradoxical about not wanting to pursue suspicions one suspects would lead to unwanted knowledge.

positions.statement: One can know what sort of thing something is without knowing which particular thing it is.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can know what sort of thing something is without knowing which particular thing it is.

positions.statement: Repression₂ involves already-formed beliefs.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repression₂ involves already-formed beliefs.

positions.statement: The essence of repression₂ is dissociation.
positions.verbatim_quote: The essence of repression₂ is dissociation.

positions.statement: To repress₂ an idea is to take away its "vote" in decision-making—to give it no weight.
positions.verbatim_quote: To repress₂ an idea is to take away its "vote" in decision-making—to give it no weight.

positions.statement: Repression₂ involves blinding oneself to an existing belief one has already formed.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repression₂ involves blinding oneself to an existing belief one has already formed.

positions.statement: The possibility of self-deception is a consequence of three facts about the mind.
positions.verbatim_quote: The possibility of self-deception is a consequence of three facts about the mind.

positions.statement: The mind is not a perfectly unified entity; it consists of parts that communicate imperfectly.
positions.verbatim_quote: The mind is not a perfectly unified entity; it consists of parts that communicate imperfectly.

positions.statement: There are two very different ways of being aware of something: knowledge by acquaintance and knowledge by description.
positions.verbatim_quote: There are two very different ways of being aware of something: knowledge by acquaintance and knowledge by description.

positions.statement: There are two very different senses in which mental content can be "conscious": as a constituent of consciousness, or as something one is conscious of.

positions.statement: All mental entities that aren't constituents of consciousness are, in one sense, unconscious.
positions.verbatim_quote: All mental entities that aren't constituents of consciousness are, in one sense, unconscious.

positions.statement: Beliefs exist and are operative even when one is not conscious of them.
positions.verbatim_quote: Beliefs exist and are operative even when one is not conscious of them.

positions.statement: A belief can be psychologically active as a belief even when not the object of consciousness.
positions.verbatim_quote: A belief can be psychologically active as a belief even when not the object of consciousness.

positions.statement: One can, without knowing it, have two distinct concepts of one of one's own propositional attitudes.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can, without knowing it, have two distinct concepts of one of one's own propositional attitudes.

positions.statement: Emotions are distinct from their manifestations in consciousness.
positions.verbatim_quote: Emotions are distinct from their manifestations in consciousness.

positions.statement: Emotions are enduring psychological structures, not ephemeral events.
positions.verbatim_quote: Emotions are enduring psychological structures, not ephemeral events.

positions.verbatim_quote: Beliefs, like emotions, are enduring structures distinguishable from the constituents of consciousness they may cause.

positions.verbatim_quote: All propositional attitudes are enduring structures distinguishable from any constituents of consciousness for whose existence they're responsible.

positions.statement: Given two qualitatively distinct conscious events both expressing one propositional attitude, there isn't necessarily reason to recognize the attitude in both.
positions.verbatim_quote: Given two qualitatively distinct conscious events both expressing one propositional attitude, there isn't necessarily reason to recognize the attitude in both.

positions.statement: One can have very different attitudes towards a given one of one's own propositional attitudes without knowing it.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can have very different attitudes towards a given one of one's own propositional attitudes without knowing it.

positions.statement: Having a propositional attitude is distinct from knowing that one has it.
positions.verbatim_quote: Having a propositional attitude is distinct from knowing that one has it.

positions.statement: Knowing one feels a certain way involves making a judgment about one's mental state.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowing one feels a certain way involves making a judgment about one's mental state.

positions.verbatim_quote: One must "synthesize" indications of one's attitudes; one must make a judgment that they express an enduring attitude.

positions.statement: These synthesis-judgments are often quite wrong.
positions.verbatim_quote: These synthesis-judgments are often quite wrong.

positions.statement: We sometimes like those toward whom we have constant surges of rage; we sometimes dislike those who make us feel good.
positions.verbatim_quote: We sometimes like those toward whom we have constant surges of rage; we sometimes dislike those who make us feel good.

positions.statement: One's agency only goes so far; much within one's mind falls outside its scope.
positions.verbatim_quote: One's agency only goes so far; much within one's mind falls outside its scope.

positions.statement: Judgment-producing processes lie beyond the reach of what one can choose to occur.
positions.verbatim_quote: Judgment-producing processes lie beyond the reach of what one can choose to occur.

positions.statement: It is not within one's power to completely suspend judgment-producing processes.
positions.verbatim_quote: It is not within one's power to completely suspend judgment-producing processes.
