positions.statement: The anxiety felt when repression₁ breaks down isn't from unconscious knowledge entering consciousness.
positions.verbatim_quote: The anxiety felt when repression₁ breaks down isn't from unconscious knowledge entering consciousness.

positions.statement: It results from one's thought-processes following up on clues despite attempts to stymie them.
positions.verbatim_quote: It results from one's thought-processes following up on clues despite attempts to stymie them.

positions.statement: Every case of repression₁ involves intrapsychic conflict, but not between unconscious knowledge and conscious ignorance.
positions.verbatim_quote: Every case of repression₁ involves intrapsychic conflict, but not between unconscious knowledge and conscious ignorance.

positions.statement: The conflict in repression₁ is between a wish to know the truth and a wish not to know it.
positions.verbatim_quote: The conflict in repression₁ is between a wish to know the truth and a wish not to know it.

positions.statement: For a propositional attitude to be a candidate for repression₂, it must be a source of conflict within one's psyche.
positions.verbatim_quote: For a propositional attitude to be a candidate for repression₂, it must be a source of conflict within one's psyche.

positions.statement: It isn't enough for something to be painful for it to be repressed₂.
positions.verbatim_quote: It isn't enough for something to be painful for it to be repressed₂.

positions.statement: People typically choose to suppress painful memories, but suppression isn't repression₂.
positions.verbatim_quote: People typically choose to suppress painful memories, but suppression isn't repression₂.

positions.statement: One represses₂ knowledge that would severely disrupt one's life-structure if consciously admitted.
positions.verbatim_quote: One represses₂ knowledge that would severely disrupt one's life-structure if consciously admitted.

positions.statement: Repression₂ isn't always bad; in many contexts, it's optimal.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repression₂ isn't always bad; in many contexts, it's optimal.

positions.statement: A person who never repressed₂ anything would quickly go mad.
positions.verbatim_quote: A person who never repressed₂ anything would quickly go mad.

positions.statement: Repressions₂ are necessary.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repressions₂ are necessary.

positions.statement: Repressions₂ outlive their usefulness—circumstances change but the repression persists.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repressions₂ outlive their usefulness—circumstances change but the repression persists.

positions.statement: Repression₂ isn't a one-off affair; it is an ongoing process.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repression₂ isn't a one-off affair; it is an ongoing process.

positions.statement: Each instance of repression₂ creates holes in one's knowledge that must be explained away.
positions.verbatim_quote: Each instance of repression₂ creates holes in one's knowledge that must be explained away.

positions.statement: These explanations cannot be genuine and each incentivizes more bogus, anomaly-creating explanations.
positions.verbatim_quote: These explanations cannot be genuine and each incentivizes more bogus, anomaly-creating explanations.

positions.statement: The need to plug these holes disposes one to devalue truth and hyper-value illegitimate reasoning methods.
positions.verbatim_quote: The need to plug these holes disposes one to devalue truth and hyper-value illegitimate reasoning methods.

positions.statement: The result of sustained repression₂ is loss of both ratiocinative and ethical integrity.
positions.verbatim_quote: The result of sustained repression₂ is loss of both ratiocinative and ethical integrity.

positions.statement: One can know something without that thing being obvious to one.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can know something without that thing being obvious to one.

positions.statement: It's harder to repress₂ knowledge of the obvious than of the non-obvious.
positions.verbatim_quote: It's harder to repress₂ knowledge of the obvious than of the non-obvious.

positions.statement: Inference-based knowledge is easier to repress₂ than sense-based knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: Inference-based knowledge is easier to repress₂ than sense-based knowledge.

positions.statement: People can repress₂ knowledge of totally obvious truths, but this requires telling oneself one isn't capable of knowing truth.
positions.verbatim_quote: People can repress₂ knowledge of totally obvious truths, but this requires telling oneself one isn't capable of knowing truth.

positions.statement: Complete loss of faith in one's ratiocinative ability usually creates more conflict than it eliminates.
positions.verbatim_quote: Complete loss of faith in one's ratiocinative ability usually creates more conflict than it eliminates.

positions.statement: In most cases of repression₂, there must be "plausible deniability."
positions.verbatim_quote: In most cases of repression₂, there must be "plausible deniability."

positions.statement: The things one represses₂ tend to involve judgment-calls rather than pure sense-perception.
positions.verbatim_quote: The things one represses₂ tend to involve judgment-calls rather than pure sense-perception.

positions.statement: If a belief concerns something personal, one's standard of proof tends to be ridiculously high.
positions.verbatim_quote: If a belief concerns something personal, one's standard of proof tends to be ridiculously high.

positions.statement: Repressed entities weren't destroyed; the subject merely blinded himself to them.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repressed entities weren't destroyed; the subject merely blinded himself to them.

positions.statement: One can choose courses of action that redirect the judgment-making faculty or deplete its energy.

positions.statement: Unless one damages one's brain, the stream of mental activity will eventually yield the very judgments one doesn't want.
positions.verbatim_quote: Unless one damages one's brain, the stream of mental activity will eventually yield the very judgments one doesn't want.

positions.statement: The anxiety felt when forces of repression₁ break down isn't the result of unconscious knowledge entering consciousness.
positions.verbatim_quote: The anxiety felt when forces of repression₁ break down isn't the result of unconscious knowledge entering consciousness.

positions.statement: Such anxiety results from one's thought-processes, despite attempts to stymie them, following up on clues one believed would lead to unwanted beliefs.
positions.verbatim_quote: Such anxiety results from one's thought-processes, despite attempts to stymie them, following up on clues one believed would lead to unwanted beliefs.

positions.statement: For a propositional attitude to be a candidate for repression₂, it must be a source of conflict within one's own psyche, not merely a source of pain.
positions.verbatim_quote: For a propositional attitude to be a candidate for repression₂, it must be a source of conflict within one's own psyche, not merely a source of pain.

positions.statement: One often fails to repress₂ one's most painful memories; Holocaust survivors remember what they've been through.
positions.verbatim_quote: One often fails to repress₂ one's most painful memories; Holocaust survivors remember what they've been through.

positions.statement: Suppression (choosing not to think about something) isn't repression₂.
positions.verbatim_quote: Suppression (choosing not to think about something) isn't repression₂.

positions.statement: One represses₂ knowledge that cannot be reconciled with one's life as currently structured.
positions.verbatim_quote: One represses₂ knowledge that cannot be reconciled with one's life as currently structured.

positions.statement: Repressions₂ tend to outlive their usefulness.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repressions₂ tend to outlive their usefulness.

positions.statement: Whenever one encounters information confirming a repressed₂ belief, one must either repress₂ that knowledge or convince oneself of some spurious interpretation.
positions.verbatim_quote: Whenever one encounters information confirming a repressed₂ belief, one must either repress₂ that knowledge or convince oneself of some spurious interpretation.

positions.statement: Each instance of repression₂ creates a hole in one's body of knowledge that must be explained away.
positions.verbatim_quote: Each instance of repression₂ creates a hole in one's body of knowledge that must be explained away.

positions.statement: The need to plug explanatory holes disposes one to devalue truth and hyper-value reasoning methods whose legitimacy spurious explanations falsely assume.
positions.verbatim_quote: The need to plug explanatory holes disposes one to devalue truth and hyper-value reasoning methods whose legitimacy spurious explanations falsely assume.

positions.statement: The result of ongoing repression₂ is loss of both ratiocinative and ethical integrity.
positions.verbatim_quote: The result of ongoing repression₂ is loss of both ratiocinative and ethical integrity.

positions.statement: One cannot repress₂ knowledge of totally obvious truths without telling oneself one isn't capable of knowing truth.
positions.verbatim_quote: One cannot repress₂ knowledge of totally obvious truths without telling oneself one isn't capable of knowing truth.

positions.statement: Since complete loss of faith in one's ratiocinative ability usually creates more conflict than it eliminates, repression₂ tends to target knowledge of what is not totally obvious.
positions.verbatim_quote: Since complete loss of faith in one's ratiocinative ability usually creates more conflict than it eliminates, repression₂ tends to target knowledge of what is not totally obvious.

positions.statement: Things one represses₂ tend to involve judgment-calls rather than strict sense-based knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: Things one represses₂ tend to involve judgment-calls rather than strict sense-based knowledge.

positions.statement: People have always known that we evolved from other life forms, given the anatomical, behavioral, and psychological similarities between humans and other mammals.
positions.verbatim_quote: People have always known that we evolved from other life forms, given the anatomical, behavioral, and psychological similarities between humans and other mammals.

positions.statement: The theory of evolution is resisted because it implies we're orangutans whose lives have no meaning.
positions.verbatim_quote: The theory of evolution is resisted because it implies we're orangutans whose lives have no meaning.

positions.statement: Religious claims about divine creation don't explain why God made us look so much like apes or stocked our minds with ignominious urges.
positions.verbatim_quote: Religious claims about divine creation don't explain why God made us look so much like apes or stocked our minds with ignominious urges.

positions.statement: Freud's theories are theoretically extraordinarily conservative.
positions.verbatim_quote: Freud's theories are theoretically extraordinarily conservative.

positions.statement: Freud was simply making explicit the principles we ordinarily use when making intuitive judgments about other people.
positions.verbatim_quote: Freud was simply making explicit the principles we ordinarily use when making intuitive judgments about other people.

positions.statement: People dismiss Freud's theories, despite their staggering explanatory power, because they don't want to be told they lie to themselves.
positions.verbatim_quote: People dismiss Freud's theories, despite their staggering explanatory power, because they don't want to be told they lie to themselves.

positions.statement: One can readily become conscious of some previously unconscious mental constituents without resistance; these are "preconscious."
positions.verbatim_quote: One can readily become conscious of some previously unconscious mental constituents without resistance; these are "preconscious."

positions.statement: When one represses an entity, one doesn't destroy it; one merely blinds oneself to it.
positions.verbatim_quote: When one represses an entity, one doesn't destroy it; one merely blinds oneself to it.

positions.statement: A repressed desire cannot be discharged unless it employs a subterfuge.
positions.verbatim_quote: A repressed desire cannot be discharged unless it employs a subterfuge.

positions.statement: Repressed desires can disguise themselves as desires the subject consciously wishes to act on.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repressed desires can disguise themselves as desires the subject consciously wishes to act on.

positions.statement: Repressed desires can be expressed as symptoms.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repressed desires can be expressed as symptoms.

positions.statement: Arguments against Freudian psychology are pitifully weak and involve regressions to crude, demonstrably false positions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Arguments against Freudian psychology are pitifully weak and involve regressions to crude, demonstrably false positions.

positions.statement: The views that "we're computers," "there is no consciousness," "there are no minds," and "the mind is completely transparent to itself" are willful denials of the obvious.
positions.verbatim_quote: The views that "we're computers," "there is no consciousness," "there are no minds," and "the mind is completely transparent to itself" are willful denials of the obvious.

positions.statement: While it's a good idea not to impute minds to stones, it's obviously not a good idea not to impute them to people.
positions.verbatim_quote: While it's a good idea not to impute minds to stones, it's obviously not a good idea not to impute them to people.

positions.statement: The projector itself cannot be a projection; the mind cannot be eliminated from the scientific picture.
positions.verbatim_quote: The projector itself cannot be a projection; the mind cannot be eliminated from the scientific picture.

positions.statement: One can partly de-operationalize beliefs one doesn't want by choosing not to delineate their consequences.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can partly de-operationalize beliefs one doesn't want by choosing not to delineate their consequences.

positions.statement: One can isolate a belief—prevent it from engaging bodies of belief it would otherwise engage and from begetting beliefs it would otherwise beget.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can isolate a belief—prevent it from engaging bodies of belief it would otherwise engage and from begetting beliefs it would otherwise beget.

positions.statement: By de-operationalizing acceptance of a fact, one can cease to have more than an abstract, formal understanding of what it amounts to.
positions.verbatim_quote: By de-operationalizing acceptance of a fact, one can cease to have more than an abstract, formal understanding of what it amounts to.

positions.statement: One can choose to look for reasons to have beliefs opposed to those one wishes one didn't have, like a lawyer building a case for a client known to be guilty.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can choose to look for reasons to have beliefs opposed to those one wishes one didn't have, like a lawyer building a case for a client known to be guilty.

positions.statement: Even though one can't directly choose one's beliefs, one can choose to do things that make it harder to attend to a given belief than to withdraw attention from it.
positions.verbatim_quote: Even though one can't directly choose one's beliefs, one can choose to do things that make it harder to attend to a given belief than to withdraw attention from it.

positions.statement: The sub-personal gathering and processing of information is more fundamental than personal gathering and processing; minds are more basic than selves.
positions.verbatim_quote: The sub-personal gathering and processing of information is more fundamental than personal gathering and processing; minds are more basic than selves.

positions.statement: One's decisions about what goes on in one's mind are of limited scope, affecting how conscious strata communicate with other strata but not directly affecting deeper strata.
positions.verbatim_quote: One's decisions about what goes on in one's mind are of limited scope, affecting how conscious strata communicate with other strata but not directly affecting deeper strata.

positions.statement: Contemporary theoretical psychology's denial of emotions and repression is itself thoroughly emotional and an instance of repression—a rationalization serving to keep unwanted self-knowledge at bay.
positions.verbatim_quote: Contemporary theoretical psychology's denial of emotions and repression is itself thoroughly emotional and an instance of repression—a rationalization serving to keep unwanted self-knowledge at bay.

positions.statement: The claim that self-deception is conceptually incoherent is demonstrably false.
positions.verbatim_quote: The claim that self-deception is conceptually incoherent is demonstrably false.

positions.statement: The apparent paradox of repression (that one must be conscious of what one represses) dissolves once one distinguishes repression₁ from repression₂.
positions.verbatim_quote: The apparent paradox of repression (that one must be conscious of what one represses) dissolves once one distinguishes repression₁ from repression₂.

positions.statement: The natures of both conscious and unconscious forces involved in repression₁ differ from those involved in repression₂.
positions.verbatim_quote: The natures of both conscious and unconscious forces involved in repression₁ differ from those involved in repression₂.

positions.statement: The possibility of self-deception is a consequence of three facts about the mind: its disunity, the distinction between acquaintance and description, and the ambiguity of "conscious."
positions.verbatim_quote: The possibility of self-deception is a consequence of three facts about the mind: its disunity, the distinction between acquaintance and description, and the ambiguity of "conscious."

positions.statement: The right hand of the mind doesn't always know what the left is doing.
positions.verbatim_quote: The right hand of the mind doesn't always know what the left is doing.

positions.statement: One can unwittingly have two divergent attitudes towards a single propositional attitude of one's own.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can unwittingly have two divergent attitudes towards a single propositional attitude of one's own.

positions.statement: Given only that two conscious events are derivatives of some propositional attitude, it doesn't follow that any one part of one's mind has the information needed to recognize that attitude in both.
positions.verbatim_quote: Given only that two conscious events are derivatives of some propositional attitude, it doesn't follow that any one part of one's mind has the information needed to recognize that attitude in both.

positions.statement: Were one's belief that 1+1=2 inoperative whenever not blazing a trail across consciousness, one's way of dealing with the world would bear little resemblance to one's actual way.
positions.verbatim_quote: Were one's belief that 1+1=2 inoperative whenever not blazing a trail across consciousness, one's way of dealing with the world would bear little resemblance to one's actual way.

positions.statement: Supposing knowledge is identical with some physiological structure, that structure is psychologically active as a belief even when not the object of consciousness—not just as a heap of molecules.
positions.verbatim_quote: Supposing knowledge is identical with some physiological structure, that structure is psychologically active as a belief even when not the object of consciousness—not just as a heap of molecules.

positions.statement: One can have thoughts about Charlemagne and thus have a concept of him, yet fail to recognize him if one met him.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can have thoughts about Charlemagne and thus have a concept of him, yet fail to recognize him if one met him.

positions.statement: So long as one didn't figure out who Charlemagne was upon meeting him, one would unwittingly have two distinct concepts of him.
positions.verbatim_quote: So long as one didn't figure out who Charlemagne was upon meeting him, one would unwittingly have two distinct concepts of him.

positions.statement: One can discover that the gnawing feeling of unpleasantness experienced when somebody mentions Smith is one's detestation of Smith.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can discover that the gnawing feeling of unpleasantness experienced when somebody mentions Smith is one's detestation of Smith.

positions.statement: One can be acquainted with a given one of one's own mental contents while also having descriptive knowledge of it.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can be acquainted with a given one of one's own mental contents while also having descriptive knowledge of it.

positions.statement: One can discover that one actually has some attitude towards a mental entity that one did not previously know oneself to have.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can discover that one actually has some attitude towards a mental entity that one did not previously know oneself to have.

positions.statement: What one is directly given in consciousness are various indications that one has a particular emotion, not the emotion per se.
positions.verbatim_quote: What one is directly given in consciousness are various indications that one has a particular emotion, not the emotion per se.

positions.statement: Even when indications of an emotion are strong enough to leave no room for reasonable doubt, one still must "synthesize" them by making a judgment.
positions.verbatim_quote: Even when indications of an emotion are strong enough to leave no room for reasonable doubt, one still must "synthesize" them by making a judgment.

positions.statement: In most cases, the judgment that synthesizes emotional indications is made so automatically that one is unaware any judgment has been made.
positions.verbatim_quote: In most cases, the judgment that synthesizes emotional indications is made so automatically that one is unaware any judgment has been made.

positions.statement: When a propositional attitude is emotionally sterile—concerning number-theory or epistemology—we have no trouble making the needed judgments about it.
positions.verbatim_quote: When a propositional attitude is emotionally sterile—concerning number-theory or epistemology—we have no trouble making the needed judgments about it.

positions.statement: Evidences of a propositional attitude may be dispersed over time and occur in multifarious contexts.
positions.verbatim_quote: Evidences of a propositional attitude may be dispersed over time and occur in multifarious contexts.

positions.statement: Part (b) of the conventional conception of repression—that repressed content constantly struggles to break into consciousness—is paradoxical as stated.
positions.verbatim_quote: Part (b) of the conventional conception of repression—that repressed content constantly struggles to break into consciousness—is paradoxical as stated.

positions.statement: The paradox arises because keeping content out of consciousness would seem to require knowing what that content is.
positions.verbatim_quote: The paradox arises because keeping content out of consciousness would seem to require knowing what that content is.

positions.statement: The conventional conception incorrectly describes repression as an operation performed on existing beliefs rather than a failure to form beliefs.
positions.verbatim_quote: The conventional conception incorrectly describes repression as an operation performed on existing beliefs rather than a failure to form beliefs.

positions.statement: Repression₁ involves choosing not to learn something that, if learned and therefore known, one would wish one had never learned—but only after it was too late.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repression₁ involves choosing not to learn something that, if learned and therefore known, one would wish one had never learned—but only after it was too late.

positions.statement: Every case of repression₁ does involve intrapsychic conflict, as the conventional conception says.
positions.verbatim_quote: Every case of repression₁ does involve intrapsychic conflict, as the conventional conception says.

positions.statement: Contrary to the conventional conception, the conflict in repression₁ is not between unconscious knowledge of truth T and conscious ignorance of T.
positions.verbatim_quote: Contrary to the conventional conception, the conflict in repression₁ is not between unconscious knowledge of truth T and conscious ignorance of T.

positions.statement: The conflict in repression₁ is between a wish to know the truth and a wish not to know the truth.
positions.verbatim_quote: The conflict in repression₁ is between a wish to know the truth and a wish not to know the truth.

positions.statement: One can choose activities that flood the judgment-making faculty with information concerning judgments one wants to avoid making.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can choose activities that flood the judgment-making faculty with information concerning judgments one wants to avoid making.

positions.statement: One can choose to do things that deplete the judgment-making faculty of energy it needs to function (e.g., intense exercise for hours).
positions.verbatim_quote: One can choose to do things that deplete the judgment-making faculty of energy it needs to function (e.g., intense exercise for hours).

positions.statement: One can choose to paralyze the physiological underpinnings of judgments (e.g., by getting drunk) or permanently damage them (e.g., by lobotomy).
positions.verbatim_quote: One can choose to paralyze the physiological underpinnings of judgments (e.g., by getting drunk) or permanently damage them (e.g., by lobotomy).

positions.statement: One cannot directly choose what to believe; one can only choose what to believe in the way one can choose to gain weight.
positions.verbatim_quote: One cannot directly choose what to believe; one can only choose what to believe in the way one can choose to gain weight.

positions.statement: Within limits, one can choose which beliefs to make operational and which to make non-operational.
positions.verbatim_quote: Within limits, one can choose which beliefs to make operational and which to make non-operational.

positions.statement: One can choose to do things that make a given belief impotent and irrelevant.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can choose to do things that make a given belief impotent and irrelevant.

positions.statement: One can choose an occupation in which a lack of some ability is irrelevant, thereby making one's knowledge of that lack irrelevant.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can choose an occupation in which a lack of some ability is irrelevant, thereby making one's knowledge of that lack irrelevant.

positions.statement: What it would take to convince you that somebody you're not married to is cheating on his wife is minuscule compared to what it would take to convince you that your husband is cheating.
positions.verbatim_quote: What it would take to convince you that somebody you're not married to is cheating on his wife is minuscule compared to what it would take to convince you that your husband is cheating.

positions.statement: Because evolution implies we're meaningless orangutans, we won't judge it worthy of acceptance until it's met absurdly high standards of evidence.
positions.verbatim_quote: Because evolution implies we're meaningless orangutans, we won't judge it worthy of acceptance until it's met absurdly high standards of evidence.

positions.statement: Denying that orangutans are our biological kin is like denying that the person with grape jelly and crumbs around his mouth ate your jelly-doughnut.
positions.verbatim_quote: Denying that orangutans are our biological kin is like denying that the person with grape jelly and crumbs around his mouth ate your jelly-doughnut.

positions.statement: If you read Freud and then study a single person's behavior for around 10 minutes, it becomes clear his theories are theoretically conservative.
positions.verbatim_quote: If you read Freud and then study a single person's behavior for around 10 minutes, it becomes clear his theories are theoretically conservative.

positions.statement: People don't want to part with rationalizations; they'd rather be a king in their dreams than a janitor in reality.
positions.verbatim_quote: People don't want to part with rationalizations; they'd rather be a king in their dreams than a janitor in reality.

positions.statement: The opposition to Freud's claims involves regressions to crude positions: "We're computers" (Fodor), "There is no consciousness" (Dennett), "There are no minds" (Quine).
positions.verbatim_quote: The opposition to Freud's claims involves regressions to crude positions: "We're computers" (Fodor), "There is no consciousness" (Dennett), "There are no minds" (Quine).

positions.statement: Searle's view that the mind is completely transparent to itself is a willful denial of the obvious.
positions.verbatim_quote: Searle's view that the mind is completely transparent to itself is a willful denial of the obvious.

positions.statement: The Churchlands' view that nobody believes, doubts, or hopes for anything—that propositional attitude terms belong to "folk-psychology"—is demonstrably false.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Churchlands' view that nobody believes, doubts, or hopes for anything—that propositional attitude terms belong to "folk-psychology"—is demonstrably false.

positions.statement: The Dretske-Fodor view that there is no difference between a concept of a person and a photograph of that person is risible.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Dretske-Fodor view that there is no difference between a concept of a person and a photograph of that person is risible.

positions.statement: These flights into inanity are touted as "scientific" and "rigorous" under the pretense of completing science's victory over animism.
positions.verbatim_quote: These flights into inanity are touted as "scientific" and "rigorous" under the pretense of completing science's victory over animism.

positions.statement: While it's good not to impute minds to stones, the projector—the mind itself—cannot be a projection.
positions.verbatim_quote: While it's good not to impute minds to stones, the projector—the mind itself—cannot be a projection.

positions.statement: For one's knowledge of an ugly truth to be repressed₂, that knowledge, when taken with other accepted propositions, entails a more generic proposition.
positions.verbatim_quote: For one's knowledge of an ugly truth to be repressed₂, that knowledge, when taken with other accepted propositions, entails a more generic proposition.

positions.statement: The more generic proposition can be kept in consciousness without having to overhaul one's entire life.
positions.verbatim_quote: The more generic proposition can be kept in consciousness without having to overhaul one's entire life.

positions.statement: The generic proposition is sufficiently vague that knowledge of it won't make one retch at the sight of the problematic object.
positions.verbatim_quote: The generic proposition is sufficiently vague that knowledge of it won't make one retch at the sight of the problematic object.

positions.statement: One can realize one wishes one hadn't discovered an ugly truth while also realizing that mere suppression won't suffice.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can realize one wishes one hadn't discovered an ugly truth while also realizing that mere suppression won't suffice.

positions.statement: One can resolve that, when confronted with data that led to the ugly belief, one will model it in a way consistent with the generic belief but not with the specific ugly truth.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can resolve that, when confronted with data that led to the ugly belief, one will model it in a way consistent with the generic belief but not with the specific ugly truth.

positions.statement: Beliefs are inert except to the extent that one draws consequences from them and that they are allowed to beget or engage other beliefs.
positions.verbatim_quote: Beliefs are inert except to the extent that one draws consequences from them and that they are allowed to beget or engage other beliefs.

positions.statement: The making of inferences at least sometimes involves deliberate, conscious effort.
positions.verbatim_quote: The making of inferences at least sometimes involves deliberate, conscious effort.

positions.statement: Some inferences are made involuntarily; insights often just occur to one based on rational consideration of evidence.
positions.verbatim_quote: Some inferences are made involuntarily; insights often just occur to one based on rational consideration of evidence.

positions.statement: Even though many inferences are made involuntarily, one has at least some control over what sorts of inferences one's mind makes.
positions.verbatim_quote: Even though many inferences are made involuntarily, one has at least some control over what sorts of inferences one's mind makes.

positions.statement: One can so structure one's life that it is very unlikely one will consciously make inferences from a belief that one would otherwise make.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can so structure one's life that it is very unlikely one will consciously make inferences from a belief that one would otherwise make.

positions.statement: One can so structure one's life that a belief, though still conscious, is isolated—prevented from engaging bodies of belief and from begetting beliefs it otherwise would.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can so structure one's life that a belief, though still conscious, is isolated—prevented from engaging bodies of belief and from begetting beliefs it otherwise would.

positions.statement: Such an isolated belief is conscious in some formal sense but has become inert at the level of consciousness, like knowledge of some random, uninteresting fact.
positions.verbatim_quote: Such an isolated belief is conscious in some formal sense but has become inert at the level of consciousness, like knowledge of some random, uninteresting fact.

positions.statement: By de-operationalizing acceptance of a fact, one can cease to have anything more than an abstract, formal understanding of what it amounts to.
positions.verbatim_quote: By de-operationalizing acceptance of a fact, one can cease to have anything more than an abstract, formal understanding of what it amounts to.

positions.statement: One can know that people are being tortured without knowing what that proposition amounts to as well as someone who witnessed torture.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can know that people are being tortured without knowing what that proposition amounts to as well as someone who witnessed torture.

positions.statement: Even if technically no less aware of a truth than someone with first-hand knowledge, one's awareness can mean very little compared to theirs.
positions.verbatim_quote: Even if technically no less aware of a truth than someone with first-hand knowledge, one's awareness can mean very little compared to theirs.

positions.statement: First-hand knowledge transforms abstract awareness into something that means a great deal.
positions.verbatim_quote: First-hand knowledge transforms abstract awareness into something that means a great deal.

positions.statement: Knowledge of complex interpersonal truths is not derived from some one sense-perception; such truths can't be known that directly.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowledge of complex interpersonal truths is not derived from some one sense-perception; such truths can't be known that directly.

positions.statement: Such knowledge embodies inference to the best explanation.
positions.verbatim_quote: Such knowledge embodies inference to the best explanation.

positions.statement: Unless knowledge can be acquired through inferences to the best explanation, what we actually know is only an infinitesimally small part of what we think we know.
positions.verbatim_quote: Unless knowledge can be acquired through inferences to the best explanation, what we actually know is only an infinitesimally small part of what we think we know.

positions.statement: Given a body of data, it is more likely than not that there is more than one reasonable or semi-reasonable way to model it.
positions.verbatim_quote: Given a body of data, it is more likely than not that there is more than one reasonable or semi-reasonable way to model it.

positions.statement: An alternative model of data need not be optimal; it need only be far from obviously false to serve repression₂.
positions.verbatim_quote: An alternative model of data need not be optimal; it need only be far from obviously false to serve repression₂.

positions.statement: By deciding not to draw inferences from an ugly belief, one becomes more likely to take aberrant phenomena on a case-by-case basis.
positions.verbatim_quote: By deciding not to draw inferences from an ugly belief, one becomes more likely to take aberrant phenomena on a case-by-case basis.

positions.statement: Bits of knowledge that would otherwise congregate will remain isolated from one another when one resolves not to synthesize them.
positions.verbatim_quote: Bits of knowledge that would otherwise congregate will remain isolated from one another when one resolves not to synthesize them.

positions.statement: As a result of isolation, one's appreciation of what an ugly truth entails will remain superficial.
positions.verbatim_quote: As a result of isolation, one's appreciation of what an ugly truth entails will remain superficial.

positions.statement: One will be slow to recognize the consequences of an ugly truth for one's own welfare.
positions.verbatim_quote: One will be slow to recognize the consequences of an ugly truth for one's own welfare.

positions.statement: By isolating a belief, one ensures that energy and thought that would deepen understanding of its consequences are diverted to a fool's errand.
positions.verbatim_quote: By isolating a belief, one ensures that energy and thought that would deepen understanding of its consequences are diverted to a fool's errand.

positions.statement: The response of modeling data in terms of a preferred alternative soon becomes automatic, like an actor's rehearsed lines.
positions.verbatim_quote: The response of modeling data in terms of a preferred alternative soon becomes automatic, like an actor's rehearsed lines.

positions.statement: This automatic response-mechanism further isolates the knowledge one wishes to suppress.
positions.verbatim_quote: This automatic response-mechanism further isolates the knowledge one wishes to suppress.

positions.statement: One cannot uninstall a belief by tinkering with its representations in consciousness, just as one typically cannot uninstall a computer program by dragging the desktop icon to the garbage.
positions.verbatim_quote: One cannot uninstall a belief by tinkering with its representations in consciousness, just as one typically cannot uninstall a computer program by dragging the desktop icon to the garbage.

positions.statement: Beliefs are enduring structures; they do a lot of work even when not consciously deployed.
positions.verbatim_quote: Beliefs are enduring structures; they do a lot of work even when not consciously deployed.

positions.statement: If one really stopped knowing that 1+1=2, one's way of dealing with the world would suddenly change radically, pervading practically every field of endeavor.
positions.verbatim_quote: If one really stopped knowing that 1+1=2, one's way of dealing with the world would suddenly change radically, pervading practically every field of endeavor.

positions.statement: A belief isn't like a mood or other will-o'-the-wisps that populate consciousness.
positions.verbatim_quote: A belief isn't like a mood or other will-o'-the-wisps that populate consciousness.

positions.statement: Like any enduring structure constitutive of one's metabolism, one has at most partial control over a belief's fortunes.
positions.verbatim_quote: Like any enduring structure constitutive of one's metabolism, one has at most partial control over a belief's fortunes.

positions.statement: The conscious representative of a repressed₂ belief becomes an innocuous shell—it has been repressed, but it still lives on.
positions.verbatim_quote: The conscious representative of a repressed₂ belief becomes an innocuous shell—it has been repressed, but it still lives on.

positions.statement: A repressed₂ belief "presses for discharge" (Freud's term).
positions.verbatim_quote: A repressed₂ belief "presses for discharge" (Freud's term).

positions.statement: Since one no longer acknowledges a repressed₂ belief's existence, it cannot be discharged through intentional behavior.
positions.verbatim_quote: Since one no longer acknowledges a repressed₂ belief's existence, it cannot be discharged through intentional behavior.

positions.statement: A repressed₂ belief must insinuate itself into one's intentions without one's knowing it.
positions.verbatim_quote: A repressed₂ belief must insinuate itself into one's intentions without one's knowing it.

positions.statement: Displacement occurs when repressed rage at one person is expressed as meanness toward another (e.g., rage at father displaced onto students).
positions.verbatim_quote: Displacement occurs when repressed rage at one person is expressed as meanness toward another (e.g., rage at father displaced onto students).

positions.statement: A repressed₂ belief can be expressed as a symptom—e.g., crippling anxiety when encountering situations reminiscent of what was repressed.
positions.verbatim_quote: A repressed₂ belief can be expressed as a symptom—e.g., crippling anxiety when encountering situations reminiscent of what was repressed.

positions.statement: To keep something repressed₂, one must be able to identify it—but if one can identify it, one is conscious of it and it's not repressed.
positions.verbatim_quote: To keep something repressed₂, one must be able to identify it—but if one can identify it, one is conscious of it and it's not repressed.

positions.statement: The resolution of this paradox involves retaining knowledge of a generic proposition while repressing the specific ugly truth.
positions.verbatim_quote: The resolution of this paradox involves retaining knowledge of a generic proposition while repressing the specific ugly truth.

positions.statement: By accepting a generic version of an ugly truth, one's conscious disposition isn't completely antagonistic to the rational side urging acceptance of the specific truth.
positions.verbatim_quote: By accepting a generic version of an ugly truth, one's conscious disposition isn't completely antagonistic to the rational side urging acceptance of the specific truth.

positions.verbatim_quote: If you wait, the moment and the unconscious constellation behind the thought will be lost.

positions.statement: The #1 rule of writing is also complete honesty, which is achieved by writing thoughts immediately.
positions.verbatim_quote: The #1 rule of writing is also complete honesty, which is achieved by writing thoughts immediately.

positions.statement: Lack of coordination stems from a failure to be centered and to have a true objective.
positions.verbatim_quote: Lack of coordination stems from a failure to be centered and to have a true objective.

positions.statement: A psychological condition is pathological if it restricts freedom.
positions.verbatim_quote: A psychological condition is pathological if it restricts freedom.

positions.statement: A condition is positively counter-pathological if it augments freedom, even if unusual.
positions.verbatim_quote: A condition is positively counter-pathological if it augments freedom, even if unusual.

positions.statement: The expression "the intentions of the framers" denotes an idealization, not an empirical actuality, since the various framers had numerically and qualitatively different minds.
positions.verbatim_quote: The expression "the intentions of the framers" denotes an idealization, not an empirical actuality, since the various framers had numerically and qualitatively different minds.

positions.statement: When the word "they" is part of an expression meant to denote a collective attitude, it denotes an idealization rather than an empirical reality.
positions.verbatim_quote: When the word "they" is part of an expression meant to denote a collective attitude, it denotes an idealization rather than an empirical reality.

positions.statement: Originalism is exceedingly dubious if the term "intentions" is understood in purely individualistic, psychological terms.
positions.verbatim_quote: Originalism is exceedingly dubious if the term "intentions" is understood in purely individualistic, psychological terms.

positions.statement: If originalism is to hold water, "the intentions of the framers" must refer to the intentions of some kind of collective entity.
positions.verbatim_quote: If originalism is to hold water, "the intentions of the framers" must refer to the intentions of some kind of collective entity.

positions.statement: The intentions of the framers cannot be understood strictly in terms of the psychologies of the framers taken individually.
positions.verbatim_quote: The intentions of the framers cannot be understood strictly in terms of the psychologies of the framers taken individually.

positions.statement: The originalist position collapses into circularity: Constitutional interpretations are to be evaluated in terms of the intentions of the framers, but the intentions of the framers are to be understood in terms of the historical and social role of Constitutional interpretation.
positions.verbatim_quote: The originalist position collapses into circularity: Constitutional interpretations are to be evaluated in terms of the intentions of the framers, but the intentions of the framers are to be understood in terms of the historical and social role of Constitutional interpretation.

positions.statement: An idealization is by definition something that has no precise counterpart in the spatiotemporal world.
positions.verbatim_quote: An idealization is by definition something that has no precise counterpart in the spatiotemporal world.

positions.statement: When discussing what Jefferson would have said about constitutional issues, we are not making an empirical statement about what the actual Jefferson would have said, but rather an a priori proposition about what he should have said given his values.
positions.verbatim_quote: When discussing what Jefferson would have said about constitutional issues, we are not making an empirical statement about what the actual Jefferson would have said, but rather an a priori proposition about what he should have said given his values.

positions.statement: The originalist is caught in a vicious circle: he must use a counterfactual to identify the values on which his conception of Constitutionality is based, but he cannot run the counterfactual until he has identified those values.
positions.verbatim_quote: The originalist is caught in a vicious circle: he must use a counterfactual to identify the values on which his conception of Constitutionality is based, but he cannot run the counterfactual until he has identified those values.

positions.statement: Jefferson's values are definable independently of any views of Constitutional interpretation, but the expression "Jefferson's values" itself denotes an idealization as opposed to a psychological reality.
positions.verbatim_quote: Jefferson's values are definable independently of any views of Constitutional interpretation, but the expression "Jefferson's values" itself denotes an idealization as opposed to a psychological reality.

positions.statement: Like many complex human beings, Jefferson had many values, and while some may have been fair-minded and egalitarian, others may have been retrograde and misogynist.
positions.verbatim_quote: Like many complex human beings, Jefferson had many values, and while some may have been fair-minded and egalitarian, others may have been retrograde and misogynist.

positions.statement: When we say that Jefferson was not being "true to his values," the word "his" doesn't denote Thomas Jefferson the human being but rather an idealization of Jefferson purged of his 18th century prejudices.
positions.verbatim_quote: When we say that Jefferson was not being "true to his values," the word "his" doesn't denote Thomas Jefferson the human being but rather an idealization of Jefferson purged of his 18th century prejudices.

positions.statement: Even the finest minds are marred by ugly biases.
positions.verbatim_quote: Even the finest minds are marred by ugly biases.

positions.statement: When we talk about what Jefferson would have said, we are talking about what some idealization of Jefferson would have said—one who didn't suffer from the cultural limitations and random neuroses that mar even the best of minds.
positions.verbatim_quote: When we talk about what Jefferson would have said, we are talking about what some idealization of Jefferson would have said—one who didn't suffer from the cultural limitations and random neuroses that mar even the best of minds.

positions.statement: Once we start dealing with an idealization of Jefferson's psyche, as opposed to his actual psyche, we have replaced empirical propositions about psychology with a priori propositions about values.
positions.verbatim_quote: Once we start dealing with an idealization of Jefferson's psyche, as opposed to his actual psyche, we have replaced empirical propositions about psychology with a priori propositions about values.

positions.statement: People with borderline personality disorder have two distinct, simultaneously operative psychological "operating systems"—one appropriately adult and sane, the other infantile in nature.
positions.verbatim_quote: People with borderline personality disorder have two distinct, simultaneously operative psychological "operating systems"—one appropriately adult and sane, the other infantile in nature.

positions.statement: One part of the BPD person's mind remained "stuck" or "fixated" at an early phase of life, usually very early childhood, while the other part advanced to maturity.
positions.verbatim_quote: One part of the BPD person's mind remained "stuck" or "fixated" at an early phase of life, usually very early childhood, while the other part advanced to maturity.

positions.statement: The fixation in BPD typically results from a trauma, usually sexual molestation.
positions.verbatim_quote: The fixation in BPD typically results from a trauma, usually sexual molestation.

positions.statement: People with BPD oscillate between their adult and infantile psychological integrations.
positions.verbatim_quote: People with BPD oscillate between their adult and infantile psychological integrations.

positions.statement: The rapid oscillation between two modalities makes BPD individuals appear to be lying or "playing games," when in fact they are shifting between two distinct and incongruent worldviews.
positions.verbatim_quote: The rapid oscillation between two modalities makes BPD individuals appear to be lying or "playing games," when in fact they are shifting between two distinct and incongruent worldviews.

positions.statement: People with BPD are not psychopaths, despite sometimes acting in entitled, limitlessly self-serving narcissistic ways.
positions.verbatim_quote: People with BPD are not psychopaths, despite sometimes acting in entitled, limitlessly self-serving narcissistic ways.

positions.statement: The difference between BPD and psychopathy: the psychopath is simply a phony who sometimes puts on a mask of sanity and decency, while the BPD person is genuinely two-sided, with neither side being a mask.
positions.verbatim_quote: The difference between BPD and psychopathy: the psychopath is simply a phony who sometimes puts on a mask of sanity and decency, while the BPD person is genuinely two-sided, with neither side being a mask.

positions.statement: The preferred psychological defense mechanism in BPD is splitting rather than repression.
positions.verbatim_quote: The preferred psychological defense mechanism in BPD is splitting rather than repression.

positions.statement: The BPD personality-structure is itself the result of splitting.
positions.verbatim_quote: The BPD personality-structure is itself the result of splitting.

positions.statement: Repression involves having a single psychological architecture and shoving incompatible conceits into the unconscious, while splitting involves shifting between one's adult side and one's infantile side.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repression involves having a single psychological architecture and shoving incompatible conceits into the unconscious, while splitting involves shifting between one's adult side and one's infantile side.

positions.statement: The normal person's psyche keeps its infantilism in the abyss of the unconscious, while the BPD person's psyche keeps infantilisms in a concurrently operative sphere of mental activity.
positions.verbatim_quote: The normal person's psyche keeps its infantilism in the abyss of the unconscious, while the BPD person's psyche keeps infantilisms in a concurrently operative sphere of mental activity.

positions.statement: The essence of borderline personality disorder is that splitting takes the place of repression.
positions.verbatim_quote: The essence of borderline personality disorder is that splitting takes the place of repression.

positions.statement: When the psychopath acts non-psychopathically, it is because he is just acting; when the BPD person acts non-psychopathically, it is because she is being true to one side of her personality.
positions.verbatim_quote: When the psychopath acts non-psychopathically, it is because he is just acting; when the BPD person acts non-psychopathically, it is because she is being true to one side of her personality.

positions.statement: When the BPD person acts psychopathically, it is because she is regressing and her infantile side is dominating, not because a mask has fallen.
positions.verbatim_quote: When the BPD person acts psychopathically, it is because she is regressing and her infantile side is dominating, not because a mask has fallen.

positions.statement: Most people, including most psychologists, wrongly assume that group psychology is to be understood in terms of individual psychology.
positions.verbatim_quote: Most people, including most psychologists, wrongly assume that group psychology is to be understood in terms of individual psychology.

positions.statement: The standard view that individuals have self-directed drives that are somehow diverted in group contexts cannot be reconciled with the incredibly high degree of conformism exhibited by people.
positions.verbatim_quote: The standard view that individuals have self-directed drives that are somehow diverted in group contexts cannot be reconciled with the incredibly high degree of conformism exhibited by people.

positions.statement: The deference given by people to convention, pre-existing custom, and fleeting but powerful fads cannot be explained in terms of fear of others alone.
positions.verbatim_quote: The deference given by people to convention, pre-existing custom, and fleeting but powerful fads cannot be explained in terms of fear of others alone.

positions.statement: Given how unintelligent, ignorant, and lacking in moral fiber most individuals are, yet how much intelligence, knowledge, and moral rigor is embodied in the behavior of collectives, it is hard to believe that collectives are merely the result of individuals pursuing their respective paths.
positions.verbatim_quote: Given how unintelligent, ignorant, and lacking in moral fiber most individuals are, yet how much intelligence, knowledge, and moral rigor is embodied in the behavior of collectives, it is hard to believe that collectives are merely the result of individuals pursuing their respective paths.

positions.statement: The collective is the primary thing, biologically speaking, and there is an illusion of individual choice and indeed of individualism per se.
positions.verbatim_quote: The collective is the primary thing, biologically speaking, and there is an illusion of individual choice and indeed of individualism per se.

positions.statement: Individual cells can be better understood if we recognize that they individually try to survive, flourish, and reproduce only to the extent that their doing so is necessary for the collectives formed thereby to survive, flourish, and reproduce.
positions.verbatim_quote: Individual cells can be better understood if we recognize that they individually try to survive, flourish, and reproduce only to the extent that their doing so is necessary for the collectives formed thereby to survive, flourish, and reproduce.

positions.statement: Cell-individualism can be explained in terms of cell collectivism, but not so much vice versa.
positions.verbatim_quote: Cell-individualism can be explained in terms of cell collectivism, but not so much vice versa.

positions.statement: Person-individualism can be explained in terms of person-collectivism, but not so much vice versa.
positions.verbatim_quote: Person-individualism can be explained in terms of person-collectivism, but not so much vice versa.

positions.statement: Bona fide individuals—geniuses who think for themselves—can be seen as limiting cases of collectives, as collectives of one, or as rogue actors with an unusual office within a collective.
positions.verbatim_quote: Bona fide individuals—geniuses who think for themselves—can be seen as limiting cases of collectives, as collectives of one, or as rogue actors with an unusual office within a collective.

positions.statement: The intense drives that individuals have to survive and experience gratification can be seen as necessary for, and therefore explainable in terms of, the collectives to which they belong.
positions.verbatim_quote: The intense drives that individuals have to survive and experience gratification can be seen as necessary for, and therefore explainable in terms of, the collectives to which they belong.

positions.statement: It is very hard to explain group behavior on the assumption that collectives represent averages of the behaviors of so many self-contained existentialist autonomous deciders.
positions.verbatim_quote: It is very hard to explain group behavior on the assumption that collectives represent averages of the behaviors of so many self-contained existentialist autonomous deciders.

positions.statement: Outside of contexts involving immediate threats to physical well-being or prospects of crude gratification, people give far too much weight to existing beliefs and mores to be accounted for by the hypothesis that collectives are indeed collectives of bona fide individuals.
positions.verbatim_quote: Outside of contexts involving immediate threats to physical well-being or prospects of crude gratification, people give far too much weight to existing beliefs and mores to be accounted for by the hypothesis that collectives are indeed collectives of bona fide individuals.

positions.statement: Before the 1929 Stock Market Crash, the nation's financial system was highly unregulated, leading to improprieties that caused the Crash.
positions.verbatim_quote: Before the 1929 Stock Market Crash, the nation's financial system was highly unregulated, leading to improprieties that caused the Crash.

positions.statement: The Fed responded to the Stock Market Crash by tightening monetary policy, which exacerbated the situation and led to a full-blown economic depression.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Fed responded to the Stock Market Crash by tightening monetary policy, which exacerbated the situation and led to a full-blown economic depression.

positions.statement: Glass-Steagall prohibited commercial banks from functioning as investment banks, thereby preventing banks from using customer funds to finance their own ventures.
positions.verbatim_quote: Glass-Steagall prohibited commercial banks from functioning as investment banks, thereby preventing banks from using customer funds to finance their own ventures.

positions.statement: The repeal of Glass-Steagall in 1999 and the deregulation of the derivatives market in 2004 eliminated the firewalls put in place after the 1929 Crash.
positions.verbatim_quote: The repeal of Glass-Steagall in 1999 and the deregulation of the derivatives market in 2004 eliminated the firewalls put in place after the 1929 Crash.

positions.statement: The 2001 Dot Bomb Crash resulted from banks investing in substandard tech startups, and the 2008 Housing Crash resulted from banks investing in worthless derivatives contracts.
positions.verbatim_quote: The 2001 Dot Bomb Crash resulted from banks investing in substandard tech startups, and the 2008 Housing Crash resulted from banks investing in worthless derivatives contracts.

positions.statement: A derivative is a contract whose value is a function of the value of some other security, and most derivatives are highly leveraged, highly risky, and difficult to value.
positions.verbatim_quote: A derivative is a contract whose value is a function of the value of some other security, and most derivatives are highly leveraged, highly risky, and difficult to value.

positions.statement: The price of a home tends to stay close to its value, but with securities there is very little short-term relationship between price and value—the two can diverge without limit instantaneously.
positions.verbatim_quote: The price of a home tends to stay close to its value, but with securities there is very little short-term relationship between price and value—the two can diverge without limit instantaneously.

positions.statement: When real-estate debts were bundled into financial securities like MBS's, the market could make them far more valuable than the underlying assets, and could do so in hours.
positions.verbatim_quote: When real-estate debts were bundled into financial securities like MBS's, the market could make them far more valuable than the underlying assets, and could do so in hours.

positions.statement: Once mortgages were securitized, investment banks had enormous incentives to drive up the number of home loans issued, regardless of the quality of those loans.
positions.verbatim_quote: Once mortgages were securitized, investment banks had enormous incentives to drive up the number of home loans issued, regardless of the quality of those loans.

positions.statement: Bubbles can only last so long; eventually prices and values converge when demand fails to keep pace with supply.
positions.verbatim_quote: Bubbles can only last so long; eventually prices and values converge when demand fails to keep pace with supply.

positions.statement: The 2008 crisis was really two distinct crises: a housing crisis that decreased wealth and a banking crisis that diminished credit.
positions.verbatim_quote: The 2008 crisis was really two distinct crises: a housing crisis that decreased wealth and a banking crisis that diminished credit.

positions.statement: Economies depend on credit as much as they do on wealth; when businesses cannot borrow, they fail and the economy fails.
positions.verbatim_quote: Economies depend on credit as much as they do on wealth; when businesses cannot borrow, they fail and the economy fails.

positions.statement: The Volcker Rule does not categorically prohibit banks from engaging in proprietary trading but requires that they match customer funds with their own funds when doing so.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Volcker Rule does not categorically prohibit banks from engaging in proprietary trading but requires that they match customer funds with their own funds when doing so.

positions.statement: The Volcker Rule prohibits banks from partnering with hedge funds and private equity firms to limit the extent to which large banks can endanger themselves and the market.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Volcker Rule prohibits banks from partnering with hedge funds and private equity firms to limit the extent to which large banks can endanger themselves and the market.

positions.statement: The Fed's role as a regulatory agency is ambiguous, since unlike every other financial regulatory agency, it is partly made up of the very entities it is supposed to regulate.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Fed's role as a regulatory agency is ambiguous, since unlike every other financial regulatory agency, it is partly made up of the very entities it is supposed to regulate.

positions.statement: Given that three banks own over 75% of the Fed's shares, the Fed has at best a serious conflict of interest and at worst has no existence separate from the banks that own it.
positions.verbatim_quote: Given that three banks own over 75% of the Fed's shares, the Fed has at best a serious conflict of interest and at worst has no existence separate from the banks that own it.

positions.statement: Financial regulation has done a great deal of good and very little harm; financial deregulation has done a great deal of harm and very little good.
positions.verbatim_quote: Financial regulation has done a great deal of good and very little harm; financial deregulation has done a great deal of harm and very little good.

positions.statement: The Fed is in the practice of managing self-generated crises.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Fed is in the practice of managing self-generated crises.

positions.statement: We cannot expect banks to self-regulate, and we therefore cannot expect the Fed to self-regulate to the extent that it is owned by banks.
positions.verbatim_quote: We cannot expect banks to self-regulate, and we therefore cannot expect the Fed to self-regulate to the extent that it is owned by banks.

positions.statement: In the United States, financial regulations have decentralized access to capital, keeping the economy going, while financial deregulation has hindered the economy by centralizing access to capital.
positions.verbatim_quote: In the United States, financial regulations have decentralized access to capital, keeping the economy going, while financial deregulation has hindered the economy by centralizing access to capital.

positions.statement: Even by the lights of a radical free marketeer, financial regulation has been a success because it has decentralized access to capital.
positions.verbatim_quote: Even by the lights of a radical free marketeer, financial regulation has been a success because it has decentralized access to capital.

positions.statement: The Sorites paradox can be solved while holding on to all the laws of classical logic, contrary to most attempts that reject the law of bivalence.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Sorites paradox can be solved while holding on to all the laws of classical logic, contrary to most attempts that reject the law of bivalence.

positions.statement: Given any predicate that generates a Sorites-paradox, significant use of that predicate is actually elliptical for a relational statement.
positions.verbatim_quote: Given any predicate that generates a Sorites-paradox, significant use of that predicate is actually elliptical for a relational statement.

positions.statement: A significant token of "Bob is poor" means "Bob is poor compared to x" for some value of x.
positions.verbatim_quote: A significant token of "Bob is poor" means "Bob is poor compared to x" for some value of x.

positions.statement: Once a value of x is supplied, a definite cutoff line between having and not having the paradox-generating predicate is supplied, which neutralizes the inductive step.
positions.verbatim_quote: Once a value of x is supplied, a definite cutoff line between having and not having the paradox-generating predicate is supplied, which neutralizes the inductive step.

positions.statement: Not all properties generate Sorites-type arguments; only properties that can be had to varying degrees generate them.
positions.verbatim_quote: Not all properties generate Sorites-type arguments; only properties that can be had to varying degrees generate them.

positions.statement: Binary properties—those that do not admit of comparatives—do not generate Sorites arguments.
positions.verbatim_quote: Binary properties—those that do not admit of comparatives—do not generate Sorites arguments.

positions.statement: Sorites-sentences are context-sensitive; the sentence "Bob is fast" makes a false statement if Bob is a cheetah with a top speed of 30 mph but a true statement if Bob is a turtle with a top speed of 2 mph.
positions.verbatim_quote: Sorites-sentences are context-sensitive; the sentence "Bob is fast" makes a false statement if Bob is a cheetah with a top speed of 30 mph but a true statement if Bob is a turtle with a top speed of 2 mph.

positions.statement: Bob cannot be wealthy simpliciter; he must be wealthy compared to some standard or class.
positions.verbatim_quote: Bob cannot be wealthy simpliciter; he must be wealthy compared to some standard or class.

positions.statement: Different tokens of "x is smart" involve comparison to different standards and thus express what are, strictly speaking, different propositions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Different tokens of "x is smart" involve comparison to different standards and thus express what are, strictly speaking, different propositions.

positions.statement: The term "tall" has the same meaning in "Bob is tall" as it has in "Bob is tall compared to Fred," and therefore "tall" is really elliptical for "tall compared to __."
positions.verbatim_quote: The term "tall" has the same meaning in "Bob is tall" as it has in "Bob is tall compared to Fred," and therefore "tall" is really elliptical for "tall compared to __."

positions.statement: The meaning of a predicate is intimately bound up with the number of argument places it has; predicates of different degrees ipso facto have different meanings.
positions.verbatim_quote: The meaning of a predicate is intimately bound up with the number of argument places it has; predicates of different degrees ipso facto have different meanings.

positions.statement: Being "absolutely non-wealthy" involves just as much reference to some standard of comparison as being "comparatively non-wealthy"—it means being non-wealthy relative to every standard.
positions.verbatim_quote: Being "absolutely non-wealthy" involves just as much reference to some standard of comparison as being "comparatively non-wealthy"—it means being non-wealthy relative to every standard.

positions.statement: Relativization to a standard is the essence of measurement; to measure is to compare with something taken as a standard.
positions.verbatim_quote: Relativization to a standard is the essence of measurement; to measure is to compare with something taken as a standard.

positions.statement: Degree-statements, even highly generic ones like "x is acidic to some positive degree," always presuppose some benchmark.
positions.verbatim_quote: Degree-statements, even highly generic ones like "x is acidic to some positive degree," always presuppose some benchmark.

positions.statement: Libet's experiment shows that the conscious events people believe to be their decisions are not the operative intentions—consciousness of intention follows rather than precedes the intention itself.
positions.verbatim_quote: Libet's experiment shows that the conscious events people believe to be their decisions are not the operative intentions—consciousness of intention follows rather than precedes the intention itself.

positions.statement: The readiness potential (RP) is obviously the proximal psychological cause of the action; therefore W (the conscious awareness) is not the intention but an awareness of the intention.
positions.verbatim_quote: The readiness potential (RP) is obviously the proximal psychological cause of the action; therefore W (the conscious awareness) is not the intention but an awareness of the intention.

positions.statement: By the time W happens, the RP is almost complete; if W is part of the intention, it is a subordinate part with at most a facilitating function.
positions.verbatim_quote: By the time W happens, the RP is almost complete; if W is part of the intention, it is a subordinate part with at most a facilitating function.

positions.statement: W is not a mere epiphenomenon because consciousness of one's intentions necessarily affects subsequent thought and behavior.
positions.verbatim_quote: W is not a mere epiphenomenon because consciousness of one's intentions necessarily affects subsequent thought and behavior.

positions.statement: The evidence suggests W is not a part of the operative intention but rather an awareness of it; W happens very late in the process.
positions.verbatim_quote: The evidence suggests W is not a part of the operative intention but rather an awareness of it; W happens very late in the process.

positions.statement: If W were the decision responsible for the finger-movement, the graph would inflect upwards after W, not fail to inflect or inflect negatively.
positions.verbatim_quote: If W were the decision responsible for the finger-movement, the graph would inflect upwards after W, not fail to inflect or inflect negatively.

positions.statement: W cannot possibly be an intention, let alone a decision, since such things are by their nature decisive causes, and W is not decisive.
positions.verbatim_quote: W cannot possibly be an intention, let alone a decision, since such things are by their nature decisive causes, and W is not decisive.

positions.statement: Libet's veto experiment provides evidence that W can at least put the brakes on an already-initiated action, even if it cannot initiate actions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Libet's veto experiment provides evidence that W can at least put the brakes on an already-initiated action, even if it cannot initiate actions.

positions.statement: Libet's experiment concerns a subset of actions—real-time sensory-motor engagements with one's environment—but these are actions where consciousness is presumably most heavily involved.
positions.verbatim_quote: Libet's experiment concerns a subset of actions—real-time sensory-motor engagements with one's environment—but these are actions where consciousness is presumably most heavily involved.

positions.statement: Standing intentions (enduring psychological structures like "my intention to create a trading platform") demonstrably cannot be constituents of consciousness; one can be conscious of them, but they are not themselves constituents of consciousness.
positions.verbatim_quote: Standing intentions (enduring psychological structures like "my intention to create a trading platform") demonstrably cannot be constituents of consciousness; one can be conscious of them, but they are not themselves constituents of consciousness.

positions.statement: Libet's experiment shows that we do not have "conscious free will"; our decisions, even those governing real-time responses to the environment, are not constituents of consciousness.
positions.verbatim_quote: Libet's experiment shows that we do not have "conscious free will"; our decisions, even those governing real-time responses to the environment, are not constituents of consciousness.

positions.statement: The .2 second delay between intention and awareness is very possibly not mere "tape-delay" but reflects W's function as an action-monitor rather than action-instigator.
positions.verbatim_quote: The .2 second delay between intention and awareness is very possibly not mere "tape-delay" but reflects W's function as an action-monitor rather than action-instigator.

positions.statement: Follow-up studies using fMRI show that relevant RPs began much earlier than Libet thought, sometimes preceding W by as much as 10 seconds.
positions.verbatim_quote: Follow-up studies using fMRI show that relevant RPs began much earlier than Libet thought, sometimes preceding W by as much as 10 seconds.

positions.statement: What we believe to be choices initiated in consciousness are not initiated in consciousness; they are initiated prior to any conscious awareness of them.
positions.verbatim_quote: What we believe to be choices initiated in consciousness are not initiated in consciousness; they are initiated prior to any conscious awareness of them.

positions.statement: It is unclear how Libet's results bear on "whether we have free will," but that is because the concept of free will is unclear, not because the experimental findings are unclear.
positions.verbatim_quote: It is unclear how Libet's results bear on "whether we have free will," but that is because the concept of free will is unclear, not because the experimental findings are unclear.

positions.statement: Philosophers have responded very conservatively and defensively to Libet's findings, doing more to obfuscate than to illuminate their significance.
positions.verbatim_quote: Philosophers have responded very conservatively and defensively to Libet's findings, doing more to obfuscate than to illuminate their significance.

positions.statement: Thoughts that totally lacked a causal basis in a person's pre-existing psychological structures would be mere intrusions, not exercises of agency.
positions.verbatim_quote: Thoughts that totally lacked a causal basis in a person's pre-existing psychological structures would be mere intrusions, not exercises of agency.

positions.statement: We only have freedom to the extent that the world, including ourselves, is deterministic.
positions.verbatim_quote: We only have freedom to the extent that the world, including ourselves, is deterministic.

positions.statement: Neuroscience does not merely show us how intentions and beliefs are physiologically implemented; it gives us counterintuitive information about them.
positions.verbatim_quote: Neuroscience does not merely show us how intentions and beliefs are physiologically implemented; it gives us counterintuitive information about them.

positions.statement: Libet's experimental data cannot be dismissed as margin-of-error; the subject established the time of W by coordinating it with a clock making one full rotation every 500 ms.
positions.verbatim_quote: Libet's experimental data cannot be dismissed as margin-of-error; the subject established the time of W by coordinating it with a clock making one full rotation every 500 ms.

positions.statement: The distinction between proximal and distal intentions is valid, but distal intentions are extremely unlikely to be more consciousness-based than proximal intentions.
positions.verbatim_quote: The distinction between proximal and distal intentions is valid, but distal intentions are extremely unlikely to be more consciousness-based than proximal intentions.

positions.statement: The actions studied in Libet's experiment are textbook cases of bona fide actions—non-automatic, non-reflexive, "freely made" actions—not quasi-reflexes.
