positions.verbatim_quote: The actions studied in Libet's experiment are textbook cases of bona fide actions—non-automatic, non-reflexive, "freely made" actions—not quasi-reflexes.

positions.statement: The RP obviously causes the finger-movement; either that or it is temporally coincident with whatever the cause is—either way, W is not the operative intention.
positions.verbatim_quote: The RP obviously causes the finger-movement; either that or it is temporally coincident with whatever the cause is—either way, W is not the operative intention.

positions.statement: The idea that we "just know" we have free will is straightforwardly question-begging; free will, if it exists, is a form of causation, and what causes what is always an open empirical question.
positions.verbatim_quote: The idea that we "just know" we have free will is straightforwardly question-begging; free will, if it exists, is a form of causation, and what causes what is always an open empirical question.

positions.statement: Compatibilism says you are free even though determined, but Libet's experiment shows not so much that you are determined as that you are on the sidelines—by the time you appear, the decision has been made.
positions.verbatim_quote: Compatibilism says you are free even though determined, but Libet's experiment shows not so much that you are determined as that you are on the sidelines—by the time you appear, the decision has been made.

positions.statement: What is ominous about the Libet Experiment is not that it shows your choices to be predetermined but that it shows them not to be yours—they are yours to behold but not to make.
positions.verbatim_quote: What is ominous about the Libet Experiment is not that it shows your choices to be predetermined but that it shows them not to be yours—they are yours to behold but not to make.

positions.statement: Libet's results are even more radical than Freud's: Freud regarded consciousness as a weak but genuine central authority; Libet shows it to be a mere spectator.
positions.verbatim_quote: Libet's results are even more radical than Freud's: Freud regarded consciousness as a weak but genuine central authority; Libet shows it to be a mere spectator.

positions.statement: All developed philosophical positions on human agency assume that the events we regard as our conscious choices are indeed our conscious choices; Libet's experiment shows this to be false.
positions.verbatim_quote: All developed philosophical positions on human agency assume that the events we regard as our conscious choices are indeed our conscious choices; Libet's experiment shows this to be false.

positions.statement: One purpose of consciousness may be to integrate information about the external world with information about the internal world.
positions.verbatim_quote: One purpose of consciousness may be to integrate information about the external world with information about the internal world.

positions.statement: W, though not the cause of a particular intention, may implicitly green-light future similar intentions—telling the relevant part of the mind to carry on apace.
positions.verbatim_quote: W, though not the cause of a particular intention, may implicitly green-light future similar intentions—telling the relevant part of the mind to carry on apace.

positions.statement: The "illusion of free choice"—experiencing decision-approval as decision-making—may be a small price to pay for gains in cognitive efficiency.
positions.verbatim_quote: The "illusion of free choice"—experiencing decision-approval as decision-making—may be a small price to pay for gains in cognitive efficiency.

positions.statement: Wilfred Sellars destroyed "the myth of the given" and began a revolution in epistemology, but Berkeley made essentially the same points two hundred years earlier.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wilfred Sellars destroyed "the myth of the given" and began a revolution in epistemology, but Berkeley made essentially the same points two hundred years earlier.

positions.statement: The foundationalist picture holds that no empirical background knowledge is needed to obtain knowledge of external reality—a given perception can do that on its own.
positions.verbatim_quote: The foundationalist picture holds that no empirical background knowledge is needed to obtain knowledge of external reality—a given perception can do that on its own.

positions.statement: Sellars is not denying that external realities are made known to us through sense-perceptions, but attacking the idea that perception does so without the cooperation of preexisting empirical knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: Sellars is not denying that external realities are made known to us through sense-perceptions, but attacking the idea that perception does so without the cooperation of preexisting empirical knowledge.

positions.statement: There are two senses in which knowledge is not "given": its existence presupposes a background of empirical knowledge, and the sensory experience considered apart from background knowledge does not constitute knowledge of anything.
positions.verbatim_quote: There are two senses in which knowledge is not "given": its existence presupposes a background of empirical knowledge, and the sensory experience considered apart from background knowledge does not constitute knowledge of anything.

positions.statement: The epistemic significance of a quale is not fixed or "given"; it is a variable function of background empirical knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: The epistemic significance of a quale is not fixed or "given"; it is a variable function of background empirical knowledge.

positions.statement: Berkeley's argument for anti-foundationalism is far more lucid and developed than Sellars' version.
positions.verbatim_quote: Berkeley's argument for anti-foundationalism is far more lucid and developed than Sellars' version.

positions.statement: What ultimately endows visual sensations with information regarding distances is that different kinds of visual sensations have different kinds of kinesthetic and tactile concomitants.
positions.verbatim_quote: What ultimately endows visual sensations with information regarding distances is that different kinds of visual sensations have different kinds of kinesthetic and tactile concomitants.

positions.statement: Your visual experience by itself doesn't apprise you of the size or distance of an object; what does that is your visual experience plus various pieces of background knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: Your visual experience by itself doesn't apprise you of the size or distance of an object; what does that is your visual experience plus various pieces of background knowledge.

positions.statement: One's visual experience, taken by itself and stripped of contextualization, doesn't tell one whether one is seeing a tree-size pencil a half-mile off or a tiny pencil nearby.
positions.verbatim_quote: One's visual experience, taken by itself and stripped of contextualization, doesn't tell one whether one is seeing a tree-size pencil a half-mile off or a tiny pencil nearby.

positions.statement: It is only "past experience" that teaches us that a particular appearance betokens a square object rather than a diamond-shaped one.
positions.verbatim_quote: It is only "past experience" that teaches us that a particular appearance betokens a square object rather than a diamond-shaped one.

positions.statement: Berkeley has a definite answer to Molyneux's question: a man born blind given sight would not know from visual perceptions alone whether he was seeing a round, oval, or square object.
positions.verbatim_quote: Berkeley has a definite answer to Molyneux's question: a man born blind given sight would not know from visual perceptions alone whether he was seeing a round, oval, or square object.

positions.statement: When you hear somebody talk, you feel as though you directly grasp their meaning, but your auditory experience apprises you of significance only with the help of background knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: When you hear somebody talk, you feel as though you directly grasp their meaning, but your auditory experience apprises you of significance only with the help of background knowledge.

positions.statement: Your visual experiences apprise you of the squareness of objects only in the sense in which your auditory perceptions apprise you of the meaning of a spoken sentence.
positions.verbatim_quote: Your visual experiences apprise you of the squareness of objects only in the sense in which your auditory perceptions apprise you of the meaning of a spoken sentence.

positions.statement: When a person's face reddens in a particular way indicating shame, your visual experience by itself doesn't apprise you of the shame; background knowledge of how emotions are given bodily expression is at work.
positions.verbatim_quote: When a person's face reddens in a particular way indicating shame, your visual experience by itself doesn't apprise you of the shame; background knowledge of how emotions are given bodily expression is at work.

positions.statement: No sensory experience by itself tells one anything; any such experience must be put in the context of background knowledge to bear any determinate message about the external world.
positions.verbatim_quote: No sensory experience by itself tells one anything; any such experience must be put in the context of background knowledge to bear any determinate message about the external world.

positions.statement: No sensory experience is foundational; empirical knowledge is obtained by putting current sensory experiences into the context of other sensory experiences and previously obtained empirical knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: No sensory experience is foundational; empirical knowledge is obtained by putting current sensory experiences into the context of other sensory experiences and previously obtained empirical knowledge.

positions.statement: Sellars only gives one example of how sensory experiences need background knowledge (perception of color under non-standard conditions), while Berkeley's argument directly applies to virtually every perceptible property under standard conditions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Sellars only gives one example of how sensory experiences need background knowledge (perception of color under non-standard conditions), while Berkeley's argument directly applies to virtually every perceptible property under standard conditions.

positions.statement: Sellars doesn't really explain how representational mental entities (perceptions) are forged out of non-representational mental entities (raw feels, qualia, sensations), but Berkeley goes to great lengths to show this.
positions.verbatim_quote: Sellars doesn't really explain how representational mental entities (perceptions) are forged out of non-representational mental entities (raw feels, qualia, sensations), but Berkeley goes to great lengths to show this.

positions.statement: Berkeley provides a non-metaphorical way of interpreting the metaphors that dominate contemporary anti-foundationalism (the "arc" or "web" of knowledge).
positions.verbatim_quote: Berkeley provides a non-metaphorical way of interpreting the metaphors that dominate contemporary anti-foundationalism (the "arc" or "web" of knowledge).

positions.statement: Two problems arise on Berkeley-Sellars anti-foundationalism: how any belief manages to be justified, and how anything representational arises out of what is not representational.
positions.verbatim_quote: Two problems arise on Berkeley-Sellars anti-foundationalism: how any belief manages to be justified, and how anything representational arises out of what is not representational.

positions.statement: The problem of how perceptions arise out of non-representational sensations is more fundamental than the problem of justification, because until we have perceptions, the problem of justification doesn't arise.
positions.verbatim_quote: The problem of how perceptions arise out of non-representational sensations is more fundamental than the problem of justification, because until we have perceptions, the problem of justification doesn't arise.

positions.statement: Standard conditions of perception are an idealization; no conditions are really standard—if we could set up a distortion-free situation, it would not be typical.
positions.verbatim_quote: Standard conditions of perception are an idealization; no conditions are really standard—if we could set up a distortion-free situation, it would not be typical.

positions.statement: What Sellars says about Bob's intake of color-facts in a tie-shop with unusual lighting is true of our intake of color-facts in general, and of shape-facts, size-facts, distance-facts, and so on.
positions.verbatim_quote: What Sellars says about Bob's intake of color-facts in a tie-shop with unusual lighting is true of our intake of color-facts in general, and of shape-facts, size-facts, distance-facts, and so on.

positions.statement: A ten-foot stop-sign looked at from a hundred feet away gives off the same appearance as a 1,000-foot stop-sign looked at from 10,000 feet away; one knows the approximate height only through background information.
positions.verbatim_quote: A ten-foot stop-sign looked at from a hundred feet away gives off the same appearance as a 1,000-foot stop-sign looked at from 10,000 feet away; one knows the approximate height only through background information.

positions.statement: In the absence of background empirical knowledge, our sensory episodes become indeterminate to the point of meaninglessness—to the point of having no representational content.
positions.verbatim_quote: In the absence of background empirical knowledge, our sensory episodes become indeterminate to the point of meaninglessness—to the point of having no representational content.

positions.statement: The appearance given off by a receding object is not different from the appearance given off by a shrinking object; contextual information (knowing that people don't shrink) disambiguates the visual experience.
positions.verbatim_quote: The appearance given off by a receding object is not different from the appearance given off by a shrinking object; contextual information (knowing that people don't shrink) disambiguates the visual experience.

positions.statement: The concept of "free will" is so unclear that difficulties in applying experimental findings to it reflect problems with the concept, not with the findings.
positions.verbatim_quote: The concept of "free will" is so unclear that difficulties in applying experimental findings to it reflect problems with the concept, not with the findings.

positions.statement: Philosophers seldom ask "What does the Libet experiment show?" but instead ask "What does the experiment show about free will?"—the second question concedes too much validity to assumptions that the experiment calls into question.
positions.verbatim_quote: Philosophers seldom ask "What does the Libet experiment show?" but instead ask "What does the experiment show about free will?"—the second question concedes too much validity to assumptions that the experiment calls into question.

positions.statement: Nothing is gained, and much is lost, by trying to press experimental results into the service of a pre-existing philosophical agenda.
positions.verbatim_quote: Nothing is gained, and much is lost, by trying to press experimental results into the service of a pre-existing philosophical agenda.

positions.statement: The position that pre-W brain activity is merely an "urge" that W converts into a genuine intention is question-begging; W does not have a decisive role in causing the finger-movement.
positions.verbatim_quote: The position that pre-W brain activity is merely an "urge" that W converts into a genuine intention is question-begging; W does not have a decisive role in causing the finger-movement.

positions.statement: If W happened at the very beginning or peak of the readiness potential slope, it could be a decision; but W happens far too late to launch the process and too early to transform it.
positions.verbatim_quote: If W happened at the very beginning or peak of the readiness potential slope, it could be a decision; but W happens far too late to launch the process and too early to transform it.

positions.statement: The comparison between knowledge of free will and the cogito is misconceived; the cogito registers an analytic truth whose negation is incoherent, but the assertion of free will is not trivial.
positions.verbatim_quote: The comparison between knowledge of free will and the cogito is misconceived; the cogito registers an analytic truth whose negation is incoherent, but the assertion of free will is not trivial.

positions.statement: Actions studied in Libet's experiment were set up to maximize the role of consciousness; the subject was wide awake, given explicit instructions, and could push the button whenever he wanted.
positions.verbatim_quote: Actions studied in Libet's experiment were set up to maximize the role of consciousness; the subject was wide awake, given explicit instructions, and could push the button whenever he wanted.

positions.statement: The more deliberation and "rational reflection" are involved in an action, the less likely the operative intention is to be fully conscious.
positions.verbatim_quote: The more deliberation and "rational reflection" are involved in an action, the less likely the operative intention is to be fully conscious.

positions.statement: Philosophers have done little beyond playing skeptic with Libet's data, using standards of proof by which there would be no reason to believe that smoking causes cancer.
positions.verbatim_quote: Philosophers have done little beyond playing skeptic with Libet's data, using standards of proof by which there would be no reason to believe that smoking causes cancer.

positions.statement: We stand to learn about the mind by investigating models consistent with Libet's data; we do not stand to learn by insisting that Libet "must" be wrong.
positions.verbatim_quote: We stand to learn about the mind by investigating models consistent with Libet's data; we do not stand to learn by insisting that Libet "must" be wrong.

positions.statement: Libet's experiment represents an extremely valuable but missed opportunity for philosophy.
positions.verbatim_quote: Libet's experiment represents an extremely valuable but missed opportunity for philosophy.

positions.statement: If it turns out that Libet's data is spurious, so be it; in the meantime, we should accept it and try to model it rather than reflexively dismissing it.
positions.verbatim_quote: If it turns out that Libet's data is spurious, so be it; in the meantime, we should accept it and try to model it rather than reflexively dismissing it.

positions.statement: The experiments in question do not merely support but establish that consciousness of intention follows rather than precedes the intention itself.
positions.verbatim_quote: The experiments in question do not merely support but establish that consciousness of intention follows rather than precedes the intention itself.

positions.statement: Consciousness may serve to approve or disapprove of decisions already made rather than to make decisions, with disapproval having a directive role for future intentions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Consciousness may serve to approve or disapprove of decisions already made rather than to make decisions, with disapproval having a directive role for future intentions.

positions.statement: There is no experimental data to support the claim that Libet's results only apply to "low-level" actions that fail to engage rationality or agency.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no experimental data to support the claim that Libet's results only apply to "low-level" actions that fail to engage rationality or agency.

positions.statement: Any episode of taking in information about the external world—any perception of height, speed, shape, or color—involves the cooperation of contextual or background information.KUCZYNSKI POSITION STATEMENT EMPIRICISM AND THE FOUNDATIONS OF PSYCHOLOGY
positions.verbatim_quote: Any episode of taking in information about the external world—any perception of height, speed, shape, or color—involves the cooperation of contextual or background information.KUCZYNSKI POSITION STATEMENT EMPIRICISM AND THE FOUNDATIONS OF PSYCHOLOGY

positions.statement: Empiricism is fundamentally incompatible with a scientific psychology.
positions.verbatim_quote: Empiricism is fundamentally incompatible with a scientific psychology.

positions.statement: There exists subpersonal thought that underlies conscious, preconscious, and repressed ideation.
positions.verbatim_quote: There exists subpersonal thought that underlies conscious, preconscious, and repressed ideation.

positions.statement: Subpersonal mentation is inherently intelligent, whereas personal/conscious mentation is inherently unintelligent.
positions.verbatim_quote: Subpersonal mentation is inherently intelligent, whereas personal/conscious mentation is inherently unintelligent.

positions.statement: Consciousness qua consciousness is capable only of iconic (pictorial) representation.
positions.verbatim_quote: Consciousness qua consciousness is capable only of iconic (pictorial) representation.

positions.statement: Concepts are not constituents of consciousness; they are access-conscious, not consciousness-constitutive.
positions.verbatim_quote: Concepts are not constituents of consciousness; they are access-conscious, not consciousness-constitutive.

positions.statement: Berkeley conflated images with concepts, using "idea" to refer to both.
positions.verbatim_quote: Berkeley conflated images with concepts, using "idea" to refer to both.

positions.statement: Symbol-manipulations facilitate ratiocinative operations, but anything one can think with symbols can be thought without them.
positions.verbatim_quote: Symbol-manipulations facilitate ratiocinative operations, but anything one can think with symbols can be thought without them.

positions.statement: The meaning of a complex expression cannot be directly determined by convention.
positions.verbatim_quote: The meaning of a complex expression cannot be directly determined by convention.

positions.statement: There is a fundamental distinction between object-awareness and truth-awareness (proposition-awareness).
positions.verbatim_quote: There is a fundamental distinction between object-awareness and truth-awareness (proposition-awareness).

positions.statement: Creatures can be merely object-aware (MOCs) or proposition-aware (PACs); all truth-aware creatures are object-aware, but not vice versa.
positions.verbatim_quote: Creatures can be merely object-aware (MOCs) or proposition-aware (PACs); all truth-aware creatures are object-aware, but not vice versa.

positions.statement: Desires are identical with judgments concerning what would bring pleasure or gratification.
positions.verbatim_quote: Desires are identical with judgments concerning what would bring pleasure or gratification.

positions.statement: Intentions are judgments, not desires.
positions.verbatim_quote: Intentions are judgments, not desires.

positions.statement: Davidson's identification of intentions with one's strongest desires is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Davidson's identification of intentions with one's strongest desires is false.

positions.statement: Higher-order desires as described by Frankfurt are often actually judgments, not desires.
positions.verbatim_quote: Higher-order desires as described by Frankfurt are often actually judgments, not desires.

positions.statement: Agency is identical with rationality—specifically, applied rationality deployed in accordance with one's values.
positions.verbatim_quote: Agency is identical with rationality—specifically, applied rationality deployed in accordance with one's values.

positions.statement: Rational agents are fundamentally different from mere reflex machines or reagents.
positions.verbatim_quote: Rational agents are fundamentally different from mere reflex machines or reagents.

positions.statement: The self is a rationality-constituted superstructure whose original purpose was to ensure the organism's survival but whose developed purpose is self-honing and expanding its powers.
positions.verbatim_quote: The self is a rationality-constituted superstructure whose original purpose was to ensure the organism's survival but whose developed purpose is self-honing and expanding its powers.

positions.statement: Physiological properties are multiply realizable with respect to microphysical properties.
positions.verbatim_quote: Physiological properties are multiply realizable with respect to microphysical properties.

positions.statement: The Deductive-Nomological (DN) model of scientific explanation is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Deductive-Nomological (DN) model of scientific explanation is false.

positions.statement: Psychological explanation works through rationalization, identifying causal mechanisms in rational motivations.
positions.verbatim_quote: Psychological explanation works through rationalization, identifying causal mechanisms in rational motivations.

positions.statement: A cause can be operative even if its effect was not guaranteed—causation can be probabilistic.
positions.verbatim_quote: A cause can be operative even if its effect was not guaranteed—causation can be probabilistic.

positions.statement: Laws need not be exceptionless regularities to have genuine explanatory value.
positions.verbatim_quote: Laws need not be exceptionless regularities to have genuine explanatory value.

positions.statement: Macro-level properties cannot be reduced to microphysical properties.
positions.verbatim_quote: Macro-level properties cannot be reduced to microphysical properties.

positions.statement: Perception requires conceptual articulation; it is not mere sensation but articulated sensation.
positions.verbatim_quote: Perception requires conceptual articulation; it is not mere sensation but articulated sensation.

positions.statement: Introspection is an act of conceptualization, not theoretically innocent reportage.
positions.verbatim_quote: Introspection is an act of conceptualization, not theoretically innocent reportage.

positions.statement: Husserl's phenomenological bracketing fails because one cannot strip perceptions of their conceptual articulations.
positions.verbatim_quote: Husserl's phenomenological bracketing fails because one cannot strip perceptions of their conceptual articulations.

positions.statement: The Dennett-Churchland eliminativist position on mind is untenable.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Dennett-Churchland eliminativist position on mind is untenable.

positions.statement: Perceptual data is as theory-laden as psychological data.
positions.verbatim_quote: Perceptual data is as theory-laden as psychological data.

positions.statement: Russell and other logicians were wrong that self-referential sentences are meaningless; such expressions are either false or sentence-schemata.
positions.verbatim_quote: Russell and other logicians were wrong that self-referential sentences are meaningless; such expressions are either false or sentence-schemata.

positions.statement: The unconscious mind exists and cannot be understood in strictly empiricist terms.
positions.verbatim_quote: The unconscious mind exists and cannot be understood in strictly empiricist terms.

positions.statement: Repression and rationalization are concepts inherently incompatible with empiricism.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repression and rationalization are concepts inherently incompatible with empiricism.

positions.statement: Psychosis involves partial cognitive regression where infantile and adult thought pathologically commingle.
positions.verbatim_quote: Psychosis involves partial cognitive regression where infantile and adult thought pathologically commingle.

positions.statement: Neurotic people perceive external reality accurately but are blind to their own feelings.
positions.verbatim_quote: Neurotic people perceive external reality accurately but are blind to their own feelings.

positions.statement: There is a crucial distinction between access-consciousness and consciousness-proper.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is a crucial distinction between access-consciousness and consciousness-proper.

positions.statement: Personal mentation becomes ratiocinative only when it becomes rule-governed through linguistic mediation.
positions.verbatim_quote: Personal mentation becomes ratiocinative only when it becomes rule-governed through linguistic mediation.

positions.statement: Music transfers subpersonal intelligence to the conscious level, making otherwise imperceptible thought-processes perceptible.
positions.verbatim_quote: Music transfers subpersonal intelligence to the conscious level, making otherwise imperceptible thought-processes perceptible.

positions.statement: Aesthetic beauty is relational—a property of relations between minds and sounds/objects, not intrinsic to sounds/objects themselves.
positions.verbatim_quote: Aesthetic beauty is relational—a property of relations between minds and sounds/objects, not intrinsic to sounds/objects themselves.

positions.statement: Sociopathy is psychological suicide: the destruction of one's value-based psychological architecture.
positions.verbatim_quote: Sociopathy is psychological suicide: the destruction of one's value-based psychological architecture.

positions.statement: One can change oneself but cannot change one's self; identity is predetermined, and experience determines only how one is who one is.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can change oneself but cannot change one's self; identity is predetermined, and experience determines only how one is who one is.

positions.statement: Pathological insecurity and pathological grandiosity are two sides of the same coin.
positions.verbatim_quote: Pathological insecurity and pathological grandiosity are two sides of the same coin.

positions.statement: Shame at being wrong is morbid and regressive, as making mistakes is inseparable from the human condition.
positions.verbatim_quote: Shame at being wrong is morbid and regressive, as making mistakes is inseparable from the human condition.

positions.statement: Folk-psychology enables rationalization of conscious states but has inherent limitations in explaining psychopathology.
positions.verbatim_quote: Folk-psychology enables rationalization of conscious states but has inherent limitations in explaining psychopathology.

positions.statement: Dreams involve relaxation of maturation-based inhibitions, liberating infantile mental content from the unconscious.
positions.verbatim_quote: Dreams involve relaxation of maturation-based inhibitions, liberating infantile mental content from the unconscious.

positions.statement: Propositional attitudes cannot be constituents of consciousness and are knowable only to the extent they are phenomenologized.
positions.verbatim_quote: Propositional attitudes cannot be constituents of consciousness and are knowable only to the extent they are phenomenologized.

positions.statement: It is viciously regressive to suppose that the self carries out the cognitive operations underlying sense-perception.
positions.verbatim_quote: It is viciously regressive to suppose that the self carries out the cognitive operations underlying sense-perception.

positions.statement: Science is not about sticking to facts but about organizing facts by positing hidden structures to restore continuities that observation strips away.
positions.verbatim_quote: Science is not about sticking to facts but about organizing facts by positing hidden structures to restore continuities that observation strips away.

positions.statement: The empiricist's injunction to "stick to the facts" is either a triviality or an absurdity.
positions.verbatim_quote: The empiricist's injunction to "stick to the facts" is either a triviality or an absurdity.

positions.statement: Perception cannot self-justify; justification for perception must come from non-empirical, analytic principles.
positions.verbatim_quote: Perception cannot self-justify; justification for perception must come from non-empirical, analytic principles.

positions.statement: Rationalizations are moralizations: attempts to make the immoral seem moral.
positions.verbatim_quote: Rationalizations are moralizations: attempts to make the immoral seem moral.

positions.statement: Sociopaths do not have friends because they do not have values, and a friend is somebody one values.
positions.verbatim_quote: Sociopaths do not have friends because they do not have values, and a friend is somebody one values.

positions.statement: Propositions are non-spatiotemporal entities that consist of properties.
positions.verbatim_quote: Propositions are non-spatiotemporal entities that consist of properties.

positions.statement: Properties are non-spatiotemporal; they cannot be identified with spatiotemporal entities.
positions.verbatim_quote: Properties are non-spatiotemporal; they cannot be identified with spatiotemporal entities.

positions.statement: The relata of logical relations are propositions, not sentences.
positions.verbatim_quote: The relata of logical relations are propositions, not sentences.

positions.statement: Logical relations (entailment, confirmation, disconfirmation, incompatibility, neutrality) hold among propositions, not among spatiotemporal entities.
positions.verbatim_quote: Logical relations (entailment, confirmation, disconfirmation, incompatibility, neutrality) hold among propositions, not among spatiotemporal entities.

positions.statement: Empiricists must deny the existence of propositions because propositions are non-spatiotemporal.
positions.verbatim_quote: Empiricists must deny the existence of propositions because propositions are non-spatiotemporal.

positions.statement: Psychological propositions do not present facts as being in the same spatial coordinate system as physical propositions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Psychological propositions do not present facts as being in the same spatial coordinate system as physical propositions.

positions.statement: The relationship between psychology and physiology is even more remote than the relationship between physiology and microphysics.
positions.verbatim_quote: The relationship between psychology and physiology is even more remote than the relationship between physiology and microphysics.

positions.statement: Hume's skepticism about perception and induction follows correctly from empiricism, which should lead us to reject empiricism rather than accept skepticism.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume's skepticism about perception and induction follows correctly from empiricism, which should lead us to reject empiricism rather than accept skepticism.

positions.statement: Scientific thought is not the same as empirical thought; to the extent thought mediates between observations and beliefs, beliefs are not directly supported by observation.
positions.verbatim_quote: Scientific thought is not the same as empirical thought; to the extent thought mediates between observations and beliefs, beliefs are not directly supported by observation.

positions.statement: Hume's analysis of causation as mere constant conjunction is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume's analysis of causation as mere constant conjunction is false.

positions.statement: We perceive instances of causation directly when we perceive instances of persistence and occupancy.
positions.verbatim_quote: We perceive instances of causation directly when we perceive instances of persistence and occupancy.

positions.statement: Any instance of persistence or occupancy is an instance of causation.
positions.verbatim_quote: Any instance of persistence or occupancy is an instance of causation.

positions.statement: A Hume-world (a world with the same events but no causation) is incoherent because persistence itself requires causal ties.
positions.verbatim_quote: A Hume-world (a world with the same events but no causation) is incoherent because persistence itself requires causal ties.

positions.statement: Space-time position is constituted by causal relations; there is no non-relational way of understanding space-time position.
positions.verbatim_quote: Space-time position is constituted by causal relations; there is no non-relational way of understanding space-time position.

positions.statement: Events are not constituents of the external world but nominalizations of truths.
positions.verbatim_quote: Events are not constituents of the external world but nominalizations of truths.

positions.statement: Facts and truths are distinct; truths hold in virtue of facts but are not identical with facts.
positions.verbatim_quote: Facts and truths are distinct; truths hold in virtue of facts but are not identical with facts.

positions.statement: The distinction between explanatory generalizations of different disciplines lies in the concepts composing them, not in the underlying reality.
positions.verbatim_quote: The distinction between explanatory generalizations of different disciplines lies in the concepts composing them, not in the underlying reality.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein's private language argument fails because the lone speaker of a private language is in no different epistemic position than the English speaker relying on memory.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wittgenstein's private language argument fails because the lone speaker of a private language is in no different epistemic position than the English speaker relying on memory.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein is a hard-core empiricist whose rejection of non-spatiotemporal entities like propositions and concepts follows from his empiricism.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wittgenstein is a hard-core empiricist whose rejection of non-spatiotemporal entities like propositions and concepts follows from his empiricism.

positions.statement: Groups of zombies cannot collectively think; if every member of a group is a zombie, the group itself is without consciousness.
positions.verbatim_quote: Groups of zombies cannot collectively think; if every member of a group is a zombie, the group itself is without consciousness.

positions.statement: The Argument from Analogy for other minds is valid, contrary to Wittgenstein's objections.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Argument from Analogy for other minds is valid, contrary to Wittgenstein's objections.

positions.statement: Quine's thesis of the indeterminacy of translation is a desperate measure resulting from his empiricist commitments.
positions.verbatim_quote: Quine's thesis of the indeterminacy of translation is a desperate measure resulting from his empiricist commitments.

positions.statement: Translation between languages requires reliance on introspection-based knowledge of one's own mental states.
positions.verbatim_quote: Translation between languages requires reliance on introspection-based knowledge of one's own mental states.

positions.statement: Thinking is not a psychological process in Wittgenstein's sense; propositional attitudes are not constituents of consciousness.
positions.verbatim_quote: Thinking is not a psychological process in Wittgenstein's sense; propositional attitudes are not constituents of consciousness.

positions.statement: Mental imagery can be thought-constitutive, contrary to Wittgenstein's view, when understood in relation to its ratiocinative context.
positions.verbatim_quote: Mental imagery can be thought-constitutive, contrary to Wittgenstein's view, when understood in relation to its ratiocinative context.

positions.statement: The deployment of propositional attitudes in problem-solving is not constitutive of consciousness; consciousness is to thinking what a driver is to events under the car's hood.
positions.verbatim_quote: The deployment of propositional attitudes in problem-solving is not constitutive of consciousness; consciousness is to thinking what a driver is to events under the car's hood.

positions.statement: Dispositionalism about mental states fails to model the data; mental states must be functioning as such even between bouts of generating consciousness.
positions.verbatim_quote: Dispositionalism about mental states fails to model the data; mental states must be functioning as such even between bouts of generating consciousness.

positions.statement: Your belief that 1+1=2 is not identical with your dispositions to make certain judgments; it must be actively functioning to explain those dispositions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Your belief that 1+1=2 is not identical with your dispositions to make certain judgments; it must be actively functioning to explain those dispositions.

positions.statement: Searle's view that mentality is identical with consciousness (MC) is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Searle's view that mentality is identical with consciousness (MC) is false.

positions.statement: Propositional attitudes are not and cannot be constituents of consciousness; they are access-conscious at most.
positions.verbatim_quote: Propositional attitudes are not and cannot be constituents of consciousness; they are access-conscious at most.

positions.statement: Having meta-cognitive wherewithal is required to know what one's propositional attitudes are.
positions.verbatim_quote: Having meta-cognitive wherewithal is required to know what one's propositional attitudes are.

positions.statement: Russell's paradox does not establish that there are meaningful sentences that are neither true nor false; the relevant expressions are either false or sentence-schemata.
positions.verbatim_quote: Russell's paradox does not establish that there are meaningful sentences that are neither true nor false; the relevant expressions are either false or sentence-schemata.

positions.statement: The expression "the property of being the set of all sets that aren't members of themselves" picks nothing out.
positions.verbatim_quote: The expression "the property of being the set of all sets that aren't members of themselves" picks nothing out.

positions.statement: Tarski's and Russell's type-theory response to the semantic paradoxes is self-defeating.
positions.verbatim_quote: Tarski's and Russell's type-theory response to the semantic paradoxes is self-defeating.

positions.statement: Anaphoric expressions like "itself" function as bound variables and can be eliminable in extensional contexts.
positions.verbatim_quote: Anaphoric expressions like "itself" function as bound variables and can be eliminable in extensional contexts.

positions.statement: Mach was wrong to hold that molecules are useful fictions; Einstein showed their existence is required to explain Brownian motion.
positions.verbatim_quote: Mach was wrong to hold that molecules are useful fictions; Einstein showed their existence is required to explain Brownian motion.

positions.statement: Newton's public claims to be purely empirical likely misrepresented his actual methodology for rhetorical reasons.
positions.verbatim_quote: Newton's public claims to be purely empirical likely misrepresented his actual methodology for rhetorical reasons.

positions.statement: Every person is to some degree a schizoid-affective psychopath (SAP); differences between the mentally ill and healthy are matters of degree.
positions.verbatim_quote: Every person is to some degree a schizoid-affective psychopath (SAP); differences between the mentally ill and healthy are matters of degree.

positions.statement: To outgrow a belief or desire is not to cease to have it but for it to cease to be operational.
positions.verbatim_quote: To outgrow a belief or desire is not to cease to have it but for it to cease to be operational.

positions.statement: People are organized, non-heaps of thought; thoughts are organized both vertically (hierarchically) and horizontally (laterally).
positions.verbatim_quote: People are organized, non-heaps of thought; thoughts are organized both vertically (hierarchically) and horizontally (laterally).

positions.statement: The mind of the psychologically healthy person is stratified; psychopathology manifests when this stratification breaks down.
positions.verbatim_quote: The mind of the psychologically healthy person is stratified; psychopathology manifests when this stratification breaks down.

positions.statement: A delusion is not a wrong belief but a belief that is right in the wrong way—the vehicle for a correct belief is an infantile and therefore false belief.
positions.verbatim_quote: A delusion is not a wrong belief but a belief that is right in the wrong way—the vehicle for a correct belief is an infantile and therefore false belief.

positions.statement: Pleasant affects alert us to the presence of certain structural features in music, art, and architecture; unpleasant affects alert us to their absence.
positions.verbatim_quote: Pleasant affects alert us to the presence of certain structural features in music, art, and architecture; unpleasant affects alert us to their absence.

positions.statement: Phenomenologically consecutive mental images are likely to be ratiocinatively disjoint when considered in isolation from their underlying thought-processes.
positions.verbatim_quote: Phenomenologically consecutive mental images are likely to be ratiocinatively disjoint when considered in isolation from their underlying thought-processes.

positions.statement: The survival instinct is transferred from one's body to one's self as psychological development proceeds.
positions.verbatim_quote: The survival instinct is transferred from one's body to one's self as psychological development proceeds.

positions.statement: Initially the psychological superstructure exists to keep the body alive; eventually the body exists to keep the superstructure (self) alive.
positions.verbatim_quote: Initially the psychological superstructure exists to keep the body alive; eventually the body exists to keep the superstructure (self) alive.

positions.statement: To value something is to see it as conducive to the consolidation or enlargement of one's agency.
positions.verbatim_quote: To value something is to see it as conducive to the consolidation or enlargement of one's agency.

positions.statement: Hedonistic pleasure is value-free pleasure; accomplishment-based pleasure is not hedonistic.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hedonistic pleasure is value-free pleasure; accomplishment-based pleasure is not hedonistic.

positions.statement: The object of desire is gratification, but intentions do not aim at gratification—they are judgments about what one must do to have a life embodying certain values.
positions.verbatim_quote: The object of desire is gratification, but intentions do not aim at gratification—they are judgments about what one must do to have a life embodying certain values.

positions.statement: Athletic ability is cognitive, not somatic in nature; being coordinated consists in one's mind being intelligent in governing one's body.
positions.verbatim_quote: Athletic ability is cognitive, not somatic in nature; being coordinated consists in one's mind being intelligent in governing one's body.

positions.statement: Moral nihilism and aesthetic nihilism are both false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Moral nihilism and aesthetic nihilism are both false.

positions.statement: Moral nihilism and moral relativism are equivalent doctrines.
positions.verbatim_quote: Moral nihilism and moral relativism are equivalent doctrines.

positions.statement: The Moore-Hume thesis that you cannot derive an "ought" from an "is" is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Moore-Hume thesis that you cannot derive an "ought" from an "is" is false.

positions.statement: Moral truths hold in virtue of the same facts as descriptive truths; we can experience facts either as morally antiseptic or as moral truths.
positions.verbatim_quote: Moral truths hold in virtue of the same facts as descriptive truths; we can experience facts either as morally antiseptic or as moral truths.

positions.statement: Morally good acts invariably conduce to psychological, biological, or psychobiological welfare.
positions.verbatim_quote: Morally good acts invariably conduce to psychological, biological, or psychobiological welfare.

positions.statement: Emotions are beliefs, though they are not discursive beliefs; they are fundamentally egocentric in nature.
positions.verbatim_quote: Emotions are beliefs, though they are not discursive beliefs; they are fundamentally egocentric in nature.

positions.statement: Hume's emotivism—the view that moral ideation is non-judicative sentiment—is wrong.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume's emotivism—the view that moral ideation is non-judicative sentiment—is wrong.

positions.statement: There is no moral difference without a descriptive difference; the moral supervenes on the descriptive.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no moral difference without a descriptive difference; the moral supervenes on the descriptive.

positions.statement: Moral intuitions track biological facts about welfare and harm.
positions.verbatim_quote: Moral intuitions track biological facts about welfare and harm.

positions.statement: One's personhood depends on having values (norms, though not necessarily moral norms).
positions.verbatim_quote: One's personhood depends on having values (norms, though not necessarily moral norms).

positions.statement: Psychopathy is a failure to distinguish consequence of excessive rationalization; it involves a collapse of the distinction between self and other.
positions.verbatim_quote: Psychopathy is a failure to distinguish consequence of excessive rationalization; it involves a collapse of the distinction between self and other.

positions.statement: The acceptance of empiricism is incompatible with the very existence of any attempt to study anything.
positions.verbatim_quote: The acceptance of empiricism is incompatible with the very existence of any attempt to study anything.

positions.statement: If empiricism is correct, nothing or next to nothing can be known about either the external or internal world.
positions.verbatim_quote: If empiricism is correct, nothing or next to nothing can be known about either the external or internal world.

positions.statement: Empiricism leaves the mental as nothing but a series of disjoint ex nihilo obtrusions into an otherwise integrated world.
positions.verbatim_quote: Empiricism leaves the mental as nothing but a series of disjoint ex nihilo obtrusions into an otherwise integrated world.

positions.statement: Paraperception is phenomenology-mediated, real-time conception—the mode by which we perceive language, music, and art.
positions.verbatim_quote: Paraperception is phenomenology-mediated, real-time conception—the mode by which we perceive language, music, and art.

positions.statement: Categories like rock, tree, and chair are individuated by the counterfactual properties of their instances.
positions.verbatim_quote: Categories like rock, tree, and chair are individuated by the counterfactual properties of their instances.

positions.statement: To be a copper bar is to have certain causal properties (conductivity, durability, malleability).
positions.verbatim_quote: To be a copper bar is to have certain causal properties (conductivity, durability, malleability).

positions.statement: One's survival instinct comes to be transferred from one's body to one's self.
positions.verbatim_quote: One's survival instinct comes to be transferred from one's body to one's self.

positions.statement: Animals are reflex machines; rational agents are not.
positions.verbatim_quote: Animals are reflex machines; rational agents are not.

positions.statement: Something that merely reacts is sub-agential; we may call such things "reagents."
positions.verbatim_quote: Something that merely reacts is sub-agential; we may call such things "reagents."

positions.statement: Only proposition-aware creatures can have intentions, because intentions are identical with decisions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Only proposition-aware creatures can have intentions, because intentions are identical with decisions.

positions.statement: Deliberation is nothing other than arriving at a decision.
positions.verbatim_quote: Deliberation is nothing other than arriving at a decision.

positions.statement: When an intention is not preceded by deliberation, relevant deliberations have already occurred in the past.
positions.verbatim_quote: When an intention is not preceded by deliberation, relevant deliberations have already occurred in the past.

positions.statement: Aristotle and Kant were right that agency is practical rationality and decisions are conclusions of non-theoretical thought-processes.
positions.verbatim_quote: Aristotle and Kant were right that agency is practical rationality and decisions are conclusions of non-theoretical thought-processes.

positions.statement: There is no intrinsic difference between practical rationality (agency) and theoretical rationality.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no intrinsic difference between practical rationality (agency) and theoretical rationality.

positions.statement: Practical ratiocinations are more likely to be corrupted by prejudices and emotional factors than theoretical ones.
positions.verbatim_quote: Practical ratiocinations are more likely to be corrupted by prejudices and emotional factors than theoretical ones.

positions.statement: Phenomenology can represent a given thing only by resembling it.
positions.verbatim_quote: Phenomenology can represent a given thing only by resembling it.

positions.statement: Dogs are not irrational but sub-rational; irrationality is corrupted rationality and is thus a prerogative of rational beings.
positions.verbatim_quote: Dogs are not irrational but sub-rational; irrationality is corrupted rationality and is thus a prerogative of rational beings.

positions.statement: Dogs' being sub-rational consists in their minds being incapable of personal thought, not thought tout court.
positions.verbatim_quote: Dogs' being sub-rational consists in their minds being incapable of personal thought, not thought tout court.

positions.statement: For ideation to be transferred from the subpersonal to the personal domain, it must be phenomenologized.
positions.verbatim_quote: For ideation to be transferred from the subpersonal to the personal domain, it must be phenomenologized.

positions.statement: The consciousness of music is the delight we take in acquiring knowledge; it is a form of our survival instinct applied to self-expansion.
positions.verbatim_quote: The consciousness of music is the delight we take in acquiring knowledge; it is a form of our survival instinct applied to self-expansion.

positions.statement: Personal mentation becomes ratiocinative only when governed by meta-customs that convert customs into rules.
positions.verbatim_quote: Personal mentation becomes ratiocinative only when governed by meta-customs that convert customs into rules.

positions.statement: Repressed propositional attitudes are not intrinsically different from unrepressed ones; they differ only in location within the mind.
positions.verbatim_quote: Repressed propositional attitudes are not intrinsically different from unrepressed ones; they differ only in location within the mind.

positions.statement: The conscious knowledge described by Chomsky and Marr is a conceptualization of subpersonal knowledge, not a duplicate.
positions.verbatim_quote: The conscious knowledge described by Chomsky and Marr is a conceptualization of subpersonal knowledge, not a duplicate.

positions.statement: Subpersonal processes are not strictly physiological or purely reflexive, contrary to Searle.
positions.verbatim_quote: Subpersonal processes are not strictly physiological or purely reflexive, contrary to Searle.

positions.statement: Understanding a sentence requires implicit knowledge of extremely complex semantic rules that operate too quickly for conscious, discursive application.
positions.verbatim_quote: Understanding a sentence requires implicit knowledge of extremely complex semantic rules that operate too quickly for conscious, discursive application.

positions.statement: Linguistic competence involves subpersonal mastery of rules that are not access-conscious.
positions.verbatim_quote: Linguistic competence involves subpersonal mastery of rules that are not access-conscious.

positions.statement: There is no physiological characterization of linguistic competence; the rules are inherently semantic, not physiological.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no physiological characterization of linguistic competence; the rules are inherently semantic, not physiological.

positions.statement: Given obvious facts and principles, Chomsky's position that there is subpersonal mentation is de rigueur.
positions.verbatim_quote: Given obvious facts and principles, Chomsky's position that there is subpersonal mentation is de rigueur.

positions.statement: Hume's introspections were contaminated with non-empirical ideation.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume's introspections were contaminated with non-empirical ideation.

positions.statement: Goodman's "grue" paradox shows that any body of data can provide support for incompatible hypotheses without constraints beyond empirical observation.
positions.verbatim_quote: Goodman's "grue" paradox shows that any body of data can provide support for incompatible hypotheses without constraints beyond empirical observation.

positions.statement: There is a transcendental argument for causation: without causal ties, the genidentity of one's mind across time would be unintelligible.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is a transcendental argument for causation: without causal ties, the genidentity of one's mind across time would be unintelligible.

positions.statement: The concept of complying with laws must be distinguished from the concept of being governed by them.
positions.verbatim_quote: The concept of complying with laws must be distinguished from the concept of being governed by them.

positions.statement: Everything complies with microphysical laws, but macro-level events are governed by macro-level laws implemented by varying microphysical mechanisms.
positions.verbatim_quote: Everything complies with microphysical laws, but macro-level events are governed by macro-level laws implemented by varying microphysical mechanisms.

positions.statement: Smoking causes cancer even though less than 30% of smokers get lung cancer; causes need not operate with 100% efficacy.
positions.verbatim_quote: Smoking causes cancer even though less than 30% of smokers get lung cancer; causes need not operate with 100% efficacy.

positions.statement: Salmon's probabilistic modification of the DN model (DN*) is no better than DN itself.
positions.verbatim_quote: Salmon's probabilistic modification of the DN model (DN*) is no better than DN itself.

positions.statement: Explanation can be valid even when the explanandum was less than 50% likely given the explanans.
positions.verbatim_quote: Explanation can be valid even when the explanandum was less than 50% likely given the explanans.

positions.statement: The psychoanalyst's goal is to implant conscious duplicates of repressed beliefs, which are qualitatively identical with their repressed counterparts.
positions.verbatim_quote: The psychoanalyst's goal is to implant conscious duplicates of repressed beliefs, which are qualitatively identical with their repressed counterparts.

positions.statement: VIEW: It is widely held that one can sometimes rationally accept propositions of the form P and not-P.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: It is widely held that one can sometimes rationally accept propositions of the form P and not-P.

positions.statement: VIEW: There are necessary a posteriori truths.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: There are necessary a posteriori truths.

positions.statement: VIEW: Kripke's arguments for these views appear probative only so long as one fails to distinguish between semantics and presemantics.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Kripke's arguments for these views appear probative only so long as one fails to distinguish between semantics and presemantics.

positions.statement: VIEW: The distinction between semantics and presemantics is between the literal meanings of sentences and the information on the basis of which one identifies those literal meanings.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The distinction between semantics and presemantics is between the literal meanings of sentences and the information on the basis of which one identifies those literal meanings.

positions.statement: VIEW: The failure to distinguish between semantics and presemantics underlies the popular thesis that intersubstituting co-referring terms sometimes turns true sentences into false ones and vice versa.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The failure to distinguish between semantics and presemantics underlies the popular thesis that intersubstituting co-referring terms sometimes turns true sentences into false ones and vice versa.

positions.statement: VIEW: The thesis that intersubstituting co-referring terms sometimes changes truth values has counterintuitive consequences.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The thesis that intersubstituting co-referring terms sometimes changes truth values has counterintuitive consequences.

positions.statement: VIEW: One counterintuitive consequence of the thesis is that the occurrence of 'snow' in 'it is true that snow is white' doesn't refer to snow.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: One counterintuitive consequence of the thesis is that the occurrence of 'snow' in 'it is true that snow is white' doesn't refer to snow.

positions.statement: VIEW: Understanding the distinction between semantics and presemantics suggests a way to develop a semantic system without the counterintuitive consequences.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Understanding the distinction between semantics and presemantics suggests a way to develop a semantic system without the counterintuitive consequences.

positions.statement: VIEW: The semantic system suggested can reconcile our intuitions concerning cognitive content with some powerfully argued theses of contemporary philosophy of language.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The semantic system suggested can reconcile our intuitions concerning cognitive content with some powerfully argued theses of contemporary philosophy of language.

positions.statement: VIEW: Some of the paper's main contentions are anticipated by Andrzej Boguslawski in his 1994 paper 'Sentential Complementation and Truth.'
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Some of the paper's main contentions are anticipated by Andrzej Boguslawski in his 1994 paper 'Sentential Complementation and Truth.'

positions.statement: VIEW: In at least some contexts, replacing a referring term with a co-referring term preserves truth-value.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: In at least some contexts, replacing a referring term with a co-referring term preserves truth-value.

positions.statement: VIEW: The sentence 'Hesperus is closer to the Sun than the Earth' is true.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The sentence 'Hesperus is closer to the Sun than the Earth' is true.

positions.statement: VIEW: 'Phosphorous' and 'Hesperus' refer to the same thing.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: 'Phosphorous' and 'Hesperus' refer to the same thing.

positions.statement: VIEW: The sentence 'Phosphorous is closer to the Sun than the Earth' is also true.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The sentence 'Phosphorous is closer to the Sun than the Earth' is also true.

positions.statement: VIEW: If a context tolerates intersubstitutions of co-referring terms, that context is 'extensional.'
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: If a context tolerates intersubstitutions of co-referring terms, that context is 'extensional.'

positions.statement: VIEW: If an expression occurs in an extensional context, it occurs 'extensionally.'
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: If an expression occurs in an extensional context, it occurs 'extensionally.'

positions.statement: VIEW: There seem to be cases where replacing a referring term with a co-referring term leads from truth to falsehood or vice versa.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: There seem to be cases where replacing a referring term with a co-referring term leads from truth to falsehood or vice versa.

positions.statement: VIEW: Not all contexts are extensional.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Not all contexts are extensional.

positions.statement: VIEW: If a context is not extensional, it is 'intensional' and the expressions occurring in it do so 'intensionally.'
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: If a context is not extensional, it is 'intensional' and the expressions occurring in it do so 'intensionally.'

positions.statement: VIEW: All contexts are extensional.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: All contexts are extensional.

positions.statement: VIEW: The truth of 'I am tired' applies to all sentence-types with indexical or context-sensitive components.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The truth of 'I am tired' applies to all sentence-types with indexical or context-sensitive components.

positions.statement: VIEW: Most, if not all, sentence-types of natural language contain tense-markers.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Most, if not all, sentence-types of natural language contain tense-markers.

positions.statement: VIEW: The identity of the proposition meant by a token of a sentence-type with a tense-marker depends on the time of production.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The identity of the proposition meant by a token of a sentence-type with a tense-marker depends on the time of production.

positions.statement: VIEW: Kaplan and Soames elaborate and defend the view that sentence-types with tense-markers depend on the time of production for their meaning.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Kaplan and Soames elaborate and defend the view that sentence-types with tense-markers depend on the time of production for their meaning.

positions.statement: VIEW: The function meant by a sentence-type can fail to assign a proposition to a particular token.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The function meant by a sentence-type can fail to assign a proposition to a particular token.

positions.statement: VIEW: An utterance about a non-existent pink elephant fails to encode a proposition.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: An utterance about a non-existent pink elephant fails to encode a proposition.

positions.statement: VIEW: Strawson, Kaplan, Salmon, Soames, and others, including the author, believe that sentence-tokens typically have propositions for their literal meanings.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Strawson, Kaplan, Salmon, Soames, and others, including the author, believe that sentence-tokens typically have propositions for their literal meanings.

positions.statement: VIEW: Some philosophers deny that sentence-tokens typically have truth-evaluable entities for their literal meanings.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Some philosophers deny that sentence-tokens typically have truth-evaluable entities for their literal meanings.

positions.statement: VIEW: Even after setting aside cases of presupposition-failure, sentence-tokens do not have truth-evaluable entities for their meanings according to some philosophers.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Even after setting aside cases of presupposition-failure, sentence-tokens do not have truth-evaluable entities for their meanings according to some philosophers.

positions.statement: VIEW: Contextualists believe that sentence-tokens typically communicate propositions but require contextual facts to fill in semantic gaps.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Contextualists believe that sentence-tokens typically communicate propositions but require contextual facts to fill in semantic gaps.

positions.statement: VIEW: Recanati and Travis are proponents of contextualism or radical pragmatics.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Recanati and Travis are proponents of contextualism or radical pragmatics.

positions.statement: VIEW: The meaning of 'Charles is ready' depends on knowing what Charles is ready for.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The meaning of 'Charles is ready' depends on knowing what Charles is ready for.

positions.statement: VIEW: The literal meaning of 'that is red' leaves open what has been affirmed about the object's redness.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The literal meaning of 'that is red' leaves open what has been affirmed about the object's redness.

positions.statement: VIEW: The standard of redness intended can vary based on the context, affecting the truth of the statement 'that is red'.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The standard of redness intended can vary based on the context, affecting the truth of the statement 'that is red'.

positions.statement: VIEW: Contextualism holds that these points about the need for context apply to all sentence-tokens, with few exceptions.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Contextualism holds that these points about the need for context apply to all sentence-tokens, with few exceptions.

positions.statement: VIEW: Cappelen and Lepore provide a thorough discussion of contextualism.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Cappelen and Lepore provide a thorough discussion of contextualism.

positions.statement: VIEW: Pinker provides a brief but effective discussion of contextualism.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Pinker provides a brief but effective discussion of contextualism.

positions.statement: VIEW: Russell's Theory of Descriptions states that a sentence with the form 'the phi' has a meaning that is a quantified generalization.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Russell's Theory of Descriptions states that a sentence with the form 'the phi' has a meaning that is a quantified generalization.

positions.statement: VIEW: According to Russell's Theory of Descriptions, 'the king of France is bald' means a quantified generalization about the king of France being bald.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: According to Russell's Theory of Descriptions, 'the king of France is bald' means a quantified generalization about the king of France being bald.

positions.statement: VIEW: If Russell's Theory of Descriptions is correct, 'the king of France' is not a referring term but a quantifier.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: If Russell's Theory of Descriptions is correct, 'the king of France' is not a referring term but a quantifier.

positions.statement: VIEW: The conception of meaning advocated by Quine, Davidson, Dummett, Chomsky, Kaplan, and Soames is not confined to one tradition.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The conception of meaning advocated by Quine, Davidson, Dummett, Chomsky, Kaplan, and Soames is not confined to one tradition.

positions.statement: VIEW: Cappelen and Lepore have made a strong case against contextualism.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Cappelen and Lepore have made a strong case against contextualism.

positions.statement: VIEW: Pinker has also made a strong case against contextualism.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Pinker has also made a strong case against contextualism.

positions.statement: VIEW: One can hold that sentence-tokens as a rule do have truth-evaluable entities for their literal meanings without being guilty of sheer dogmatism.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: One can hold that sentence-tokens as a rule do have truth-evaluable entities for their literal meanings without being guilty of sheer dogmatism.

positions.statement: VIEW: Searle does not deny that many sentence-tokens typically have complete propositions for their literal meanings.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Searle does not deny that many sentence-tokens typically have complete propositions for their literal meanings.

positions.statement: VIEW: Searle denies the view that for every sentence the literal meaning can be construed as the meaning it has independently of any context.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Searle denies the view that for every sentence the literal meaning can be construed as the meaning it has independently of any context.

positions.statement: VIEW: Searle holds that the notion of literal meaning only has application relative to a set of contextual or background assumptions.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Searle holds that the notion of literal meaning only has application relative to a set of contextual or background assumptions.

positions.statement: VIEW: Some tokens of 'the cat is on the mat' do have truth-evaluable entities for their literal meanings, while others do not.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Some tokens of 'the cat is on the mat' do have truth-evaluable entities for their literal meanings, while others do not.

positions.statement: VIEW: An utterance of 'the cat is on the mat' made in somebody's living room will probably have a determinately true or false proposition for its meaning.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: An utterance of 'the cat is on the mat' made in somebody's living room will probably have a determinately true or false proposition for its meaning.

positions.statement: VIEW: The same utterance of 'the cat is on the mat' made in outer space may not have a determinately true or false proposition for its meaning.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The same utterance of 'the cat is on the mat' made in outer space may not have a determinately true or false proposition for its meaning.

positions.statement: VIEW: Searle's point is that sentence-tokens have truth-evaluable literal meanings only relative to certain background assumptions.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Searle's point is that sentence-tokens have truth-evaluable literal meanings only relative to certain background assumptions.

positions.statement: VIEW: Searle is not denying that sentences have literal meanings, but that literal meaning is relative to background assumptions.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Searle is not denying that sentences have literal meanings, but that literal meaning is relative to background assumptions.

positions.statement: VIEW: The argument in the paper is consistent with Searle's thesis.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The argument in the paper is consistent with Searle's thesis.

positions.statement: VIEW: The question of whether or to what extent Searle's thesis is correct lies outside the scope of the present paper.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The question of whether or to what extent Searle's thesis is correct lies outside the scope of the present paper.

positions.statement: VIEW: The viewpoints of bona fide contextualists and authors with contextualist leanings have roots in the work of Wittgenstein and Austin.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: The viewpoints of bona fide contextualists and authors with contextualist leanings have roots in the work of Wittgenstein and Austin.

positions.statement: VIEW: Proper names are mere labels.
positions.verbatim_quote: VIEW: Proper names are mere labels.

positions.statement: Human beings have always unconsciously known the theory of evolution, repressing this knowledge due to its threat to self-esteem.
positions.verbatim_quote: Human beings have always unconsciously known the theory of evolution, repressing this knowledge due to its threat to self-esteem.

positions.statement: The anatomical similarities between humans and other animals are so obvious that recognition of common ancestry is virtually inevitable.
positions.verbatim_quote: The anatomical similarities between humans and other animals are so obvious that recognition of common ancestry is virtually inevitable.

positions.statement: When confronted with similar things, humans instinctively seek a common cause; the ability to accept coincidence marks non-instinctive thought.
positions.verbatim_quote: When confronted with similar things, humans instinctively seek a common cause; the ability to accept coincidence marks non-instinctive thought.

positions.statement: Human self-conception as morally superior to animals is a defensive mechanism against the humiliating truth of our animal nature.
positions.verbatim_quote: Human self-conception as morally superior to animals is a defensive mechanism against the humiliating truth of our animal nature.

positions.statement: The biological basis of love and sex, involving excretory organs, reveals our fundamental animality despite idealized conceptions.
positions.verbatim_quote: The biological basis of love and sex, involving excretory organs, reveals our fundamental animality despite idealized conceptions.

positions.statement: Sexual intercourse has always been regarded as indecent except under hyper-specific circumstances, proving awareness of our animal nature.
positions.verbatim_quote: Sexual intercourse has always been regarded as indecent except under hyper-specific circumstances, proving awareness of our animal nature.

positions.statement: A proposition is the non-linguistic entity meant by a complete sentence, not the sentence itself.
positions.verbatim_quote: A proposition is the non-linguistic entity meant by a complete sentence, not the sentence itself.

positions.statement: Emotions are beliefs or are at least belief-like in that they can be true or false, rational or irrational.
positions.verbatim_quote: Emotions are beliefs or are at least belief-like in that they can be true or false, rational or irrational.

positions.statement: Emotions answer to canons of rationality, which only beliefs can do; therefore emotions must be beliefs.
positions.verbatim_quote: Emotions answer to canons of rationality, which only beliefs can do; therefore emotions must be beliefs.

positions.statement: Moral statements express emotions, and since emotions are beliefs capable of truth and falsity, moral statements can be true or false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Moral statements express emotions, and since emotions are beliefs capable of truth and falsity, moral statements can be true or false.

positions.statement: Emotivism, properly understood, is a form of moral realism rather than anti-realism.
positions.verbatim_quote: Emotivism, properly understood, is a form of moral realism rather than anti-realism.

positions.statement: Awareness of norms cannot be acquired through behavioral conditioning; it must exist ab initio or not at all.
positions.verbatim_quote: Awareness of norms cannot be acquired through behavioral conditioning; it must exist ab initio or not at all.

positions.statement: A society of normless individuals cannot collectively become aware of norms; norms cannot emerge from non-normative ingredients.
positions.verbatim_quote: A society of normless individuals cannot collectively become aware of norms; norms cannot emerge from non-normative ingredients.

positions.statement: Understanding complex sentences presupposes grasping concepts; there is no way to reduce sentence comprehension to precognitive reactions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Understanding complex sentences presupposes grasping concepts; there is no way to reduce sentence comprehension to precognitive reactions.

positions.statement: To understand a complex sentence, one must grasp not just the concepts of its constituents but also the rules governing their composition.
