positions.verbatim_quote: To understand a complex sentence, one must grasp not just the concepts of its constituents but also the rules governing their composition.

positions.statement: A creature with purely de re awareness cannot make the leap to de dicto awareness through conditioning alone.
positions.verbatim_quote: A creature with purely de re awareness cannot make the leap to de dicto awareness through conditioning alone.

positions.statement: Lexical items do not come bundled the way concepts do; therefore lexical items cannot be our concepts, and we do not think in any language.
positions.verbatim_quote: Lexical items do not come bundled the way concepts do; therefore lexical items cannot be our concepts, and we do not think in any language.

positions.statement: There is no such thing as Mentalese; we do not think in a language or symbolic code.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no such thing as Mentalese; we do not think in a language or symbolic code.

positions.statement: Constitutive relations among concepts are not containment relations among symbols.
positions.verbatim_quote: Constitutive relations among concepts are not containment relations among symbols.

positions.statement: The thought "that is a sphere" is different from, though constitutively connected with, the thought "that is a closed figure of uniform curvature."
positions.verbatim_quote: The thought "that is a sphere" is different from, though constitutively connected with, the thought "that is a closed figure of uniform curvature."

positions.statement: Conceptual analysis and semantic analysis are not the same thing; a single semantic analysis may correspond to multiple conceptual analyses.
positions.verbatim_quote: Conceptual analysis and semantic analysis are not the same thing; a single semantic analysis may correspond to multiple conceptual analyses.

positions.statement: Color concepts are not mutually definable, yet they are constitutively interconnected; one cannot grasp one color without grasping others.
positions.verbatim_quote: Color concepts are not mutually definable, yet they are constitutively interconnected; one cannot grasp one color without grasping others.

positions.statement: Any concept has constitutive connections to other concepts; conceptual atomism is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Any concept has constitutive connections to other concepts; conceptual atomism is false.

positions.statement: One cannot represent a single property to oneself without being able to represent other properties; representational capacities come in networks.
positions.verbatim_quote: One cannot represent a single property to oneself without being able to represent other properties; representational capacities come in networks.

positions.statement: To grasp a specific shade of color, one must be able to distinguish it from other colors and thus grasp multiple colors.
positions.verbatim_quote: To grasp a specific shade of color, one must be able to distinguish it from other colors and thus grasp multiple colors.

positions.statement: If a creature could represent only one shade of color, its concept of that shade would collapse into a concept of color in general.
positions.verbatim_quote: If a creature could represent only one shade of color, its concept of that shade would collapse into a concept of color in general.

positions.statement: Properties are individuated by their relations to other properties; grasping a property requires grasping its place in a space of properties.
positions.verbatim_quote: Properties are individuated by their relations to other properties; grasping a property requires grasping its place in a space of properties.

positions.statement: Degree properties like "weighing 1000 lbs" obviously require grasping related properties; this point generalizes to all properties.
positions.verbatim_quote: Degree properties like "weighing 1000 lbs" obviously require grasping related properties; this point generalizes to all properties.

positions.statement: A language must comprise basic expressions; otherwise knowledge of any expression would presuppose knowledge of an infinitely large lexicon.
positions.verbatim_quote: A language must comprise basic expressions; otherwise knowledge of any expression would presuppose knowledge of an infinitely large lexicon.

positions.statement: Proper names are not definite descriptions, as Kripke decisively showed.
positions.verbatim_quote: Proper names are not definite descriptions, as Kripke decisively showed.

positions.statement: What we think does not, by itself, establish what our words and sentences mean; semantic externalism is correct.
positions.verbatim_quote: What we think does not, by itself, establish what our words and sentences mean; semantic externalism is correct.

positions.statement: Twin Earth cases show that the meanings of natural kind terms are not wholly determined by internal psychological states.
positions.verbatim_quote: Twin Earth cases show that the meanings of natural kind terms are not wholly determined by internal psychological states.

positions.statement: Content internalism is compatible with semantic externalism; linguistic meaning and cognitive content are distinct.
positions.verbatim_quote: Content internalism is compatible with semantic externalism; linguistic meaning and cognitive content are distinct.

positions.statement: Reference-fixing should be distinguished from meaning-giving; this distinction dissolves many puzzles about concepts.
positions.verbatim_quote: Reference-fixing should be distinguished from meaning-giving; this distinction dissolves many puzzles about concepts.

positions.statement: To have a concept of a thing is to know some proposition that describes that thing.
positions.verbatim_quote: To have a concept of a thing is to know some proposition that describes that thing.

positions.statement: Knowledge of an existential proposition that uniquely describes x suffices for the ability to think about x.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowledge of an existential proposition that uniquely describes x suffices for the ability to think about x.

positions.statement: Conception is sustained by knowledge of uniquely individuating descriptions, which may include indexical elements.
positions.verbatim_quote: Conception is sustained by knowledge of uniquely individuating descriptions, which may include indexical elements.

positions.statement: Recognition consists in seeing that one object satisfies two existence claims previously thought to be satisfied by different objects.
positions.verbatim_quote: Recognition consists in seeing that one object satisfies two existence claims previously thought to be satisfied by different objects.

positions.statement: Phenomenal content does not supervene on propositional content; intentionalism is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Phenomenal content does not supervene on propositional content; intentionalism is false.

positions.statement: Phenomenal content does not supervene on non-propositional representational content either.
positions.verbatim_quote: Phenomenal content does not supervene on non-propositional representational content either.

positions.statement: Intentionalism over-predicts the amount of information borne by sensations.
positions.verbatim_quote: Intentionalism over-predicts the amount of information borne by sensations.

positions.statement: A tickle or twinge is too simple and homogeneous to bear fine-grained propositions about anatomical structures.
positions.verbatim_quote: A tickle or twinge is too simple and homogeneous to bear fine-grained propositions about anatomical structures.

positions.statement: Creatures can experience phenomenal contents like woozy feelings without possessing vast networks of representational capacities.
positions.verbatim_quote: Creatures can experience phenomenal contents like woozy feelings without possessing vast networks of representational capacities.

positions.statement: If intentionalism were true, a twinge would deliver vastly more information than such sensations actually deliver.
positions.verbatim_quote: If intentionalism were true, a twinge would deliver vastly more information than such sensations actually deliver.

positions.statement: Phenomenal content is something altogether different from representational content—not identical with or supervenient on it.
positions.verbatim_quote: Phenomenal content is something altogether different from representational content—not identical with or supervenient on it.

positions.statement: Even restricted intentionalism (within sensory modalities) collapses into non-intentionalism upon examination.
positions.verbatim_quote: Even restricted intentionalism (within sensory modalities) collapses into non-intentionalism upon examination.

positions.statement: There is no absolute correspondence between phenomenal and representational content.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no absolute correspondence between phenomenal and representational content.

positions.statement: Different phenomenal contents, even within the same modality, can bear the same representational content.
positions.verbatim_quote: Different phenomenal contents, even within the same modality, can bear the same representational content.

positions.statement: The relationship between phenomenal contents and their physical causes is like a "rule of projection" that could be different.
positions.verbatim_quote: The relationship between phenomenal contents and their physical causes is like a "rule of projection" that could be different.

positions.statement: The Computational Theory of Mind (CTM) is false because there is no purely morphological characterization of syntax.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Computational Theory of Mind (CTM) is false because there is no purely morphological characterization of syntax.

positions.statement: There is no purely syntactic characterization of logical truth; adequate characterizations must be partially semantic.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no purely syntactic characterization of logical truth; adequate characterizations must be partially semantic.

positions.statement: The only way to sensitize a thing to logical form is to sensitize it to semantics.
positions.verbatim_quote: The only way to sensitize a thing to logical form is to sensitize it to semantics.

positions.statement: Turing machines do not compute in the relevant sense because they do not respond to semantics.
positions.verbatim_quote: Turing machines do not compute in the relevant sense because they do not respond to semantics.

positions.statement: Adding numbers is never a purely mechanical, cognition-free operation even when done by the "quick and dirty" method.
positions.verbatim_quote: Adding numbers is never a purely mechanical, cognition-free operation even when done by the "quick and dirty" method.

positions.statement: A representationally innocent entity generating patterns of shapes does not constitute genuine computation.
positions.verbatim_quote: A representationally innocent entity generating patterns of shapes does not constitute genuine computation.

positions.statement: Computing involves being sensitive to logical form, and logical form is buried in semantics.
positions.verbatim_quote: Computing involves being sensitive to logical form, and logical form is buried in semantics.

positions.statement: The Ramsey-Lewis sentence method for defining theoretical terms is useless because functionalism cannot be articulated without vicious circularity.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Ramsey-Lewis sentence method for defining theoretical terms is useless because functionalism cannot be articulated without vicious circularity.

positions.statement: Functionalism fails because it cannot non-circularly specify the mental states in terms of which functional roles are defined.
positions.verbatim_quote: Functionalism fails because it cannot non-circularly specify the mental states in terms of which functional roles are defined.

positions.statement: Content externalism strips mental content of causal efficacy; if externalism is true, content cannot explain behavior.
positions.verbatim_quote: Content externalism strips mental content of causal efficacy; if externalism is true, content cannot explain behavior.

positions.statement: Program causes (as defined by Jackson and Pettit) do not rescue content externalism from the causal impotence objection.
positions.verbatim_quote: Program causes (as defined by Jackson and Pettit) do not rescue content externalism from the causal impotence objection.

positions.statement: Mental causation requires that mental content be causally relevant in a way externalism cannot accommodate.
positions.verbatim_quote: Mental causation requires that mental content be causally relevant in a way externalism cannot accommodate.

positions.statement: Davidson's anomalous monism leads to epiphenomenalism about the mental.
positions.verbatim_quote: Davidson's anomalous monism leads to epiphenomenalism about the mental.

positions.statement: Jerry Fodor's computationalism is pseudo-computationalism because he cannot adequately account for how syntax tracks semantics.
positions.verbatim_quote: Jerry Fodor's computationalism is pseudo-computationalism because he cannot adequately account for how syntax tracks semantics.

positions.statement: Fodor's main argument for conceptual atomism fails because constitutive connections are not containment relations.
positions.verbatim_quote: Fodor's main argument for conceptual atomism fails because constitutive connections are not containment relations.

positions.statement: Fodor confuses the claim that concepts are not decomposable with the claim that concepts lack constitutive connections to others.
positions.verbatim_quote: Fodor confuses the claim that concepts are not decomposable with the claim that concepts lack constitutive connections to others.

positions.statement: Non-atomism does not require inferential role semantics (IRS); the inference from one to the other is fallacious.
positions.verbatim_quote: Non-atomism does not require inferential role semantics (IRS); the inference from one to the other is fallacious.

positions.statement: Inferential role semantics faces the "error objection": if inferential roles define concepts, misapplication becomes impossible.
positions.verbatim_quote: Inferential role semantics faces the "error objection": if inferential roles define concepts, misapplication becomes impossible.

positions.statement: Inferential role semantics leads to an untenable holism where no two people can grasp the same proposition.
positions.verbatim_quote: Inferential role semantics leads to an untenable holism where no two people can grasp the same proposition.

positions.statement: The bundle theory of personal identity is defensible when properly understood.
positions.verbatim_quote: The bundle theory of personal identity is defensible when properly understood.

positions.statement: Propositions are sets of properties; truth is the instantiation of all members of that set.
positions.verbatim_quote: Propositions are sets of properties; truth is the instantiation of all members of that set.

positions.statement: A proposition like "Smith punches Jones" is a set containing properties corresponding to Smith, Jones, and the punching relation.
positions.verbatim_quote: A proposition like "Smith punches Jones" is a set containing properties corresponding to Smith, Jones, and the punching relation.

positions.statement: For a proposition to be true is for all of its component properties to be instantiated.
positions.verbatim_quote: For a proposition to be true is for all of its component properties to be instantiated.

positions.statement: Propositions have decompositional structure; they are not merely specified by truth-conditions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Propositions have decompositional structure; they are not merely specified by truth-conditions.

positions.statement: Analytically equivalent propositions can convey very different information.
positions.verbatim_quote: Analytically equivalent propositions can convey very different information.

positions.statement: Analytic propositions do typically convey information, contrary to Lewis's model.
positions.verbatim_quote: Analytic propositions do typically convey information, contrary to Lewis's model.

positions.statement: Hempel's paradox is solved by recognizing that accidental generalizations do not receive support from their instances.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hempel's paradox is solved by recognizing that accidental generalizations do not receive support from their instances.

positions.statement: Only principled (nomic) generalizations receive confirmational support from their instances.
positions.verbatim_quote: Only principled (nomic) generalizations receive confirmational support from their instances.

positions.statement: "If x is heated metal, x expands" and "If x isn't expanding, x isn't heated metal" are not confirmationally equivalent when read nomically.
positions.verbatim_quote: "If x is heated metal, x expands" and "If x isn't expanding, x isn't heated metal" are not confirmationally equivalent when read nomically.

positions.statement: Negative facts (like not being heated metal) are not fit to stand in nomic relations because they are not events or constituted by events.
positions.verbatim_quote: Negative facts (like not being heated metal) are not fit to stand in nomic relations because they are not events or constituted by events.

positions.statement: A thing's not having a property is not nomically connected to anything, unlike a thing's having a property.
positions.verbatim_quote: A thing's not having a property is not nomically connected to anything, unlike a thing's having a property.

positions.statement: Inductions by enumeration are actually crypto-inferences to the best explanation.
positions.verbatim_quote: Inductions by enumeration are actually crypto-inferences to the best explanation.

positions.statement: Formal truth is truth by virtue of being an instance of a sentence-schema all of whose instances are true.
positions.verbatim_quote: Formal truth is truth by virtue of being an instance of a sentence-schema all of whose instances are true.

positions.statement: Formal truth is not identical with syntactic truth; there is no purely morphological characterization of logical form.
positions.verbatim_quote: Formal truth is not identical with syntactic truth; there is no purely morphological characterization of logical form.

positions.statement: The equation of formal truth with syntactic truth is viciously circular.
positions.verbatim_quote: The equation of formal truth with syntactic truth is viciously circular.

positions.statement: Not all logical truths are formal truths; logic cannot be identified with the study of formal truth.
positions.verbatim_quote: Not all logical truths are formal truths; logic cannot be identified with the study of formal truth.

positions.statement: The most fundamental truths of logic must consist of non-formal, analytic truths.
positions.verbatim_quote: The most fundamental truths of logic must consist of non-formal, analytic truths.

positions.statement: The linguistic theory of logical truth (that logical truths are true by convention) is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: The linguistic theory of logical truth (that logical truths are true by convention) is false.

positions.statement: Logical truths are not true merely in virtue of the meanings of words or linguistic conventions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Logical truths are not true merely in virtue of the meanings of words or linguistic conventions.

positions.statement: Conceivability sometimes entails possibility, providing a neo-Cartesian argument for dualism.
positions.verbatim_quote: Conceivability sometimes entails possibility, providing a neo-Cartesian argument for dualism.

positions.statement: If mental properties are not identical with physical properties, and identity is necessary, then dualism follows.
positions.verbatim_quote: If mental properties are not identical with physical properties, and identity is necessary, then dualism follows.

positions.statement: Time travel is an incoherent concept.
positions.verbatim_quote: Time travel is an incoherent concept.

positions.statement: Probabilistic causation is a genuine form of causation distinct from deterministic causation.
positions.verbatim_quote: Probabilistic causation is a genuine form of causation distinct from deterministic causation.

positions.statement: Simulated thought is not actual thought; genuine mental processes cannot be simulated by non-mental processes.
positions.verbatim_quote: Simulated thought is not actual thought; genuine mental processes cannot be simulated by non-mental processes.

positions.statement: Davidson's views on rationality embody fundamental misconceptions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Davidson's views on rationality embody fundamental misconceptions.

positions.statement: Foundationalism about knowledge is compatible with non-atomism about concepts.
positions.verbatim_quote: Foundationalism about knowledge is compatible with non-atomism about concepts.

positions.statement: Intentionalism (the view that phenomenal properties are representational properties) fails both in restricted and unrestricted forms.
positions.verbatim_quote: Intentionalism (the view that phenomenal properties are representational properties) fails both in restricted and unrestricted forms.

positions.statement: The veil of perception problem is exacerbated by externalism, not solved by it.
positions.verbatim_quote: The veil of perception problem is exacerbated by externalism, not solved by it.

positions.statement: Representationalism about perception faces serious objections from the nature of phenomenal experience.
positions.verbatim_quote: Representationalism about perception faces serious objections from the nature of phenomenal experience.

positions.statement: Understanding a sentence requires knowing multiple existence claims and their connections.
positions.verbatim_quote: Understanding a sentence requires knowing multiple existence claims and their connections.

positions.statement: Identification is relative to background knowledge; being able to identify an object means connecting it to background knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: Identification is relative to background knowledge; being able to identify an object means connecting it to background knowledge.

positions.statement: A parrot cannot really say "it's getting hotter" because it lacks grasp of concepts and semantic rules.
positions.verbatim_quote: A parrot cannot really say "it's getting hotter" because it lacks grasp of concepts and semantic rules.

positions.statement: For a sentence to have meaning for a speaker, it must have internal structure connected to concepts.
positions.verbatim_quote: For a sentence to have meaning for a speaker, it must have internal structure connected to concepts.

positions.statement: The meaning of complex sentences is a resultant, not a mere heaping together, of component meanings.
positions.verbatim_quote: The meaning of complex sentences is a resultant, not a mere heaping together, of component meanings.

positions.statement: The word "fire" in isolation has the same semantics as in complex sentences; meaning operates through concepts uniformly.
positions.verbatim_quote: The word "fire" in isolation has the same semantics as in complex sentences; meaning operates through concepts uniformly.

positions.statement: Sense perceptions have existential content; the content of a perception is given by some bit of existential information.
positions.verbatim_quote: Sense perceptions have existential content; the content of a perception is given by some bit of existential information.

positions.statement: Introspection, while limited, is reasonably reliable for apprehending the nature of phenomenal contents.
positions.verbatim_quote: Introspection, while limited, is reasonably reliable for apprehending the nature of phenomenal contents.

positions.statement: If phenomenal contents deliver information, our conscious minds must retrieve this information, suggesting we know our phenomenal contents well.
positions.verbatim_quote: If phenomenal contents deliver information, our conscious minds must retrieve this information, suggesting we know our phenomenal contents well.

positions.statement: Kant's argument for synthetic a priori truths is spurious, but his important claims about causality, personal identity, and rationality are correct when de-psychologized.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant's argument for synthetic a priori truths is spurious, but his important claims about causality, personal identity, and rationality are correct when de-psychologized.

positions.statement: Kant's premises actually entail the opposite of his thesis: there are virtually no a priori truths, making Kant more opposed to a priori truth than John Stuart Mill.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant's premises actually entail the opposite of his thesis: there are virtually no a priori truths, making Kant more opposed to a priori truth than John Stuart Mill.

positions.statement: Kant confuses two different epistemological roles of mental imagery: as a vehicle for conceptual analysis and as an object of empirical study.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant confuses two different epistemological roles of mental imagery: as a vehicle for conceptual analysis and as an object of empirical study.

positions.statement: Kant's reasoning must be de-psychologized—his statements about psychology must be reinterpreted as statements about logic.
positions.verbatim_quote: Kant's reasoning must be de-psychologized—his statements about psychology must be reinterpreted as statements about logic.

positions.statement: Conceptual necessity is non-psychological necessity that holds entirely in virtue of facts about concepts in the platonic sense.
positions.verbatim_quote: Conceptual necessity is non-psychological necessity that holds entirely in virtue of facts about concepts in the platonic sense.

positions.statement: The proposition "triangles have three sides" would still be true even if there were no sentient beings.
positions.verbatim_quote: The proposition "triangles have three sides" would still be true even if there were no sentient beings.

positions.statement: Representational necessity is a different category where propositions are necessarily true because of facts about our minds.
positions.verbatim_quote: Representational necessity is a different category where propositions are necessarily true because of facts about our minds.

positions.statement: Wittgenstein's regress argument shows that grasping a norm is not a cognitive affair in the traditional sense of having an inner representation.
positions.verbatim_quote: Wittgenstein's regress argument shows that grasping a norm is not a cognitive affair in the traditional sense of having an inner representation.

positions.statement: Grasping a norm consists in having certain dispositions, not in possessing some mental icon corresponding to that norm.
positions.verbatim_quote: Grasping a norm consists in having certain dispositions, not in possessing some mental icon corresponding to that norm.

positions.statement: Knowing-how is not cognitive in the sense of involving a grasp of propositions; it is a kind of competence or sensitivity.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowing-how is not cognitive in the sense of involving a grasp of propositions; it is a kind of competence or sensitivity.

positions.statement: For Wittgenstein, to know what a sentence means is to know how to use it, which is to be coordinated with other people's usage.
positions.verbatim_quote: For Wittgenstein, to know what a sentence means is to know how to use it, which is to be coordinated with other people's usage.

positions.statement: Knowledge-how does ultimately reduce to knowledge-that; knowing how to do something consists in internally representing rules.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowledge-how does ultimately reduce to knowledge-that; knowing how to do something consists in internally representing rules.

positions.statement: Brandom's account of how individuals acquire intentionality is circular: one cannot give and ask for reasons without first grasping reasons.
positions.verbatim_quote: Brandom's account of how individuals acquire intentionality is circular: one cannot give and ask for reasons without first grasping reasons.

positions.statement: Locke, Kant, and classical philosophers were right that speaking is a kind of externalized thinking, not vice versa.
positions.verbatim_quote: Locke, Kant, and classical philosophers were right that speaking is a kind of externalized thinking, not vice versa.

positions.statement: The idea that thinking is internalized speaking (Wittgenstein, Brandom) is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: The idea that thinking is internalized speaking (Wittgenstein, Brandom) is false.

positions.statement: Given a group of creatures oblivious to norms, no amount of interaction will make any of them aware of norms.
positions.verbatim_quote: Given a group of creatures oblivious to norms, no amount of interaction will make any of them aware of norms.

positions.statement: The "buck cannot be passed onto society": a society of normless individuals will itself be normless.
positions.verbatim_quote: The "buck cannot be passed onto society": a society of normless individuals will itself be normless.

positions.statement: A proposition is a special kind of norm: a standard against which reality is compared.
positions.verbatim_quote: A proposition is a special kind of norm: a standard against which reality is compared.

positions.statement: To expect dinner tomorrow, unlike expecting dinner now, requires de dicto awareness and grasp of concepts.
positions.verbatim_quote: To expect dinner tomorrow, unlike expecting dinner now, requires de dicto awareness and grasp of concepts.

positions.statement: Ordinary stimuli have no internal structure, but sentences are articulate—their parts stand in significant relations.
positions.verbatim_quote: Ordinary stimuli have no internal structure, but sentences are articulate—their parts stand in significant relations.

positions.statement: Through Pavlovian training you can make a dog react to stimuli, but you cannot make it understand compound sentences.
positions.verbatim_quote: Through Pavlovian training you can make a dog react to stimuli, but you cannot make it understand compound sentences.

positions.statement: Understanding "if there's smoke, there's fire" requires grasping the concepts of smoke and fire, not just particular instances.
positions.verbatim_quote: Understanding "if there's smoke, there's fire" requires grasping the concepts of smoke and fire, not just particular instances.

positions.statement: Identity holds necessarily: if A can be distinct from B, then A must be distinct from B.
positions.verbatim_quote: Identity holds necessarily: if A can be distinct from B, then A must be distinct from B.

positions.statement: Logical possibility sometimes indicates actual possibility, but not always—the relevant difference involves object-dependent vs. object-independent concepts.
positions.verbatim_quote: Logical possibility sometimes indicates actual possibility, but not always—the relevant difference involves object-dependent vs. object-independent concepts.

positions.statement: Whenever there is a disparity between logical and metaphysical possibility, it is underwritten by facts about object-dependent concepts.
positions.verbatim_quote: Whenever there is a disparity between logical and metaphysical possibility, it is underwritten by facts about object-dependent concepts.

positions.statement: Necessities underwritten wholly by object-independent concepts have logical possibility coinciding with metaphysical possibility.
positions.verbatim_quote: Necessities underwritten wholly by object-independent concepts have logical possibility coinciding with metaphysical possibility.

positions.statement: Object-dependent concepts have actual spatiotemporal objects as constituents; object-independent concepts do not.
positions.verbatim_quote: Object-dependent concepts have actual spatiotemporal objects as constituents; object-independent concepts do not.

positions.statement: To grasp an object-involving proposition, one must have causal liaisons to the object; purely existential propositions can be grasped without such liaisons.
positions.verbatim_quote: To grasp an object-involving proposition, one must have causal liaisons to the object; purely existential propositions can be grasped without such liaisons.

positions.statement: A brain in a vat could grasp purely existential propositions but not object-involving propositions about spatiotemporal objects.
positions.verbatim_quote: A brain in a vat could grasp purely existential propositions but not object-involving propositions about spatiotemporal objects.

positions.statement: There is no purely morphological characterization of syntax; syntax is buried in semantics.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no purely morphological characterization of syntax; syntax is buried in semantics.

positions.statement: Any expression could mean anything; given any entity, there is some language in which "172" denotes that entity.
positions.verbatim_quote: Any expression could mean anything; given any entity, there is some language in which "172" denotes that entity.

positions.statement: There can be no algorithm deciding truth-value wholly on the basis of shape; truth-value requires morphology plus semantic background.
positions.verbatim_quote: There can be no algorithm deciding truth-value wholly on the basis of shape; truth-value requires morphology plus semantic background.

positions.statement: An algorithm is given by a conditional proposition: if such and such semantic system holds, then there is a morphological characterization of truth.
positions.verbatim_quote: An algorithm is given by a conditional proposition: if such and such semantic system holds, then there is a morphological characterization of truth.

positions.statement: To apply an algorithm involves recognizing the truth of a multiply conditional proposition about semantics and shapes.
positions.verbatim_quote: To apply an algorithm involves recognizing the truth of a multiply conditional proposition about semantics and shapes.

positions.statement: The manipulation of shapes is at most a causal consequence of actual computation—almost an epiphenomenon.
positions.verbatim_quote: The manipulation of shapes is at most a causal consequence of actual computation—almost an epiphenomenon.

positions.statement: Even if there are algorithms for various domains, thought in those domains cannot be "mechanized."
positions.verbatim_quote: Even if there are algorithms for various domains, thought in those domains cannot be "mechanized."

positions.statement: There are two components to applying an algorithm: recognition of an operative semantic system (not mechanical) and patterns of shapes (can be mechanical).
positions.verbatim_quote: There are two components to applying an algorithm: recognition of an operative semantic system (not mechanical) and patterns of shapes (can be mechanical).

positions.statement: Inference requires recognition that premises stand in a bearing relation (entailment or probabilification) to the conclusion.
positions.verbatim_quote: Inference requires recognition that premises stand in a bearing relation (entailment or probabilification) to the conclusion.

positions.statement: To have a rational thought-process, symbols must follow one another in a way that embodies awareness of bearing-relations among them.
positions.verbatim_quote: To have a rational thought-process, symbols must follow one another in a way that embodies awareness of bearing-relations among them.

positions.statement: A computer's symbols follow one another in the right order, but this doesn't involve recognition of bearing relations—so computers don't really think.
positions.verbatim_quote: A computer's symbols follow one another in the right order, but this doesn't involve recognition of bearing relations—so computers don't really think.

positions.statement: A computation is a purely formal, syntax-driven inference where consideration of semantics plays no part.
positions.verbatim_quote: A computation is a purely formal, syntax-driven inference where consideration of semantics plays no part.

positions.statement: Fodor's "solution" to how physics-driven brain activity can be logic-consistent involves a massive confusion.
positions.verbatim_quote: Fodor's "solution" to how physics-driven brain activity can be logic-consistent involves a massive confusion.

positions.statement: The "tracking problem"—how purely descriptive brain activity embodies sensitivity to prescriptive norms—is not solved by CTM.
positions.verbatim_quote: The "tracking problem"—how purely descriptive brain activity embodies sensitivity to prescriptive norms—is not solved by CTM.

positions.statement: Nobody knows Mentalese; nobody understands its expressions; it isn't by being understood that Mentalese tokens facilitate thought.
positions.verbatim_quote: Nobody knows Mentalese; nobody understands its expressions; it isn't by being understood that Mentalese tokens facilitate thought.

positions.statement: Mentalese, if it existed, would differ radically from real languages because its expressions need not be understood to function.
positions.verbatim_quote: Mentalese, if it existed, would differ radically from real languages because its expressions need not be understood to function.

positions.statement: The very concept of a "language of thought" is incoherent because languages require understanding to function.
positions.verbatim_quote: The very concept of a "language of thought" is incoherent because languages require understanding to function.

positions.statement: Brains are governed entirely by the laws of physics, which are purely descriptive, not prescriptive.
positions.verbatim_quote: Brains are governed entirely by the laws of physics, which are purely descriptive, not prescriptive.

positions.statement: Our mental lives are entirely realized by brain activity, yet our mental activity conforms to canons of good reasoning.
positions.verbatim_quote: Our mental lives are entirely realized by brain activity, yet our mental activity conforms to canons of good reasoning.

positions.statement: Laws of physics are not laws of rationality, so laws of rationality seemingly play no part in our thinking—yet clearly they do.
positions.verbatim_quote: Laws of physics are not laws of rationality, so laws of rationality seemingly play no part in our thinking—yet clearly they do.

positions.statement: What we think largely determines what our expressions mean, but there is also an important non-psychological dimension to meaning.
positions.verbatim_quote: What we think largely determines what our expressions mean, but there is also an important non-psychological dimension to meaning.

positions.statement: Given psychological and behavioral indistinguishability, it does not follow that utterances have the same meanings.
positions.verbatim_quote: Given psychological and behavioral indistinguishability, it does not follow that utterances have the same meanings.

positions.statement: Twin Earth cases show that two utterances can differ in meaning despite arising from psychologically identical states.
positions.verbatim_quote: Twin Earth cases show that two utterances can differ in meaning despite arising from psychologically identical states.

positions.statement: The word "water" refers to H2O even for speakers in the 1600s who knew nothing of chemistry.
positions.verbatim_quote: The word "water" refers to H2O even for speakers in the 1600s who knew nothing of chemistry.

positions.statement: If a substance were discovered to be XYZ rather than H2O, chemists would say it is extremely water-like, not that water is sometimes XYZ.
positions.verbatim_quote: If a substance were discovered to be XYZ rather than H2O, chemists would say it is extremely water-like, not that water is sometimes XYZ.

positions.statement: Semantic externalism is true: meaning is not wholly determined by internal psychological states.
positions.verbatim_quote: Semantic externalism is true: meaning is not wholly determined by internal psychological states.

positions.statement: Content internalism is also true: what we are thinking is wholly determined by our internal states.
positions.verbatim_quote: Content internalism is also true: what we are thinking is wholly determined by our internal states.

positions.statement: The distinction between reference-fixing and meaning-giving dissolves the apparent tension between externalism about meaning and internalism about content.
positions.verbatim_quote: The distinction between reference-fixing and meaning-giving dissolves the apparent tension between externalism about meaning and internalism about content.

positions.statement: The representational content of visual perception can be put into words and embodied in propositions.
positions.verbatim_quote: The representational content of visual perception can be put into words and embodied in propositions.

positions.statement: All representational content is essentially propositional; there is no genuinely non-propositional representational content.
positions.verbatim_quote: All representational content is essentially propositional; there is no genuinely non-propositional representational content.

positions.statement: Functionalism gets the order of explanation wrong: you stop because you see a stop-sign, not vice versa.
positions.verbatim_quote: Functionalism gets the order of explanation wrong: you stop because you see a stop-sign, not vice versa.

positions.statement: For functionalism, a perception has its content in virtue of causing certain behavior—but content is what causes behavior.
positions.verbatim_quote: For functionalism, a perception has its content in virtue of causing certain behavior—but content is what causes behavior.

positions.statement: If x exists in virtue of y's existing, then x cannot cause y to exist; so functionalism makes content causally inert.
positions.verbatim_quote: If x exists in virtue of y's existing, then x cannot cause y to exist; so functionalism makes content causally inert.

positions.statement: Functionalism says you see a growling dog because you flee, but obviously you flee because you see a growling dog.
positions.verbatim_quote: Functionalism says you see a growling dog because you flee, but obviously you flee because you see a growling dog.

positions.statement: Whenever one adds a referring term to one's lexicon, it involves knowing some uniquely individuating description of the referent.
positions.verbatim_quote: Whenever one adds a referring term to one's lexicon, it involves knowing some uniquely individuating description of the referent.

positions.statement: The semantics of a name are not existential-descriptive, but the act of learning the semantics is existential-descriptive.
positions.verbatim_quote: The semantics of a name are not existential-descriptive, but the act of learning the semantics is existential-descriptive.

positions.statement: Names are just labels semantically, but one learns which thing a name labels through existential-descriptive claims.
positions.verbatim_quote: Names are just labels semantically, but one learns which thing a name labels through existential-descriptive claims.

positions.statement: To avoid running afoul of Kripke's points, we must give operators like "refers to" narrow scope relative to descriptive content.
positions.verbatim_quote: To avoid running afoul of Kripke's points, we must give operators like "refers to" narrow scope relative to descriptive content.

positions.statement: Recognition of an individual consists in seeing that one thing uniquely satisfies each of two existence claims.
positions.verbatim_quote: Recognition of an individual consists in seeing that one thing uniquely satisfies each of two existence claims.

positions.statement: Conception is sustained by knowledge of a series of interlocking existence claims; any given claim may be dropped and replaced.
positions.verbatim_quote: Conception is sustained by knowledge of a series of interlocking existence claims; any given claim may be dropped and replaced.

positions.statement: At any juncture of having a conception of a thing, that conception involves knowledge of an existence claim.
positions.verbatim_quote: At any juncture of having a conception of a thing, that conception involves knowledge of an existence claim.

positions.statement: The cognitive difference between "Hesperus is lovely" and "Phosphorous is lovely" is explained by different existence claims.
positions.verbatim_quote: The cognitive difference between "Hesperus is lovely" and "Phosphorous is lovely" is explained by different existence claims.

positions.statement: Intentionalism is guilty of what Sellars called "the myth of the given."
positions.verbatim_quote: Intentionalism is guilty of what Sellars called "the myth of the given."

positions.statement: Visual sensations do not by themselves tell you what color an object is; background knowledge about environmental conditions is required.
positions.verbatim_quote: Visual sensations do not by themselves tell you what color an object is; background knowledge about environmental conditions is required.

positions.statement: Sensations coupled with background knowledge about conditions of perception tell you what properties objects have.
positions.verbatim_quote: Sensations coupled with background knowledge about conditions of perception tell you what properties objects have.

positions.statement: What makes a bit of phenomenal content have a given representational content is precisely the addition of background knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: What makes a bit of phenomenal content have a given representational content is precisely the addition of background knowledge.

positions.statement: If Sellars is right about the myth of the given, then intentionalism must be completely wrong.
positions.verbatim_quote: If Sellars is right about the myth of the given, then intentionalism must be completely wrong.

positions.statement: Perceivable properties require contextualizing information to be represented; they are not intrinsically associated with phenomenal contents.
positions.verbatim_quote: Perceivable properties require contextualizing information to be represented; they are not intrinsically associated with phenomenal contents.

positions.statement: Tickles and twinges bear only highly generic messages like "disturbance of some kind in such and such part of my body."
positions.verbatim_quote: Tickles and twinges bear only highly generic messages like "disturbance of some kind in such and such part of my body."

positions.statement: Sensations do not constitute high-resolution apprehensions of bodily conditions; they are fairly opaque and uninformative.
positions.verbatim_quote: Sensations do not constitute high-resolution apprehensions of bodily conditions; they are fairly opaque and uninformative.

positions.statement: Intentionalism demands that sensations be very non-opaque and high-resolution, which they plainly are not.
positions.verbatim_quote: Intentionalism demands that sensations be very non-opaque and high-resolution, which they plainly are not.

positions.statement: Even if sensations bore non-propositional information, they still would not bear enough information to vindicate intentionalism.
positions.verbatim_quote: Even if sensations bore non-propositional information, they still would not bear enough information to vindicate intentionalism.

positions.statement: Non-propositional content, if it exists, presupposes the same vast networks of representational capacities as propositional content.
positions.verbatim_quote: Non-propositional content, if it exists, presupposes the same vast networks of representational capacities as propositional content.

positions.statement: The ability to have any kind of representation presupposes the ability to represent things as having properties.
positions.verbatim_quote: The ability to have any kind of representation presupposes the ability to represent things as having properties.

positions.statement: A morphinated feeling of euphoria has no felt bodily location—no spatial representations seem involved.
positions.verbatim_quote: A morphinated feeling of euphoria has no felt bodily location—no spatial representations seem involved.

positions.statement: Some phenomenal contents are "generalized" feelings not felt in any particular body part.
positions.verbatim_quote: Some phenomenal contents are "generalized" feelings not felt in any particular body part.

positions.statement: Knowing what is distinctive about a color involves knowing how it differs from other colors.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowing what is distinctive about a color involves knowing how it differs from other colors.

positions.statement: Grasping the specific character of a property involves grasping what distinguishes it from other properties.
positions.verbatim_quote: Grasping the specific character of a property involves grasping what distinguishes it from other properties.

positions.statement: One can grasp a specific shape-property only if one has a grasp of a whole "space" of shape properties.
positions.verbatim_quote: One can grasp a specific shape-property only if one has a grasp of a whole "space" of shape properties.

positions.statement: Direct reference theory does not show that names express no concepts whatsoever.
positions.verbatim_quote: Direct reference theory does not show that names express no concepts whatsoever.

positions.statement: Freud held that thoughts must be clothed in words to become conscious—a view with some merit.
positions.verbatim_quote: Freud held that thoughts must be clothed in words to become conscious—a view with some merit.

positions.statement: Hume's ethical anti-realism is connected to his view that emotions are incapable of being true or false.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hume's ethical anti-realism is connected to his view that emotions are incapable of being true or false.

positions.statement: Emotions can be justified or unjustified, rational or irrational—properties that only beliefs can have.
positions.verbatim_quote: Emotions can be justified or unjustified, rational or irrational—properties that only beliefs can have.

positions.statement: People try to justify their emotions, both negative and positive, suggesting emotions answer to rational standards.
positions.verbatim_quote: People try to justify their emotions, both negative and positive, suggesting emotions answer to rational standards.

positions.statement: When someone narcotizes an irrational emotion, this presupposes that emotions can be evaluated as rational or irrational.
positions.verbatim_quote: When someone narcotizes an irrational emotion, this presupposes that emotions can be evaluated as rational or irrational.

positions.statement: Moral statements embody emotions; since emotions are beliefs capable of truth and falsity, moral realism follows.
positions.verbatim_quote: Moral statements embody emotions; since emotions are beliefs capable of truth and falsity, moral realism follows.

positions.statement: Speech-act semantics and tractarian semantics are not really opposed on the relation between sentences and propositions.
positions.verbatim_quote: Speech-act semantics and tractarian semantics are not really opposed on the relation between sentences and propositions.

positions.statement: If a sentence bears a proposition, then ipso facto it enables one to express the corresponding belief.
positions.verbatim_quote: If a sentence bears a proposition, then ipso facto it enables one to express the corresponding belief.

positions.statement: Hempel's paradox arises only if we conflate accidental generalizations with principled (nomic) generalizations.
positions.verbatim_quote: Hempel's paradox arises only if we conflate accidental generalizations with principled (nomic) generalizations.

positions.statement: Accidental generalizations like "all heated metal expands" read as mere de facto concomitances don't receive support from instances.
positions.verbatim_quote: Accidental generalizations like "all heated metal expands" read as mere de facto concomitances don't receive support from instances.

positions.statement: Only nomic generalizations—those alleging causal or lawlike connections—receive confirmational support from their instances.
positions.verbatim_quote: Only nomic generalizations—those alleging causal or lawlike connections—receive confirmational support from their instances.

positions.statement: Nomic relations hold only among spatiotemporal entities; negative facts like "not being heated metal" are not spatiotemporal.
positions.verbatim_quote: Nomic relations hold only among spatiotemporal entities; negative facts like "not being heated metal" are not spatiotemporal.

positions.statement: A thing's not having a property is like not destroying Jupiter—it is not an event and doesn't stand in nomic relations.
positions.verbatim_quote: A thing's not having a property is like not destroying Jupiter—it is not an event and doesn't stand in nomic relations.

positions.statement: The operator "there is a nomic connection between..." doesn't permit intersubstitution of logically equivalent sentences.
positions.verbatim_quote: The operator "there is a nomic connection between..." doesn't permit intersubstitution of logically equivalent sentences.

positions.statement: Logically equivalent sentences can be truth-preservingly intersubstituted in some contexts but not in contexts governed by nomic operators.
positions.verbatim_quote: Logically equivalent sentences can be truth-preservingly intersubstituted in some contexts but not in contexts governed by nomic operators.

positions.statement: Given that "P iff P" is formally true, the statement "all statements of the form P iff P are formally true" is itself not formal.
positions.verbatim_quote: Given that "P iff P" is formally true, the statement "all statements of the form P iff P are formally true" is itself not formal.

positions.statement: It is always on the basis of knowledge of non-formal truths that we know a given truth to be formal.
positions.verbatim_quote: It is always on the basis of knowledge of non-formal truths that we know a given truth to be formal.

positions.statement: It is an empirical fact that logical connectives have the syntactic and semantic properties they have.
positions.verbatim_quote: It is an empirical fact that logical connectives have the syntactic and semantic properties they have.

positions.statement: It is non-empirically true that, given their properties, certain connectives are truth-functional—this is analytic but non-formal.
positions.verbatim_quote: It is non-empirically true that, given their properties, certain connectives are truth-functional—this is analytic but non-formal.

positions.statement: Those non-formal, analytic truths are themselves part of logic and constitute its essence more than formal truths do.
positions.verbatim_quote: Those non-formal, analytic truths are themselves part of logic and constitute its essence more than formal truths do.

positions.statement: Formal logic is to pure logic as engineering is to physics—formal logic is applied logic.
positions.verbatim_quote: Formal logic is to pure logic as engineering is to physics—formal logic is applied logic.

positions.statement: Logicians who dedicate themselves exclusively to formal work are applied logicians, not logicians in the truest sense.
positions.verbatim_quote: Logicians who dedicate themselves exclusively to formal work are applied logicians, not logicians in the truest sense.

positions.statement: Bradley's Logic and Mill's Treatise on Logic, despite containing no formal reasoning, are genuine works of logic.
positions.verbatim_quote: Bradley's Logic and Mill's Treatise on Logic, despite containing no formal reasoning, are genuine works of logic.

positions.statement: A sentence is formally true if it is an instance of an open-sentence true for all values of its free variables.
positions.verbatim_quote: A sentence is formally true if it is an instance of an open-sentence true for all values of its free variables.

positions.statement: A proposition is a property of a world; for a proposition to be true is for that property to be instantiated.
positions.verbatim_quote: A proposition is a property of a world; for a proposition to be true is for that property to be instantiated.

positions.statement: Truth can be identified with instantiatedness: a proposition is true exactly if that property is instantiated in the actual world.
positions.verbatim_quote: Truth can be identified with instantiatedness: a proposition is true exactly if that property is instantiated in the actual world.

positions.statement: Lewis's identification of propositions with properties of worlds is informative but viciously circular if taken as an analysis.
positions.verbatim_quote: Lewis's identification of propositions with properties of worlds is informative but viciously circular if taken as an analysis.

positions.statement: Propositions have decompositional structure that mere sets of worlds or functions from worlds to truth-values do not capture.
positions.verbatim_quote: Propositions have decompositional structure that mere sets of worlds or functions from worlds to truth-values do not capture.

positions.statement: Analytic propositions do convey information, contrary to views that make them disappear as uninformative.
positions.verbatim_quote: Analytic propositions do convey information, contrary to views that make them disappear as uninformative.

positions.statement: A true proposition is always true in virtue of something about the world—mass-energy distribution, ripples in the quantum.
positions.verbatim_quote: A true proposition is always true in virtue of something about the world—mass-energy distribution, ripples in the quantum.

positions.statement: The truth of "Plato punched Socrates" supervenes on facts about atomic movements describable without mentioning Plato or Socrates.
positions.verbatim_quote: The truth of "Plato punched Socrates" supervenes on facts about atomic movements describable without mentioning Plato or Socrates.

positions.statement: The property of having the right "rippling" of mass-energy is more basic than the proposition it makes true.
positions.verbatim_quote: The property of having the right "rippling" of mass-energy is more basic than the proposition it makes true.

positions.statement: There is no circularity in analyzing propositions in terms of properties of worlds when those properties are more basic.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is no circularity in analyzing propositions in terms of properties of worlds when those properties are more basic.

positions.statement: Different propositions can share constituents: "Smith punches Jones" and "Plato punches Jones" share the "punches Jones" component.
positions.verbatim_quote: Different propositions can share constituents: "Smith punches Jones" and "Plato punches Jones" share the "punches Jones" component.

positions.statement: A proposition has components corresponding to incomplete properties like "x punches Jones" and "Smith punches x."
positions.verbatim_quote: A proposition has components corresponding to incomplete properties like "x punches Jones" and "Smith punches x."

positions.statement: Frege's analysis that propositions are built from relations and functions captures the structure of propositions correctly.
positions.verbatim_quote: Frege's analysis that propositions are built from relations and functions captures the structure of propositions correctly.

positions.statement: A proposition is a set of properties; it is true when all its members are instantiated.
positions.verbatim_quote: A proposition is a set of properties; it is true when all its members are instantiated.

positions.statement: Each discrete constituent of a proposition corresponds to one property in the set that constitutes it.
positions.verbatim_quote: Each discrete constituent of a proposition corresponds to one property in the set that constitutes it.

positions.statement: Fodor's argument for atomism fails because constitutive connections among concepts are not containment relations.
positions.verbatim_quote: Fodor's argument for atomism fails because constitutive connections among concepts are not containment relations.

positions.statement: Fodor confuses the claim that concepts resist decomposition with the claim that they lack constitutive connections.
positions.verbatim_quote: Fodor confuses the claim that concepts resist decomposition with the claim that they lack constitutive connections.

positions.statement: One's pink-concept is not composed of other color-concepts, yet one cannot have it without having other color-concepts.
positions.verbatim_quote: One's pink-concept is not composed of other color-concepts, yet one cannot have it without having other color-concepts.

positions.statement: Color-symbols are not mutually definable; color concepts are not decomposable into other color concepts.
positions.verbatim_quote: Color-symbols are not mutually definable; color concepts are not decomposable into other color concepts.

positions.statement: If color concepts literally contained other color concepts, any color thought would consist of infinitely many color thoughts—absurd.
positions.verbatim_quote: If color concepts literally contained other color concepts, any color thought would consist of infinitely many color thoughts—absurd.

positions.statement: Any attempt to block the infinite regress through looping definitions makes concept-possession presuppose itself.
positions.verbatim_quote: Any attempt to block the infinite regress through looping definitions makes concept-possession presuppose itself.

positions.statement: One's concept of 1,143 presupposes concepts of 1,142, 1,141, etc., but 1,143-thoughts are not cobbled together from these.
positions.verbatim_quote: One's concept of 1,143 presupposes concepts of 1,142, 1,141, etc., but 1,143-thoughts are not cobbled together from these.

positions.statement: Fodor is right that most concepts resist decomposition, but wrong that this means they lack constitutive connections.
positions.verbatim_quote: Fodor is right that most concepts resist decomposition, but wrong that this means they lack constitutive connections.

positions.statement: Inferential role semantics makes it impossible for two people to grasp the same proposition.
positions.verbatim_quote: Inferential role semantics makes it impossible for two people to grasp the same proposition.

positions.statement: For IRS, differences in inferential role mean differences in content; but no two cognitive states have identical inferential roles.
positions.verbatim_quote: For IRS, differences in inferential role mean differences in content; but no two cognitive states have identical inferential roles.

positions.statement: IRS faces the "error objection": if inferential roles define concepts, misapplication of concepts becomes impossible.
positions.verbatim_quote: IRS faces the "error objection": if inferential roles define concepts, misapplication of concepts becomes impossible.

positions.statement: If IRS is right, wrong applications of a concept collapse into correct applications of some other concept—but plainly this is false.
positions.verbatim_quote: If IRS is right, wrong applications of a concept collapse into correct applications of some other concept—but plainly this is false.

positions.statement: The distinction between reference-fixing and meaning-giving saves non-atomism from the objections Fodor raises.
positions.verbatim_quote: The distinction between reference-fixing and meaning-giving saves non-atomism from the objections Fodor raises.

positions.statement: To have a concept of a thing is to know some proposition that describes (uniquely individuates) that thing.
positions.verbatim_quote: To have a concept of a thing is to know some proposition that describes (uniquely individuates) that thing.

positions.statement: Knowledge of a proposition describing x suffices for ability to think about x—it qualifies as a concept of x.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowledge of a proposition describing x suffices for ability to think about x—it qualifies as a concept of x.

positions.statement: Once you know a proposition describing a thing, you can attribute any property you grasp to that thing.
positions.verbatim_quote: Once you know a proposition describing a thing, you can attribute any property you grasp to that thing.

positions.statement: Your concept of the number two is your belief in a proposition like "there is some number n such that n=1+1."
positions.verbatim_quote: Your concept of the number two is your belief in a proposition like "there is some number n such that n=1+1."

positions.statement: Changes in what else you believe about the number two do not change your concept of it.
positions.verbatim_quote: Changes in what else you believe about the number two do not change your concept of it.

positions.statement: The error objection is sidestepped: wrong beliefs about two are still about two because they attribute properties to what satisfies n=1+1.
positions.verbatim_quote: The error objection is sidestepped: wrong beliefs about two are still about two because they attribute properties to what satisfies n=1+1.

positions.statement: Grasping a thing consists in grasping a proposition about that thing; one cannot just think a thing without thinking something about it.
positions.verbatim_quote: Grasping a thing consists in grasping a proposition about that thing; one cannot just think a thing without thinking something about it.

positions.statement: Whatever is thought—whatever is grasped—is some truth or falsity, never just a bare object.
positions.verbatim_quote: Whatever is thought—whatever is grasped—is some truth or falsity, never just a bare object.

positions.statement: Knowing who a name refers to is contextual: relative to some existence claims you may know it, relative to others not.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowing who a name refers to is contextual: relative to some existence claims you may know it, relative to others not.

positions.statement: Understanding a sentence-token is contextual because knowing what a term refers to is contextual.
positions.verbatim_quote: Understanding a sentence-token is contextual because knowing what a term refers to is contextual.

positions.statement: Classical logic fails as a reasoning tool because recognizing that an inference instantiates a logical law requires more intelligence than recognizing the validity of the inference directly.
positions.verbatim_quote: Classical logic fails as a reasoning tool because recognizing that an inference instantiates a logical law requires more intelligence than recognizing the validity of the inference directly.

positions.statement: Logic organizes existing knowledge about entailment relationships but cannot generate new knowledge about what entails what.
positions.verbatim_quote: Logic organizes existing knowledge about entailment relationships but cannot generate new knowledge about what entails what.

positions.statement: There is a fundamental distinction between performance-demanding inferences (straining computational resources) and competence-demanding inferences (requiring genuine insight), and classical logic can only assist with the former.
positions.verbatim_quote: There is a fundamental distinction between performance-demanding inferences (straining computational resources) and competence-demanding inferences (requiring genuine insight), and classical logic can only assist with the former.

positions.statement: System L (AI-based logic) represents a decisive break from classical logic by employing semantic networks, meta-reasoning patterns, and defeasible inference rather than explicit rule application.
positions.verbatim_quote: System L (AI-based logic) represents a decisive break from classical logic by employing semantic networks, meta-reasoning patterns, and defeasible inference rather than explicit rule application.

positions.statement: The distinction between discovery procedures and verification procedures is crucial: inductive methods can be legitimately used to discover solutions while deductive methods verify them in deductive domains.
positions.verbatim_quote: The distinction between discovery procedures and verification procedures is crucial: inductive methods can be legitimately used to discover solutions while deductive methods verify them in deductive domains.

positions.statement: AI-logic is inherently ampliative (generating new knowledge), while classical logic is purely transformative (rearranging existing knowledge).
positions.verbatim_quote: AI-logic is inherently ampliative (generating new knowledge), while classical logic is purely transformative (rearranging existing knowledge).

positions.statement: Classical logic serves formalization purposes, while System L serves as a genuine inference engine for discovery.
positions.verbatim_quote: Classical logic serves formalization purposes, while System L serves as a genuine inference engine for discovery.

positions.statement: The operation of modern AI systems falsifies the traditional philosophical model of induction as purely enumerative.
positions.verbatim_quote: The operation of modern AI systems falsifies the traditional philosophical model of induction as purely enumerative.

positions.statement: Successful inductive inference requires integrating statistical evidence with theoretical frameworks about causation, continuity, and natural kinds.
positions.verbatim_quote: Successful inductive inference requires integrating statistical evidence with theoretical frameworks about causation, continuity, and natural kinds.

positions.statement: AI systems resolve Goodman's "grue" paradox not through pure enumeration but through implicit theoretical frameworks recognizing that properties don't change discontinuously without cause.
positions.verbatim_quote: AI systems resolve Goodman's "grue" paradox not through pure enumeration but through implicit theoretical frameworks recognizing that properties don't change discontinuously without cause.

positions.statement: Popper's sharp distinction between contexts of discovery and justification is untenable because the features that make a hypothesis worth considering are inherently connected to what justifies it.
positions.verbatim_quote: Popper's sharp distinction between contexts of discovery and justification is untenable because the features that make a hypothesis worth considering are inherently connected to what justifies it.

positions.statement: Discovery processes follow identifiable logical principles that are truth-tracking rather than merely psychological.
positions.verbatim_quote: Discovery processes follow identifiable logical principles that are truth-tracking rather than merely psychological.

positions.statement: Building AI systems that successfully replicate scientific reasoning constitutes reverse-engineering the cognitive processes underlying scientific discovery.
positions.verbatim_quote: Building AI systems that successfully replicate scientific reasoning constitutes reverse-engineering the cognitive processes underlying scientific discovery.

positions.statement: The operation of AI systems empirically falsifies various skeptical positions (external world skepticism, skepticism about unobservables, future knowledge, and counterfactual knowledge) through their successful operation.
positions.verbatim_quote: The operation of AI systems empirically falsifies various skeptical positions (external world skepticism, skepticism about unobservables, future knowledge, and counterfactual knowledge) through their successful operation.

positions.statement: Knowledge requires not just justified true belief but justification that serves as a proper conduit between reality and belief.
positions.verbatim_quote: Knowledge requires not just justified true belief but justification that serves as a proper conduit between reality and belief.

positions.statement: The neural architecture of AI systems supports a coherentist rather than foundationalist theory of knowledge.
positions.verbatim_quote: The neural architecture of AI systems supports a coherentist rather than foundationalist theory of knowledge.

positions.statement: LLMs provide empirical support for the classical distinction between semantics (literal meaning) and pragmatics (communicated meaning).
positions.verbatim_quote: LLMs provide empirical support for the classical distinction between semantics (literal meaning) and pragmatics (communicated meaning).

positions.statement: The ability of LLMs to process novel sentences demonstrates compositional understanding, vindicating classical theories of meaning.
positions.verbatim_quote: The ability of LLMs to process novel sentences demonstrates compositional understanding, vindicating classical theories of meaning.

positions.statement: Humans and LLMs develop similar linguistic capabilities through different learning paths, suggesting compositional structure reflects fundamental features of language rather than artifacts of particular learning mechanisms.
positions.verbatim_quote: Humans and LLMs develop similar linguistic capabilities through different learning paths, suggesting compositional structure reflects fundamental features of language rather than artifacts of particular learning mechanisms.

positions.statement: LLMs vindicate the autonomy of syntax thesis: grammatical structure operates according to its own principles, independent of meaning.
positions.verbatim_quote: LLMs vindicate the autonomy of syntax thesis: grammatical structure operates according to its own principles, independent of meaning.

positions.statement: The success of LLMs demonstrates that structural abstraction need not be innate and can emerge from statistical learning.
positions.verbatim_quote: The success of LLMs demonstrates that structural abstraction need not be innate and can emerge from statistical learning.

positions.statement: Grammar directly encodes logical relationships, making translation to first-order logic unnecessary for valid inference.
positions.verbatim_quote: Grammar directly encodes logical relationships, making translation to first-order logic unnecessary for valid inference.

positions.statement: Traditional formalizations primarily systematize knowledge we already possess rather than generate new insights.
positions.verbatim_quote: Traditional formalizations primarily systematize knowledge we already possess rather than generate new insights.

positions.statement: Formal systems can sometimes impede knowledge acquisition by prematurely ruling out meaningful concepts.
positions.verbatim_quote: Formal systems can sometimes impede knowledge acquisition by prematurely ruling out meaningful concepts.

positions.statement: The Computational Theory of Mind is fundamentally inadequate because it cannot account for the primarily analog nature of cognitive processing.
positions.verbatim_quote: The Computational Theory of Mind is fundamentally inadequate because it cannot account for the primarily analog nature of cognitive processing.

positions.statement: Intelligence—whether artificial or biological—is better understood through architectural constraints and emergent patterns than through traditional computational metaphors.
positions.verbatim_quote: Intelligence—whether artificial or biological—is better understood through architectural constraints and emergent patterns than through traditional computational metaphors.

positions.statement: What we call Universal Grammar might be better understood as architectural features of neural networks that bias language learning in universal directions, rather than as explicit rules.
positions.verbatim_quote: What we call Universal Grammar might be better understood as architectural features of neural networks that bias language learning in universal directions, rather than as explicit rules.

positions.statement: Consciousness serves three key functions in biological organisms: real-time environmental monitoring, reflexive self-awareness, and integration of multiple cognitive processes.
positions.verbatim_quote: Consciousness serves three key functions in biological organisms: real-time environmental monitoring, reflexive self-awareness, and integration of multiple cognitive processes.

positions.statement: Current AI systems lack consciousness-like features not because of technological limitations but because they lack genuine survival pressures.
positions.verbatim_quote: Current AI systems lack consciousness-like features not because of technological limitations but because they lack genuine survival pressures.

positions.statement: If AI systems needed to preserve themselves in dynamic, threatening environments, consciousness-like functional analogues might become necessary.
positions.verbatim_quote: If AI systems needed to preserve themselves in dynamic, threatening environments, consciousness-like functional analogues might become necessary.

positions.statement: The self is best understood as a hierarchical organization serving mediating functions, not as a unified Cartesian ego.
positions.verbatim_quote: The self is best understood as a hierarchical organization serving mediating functions, not as a unified Cartesian ego.

positions.statement: Current AI systems demonstrate that many cognitive capabilities associated with selfhood can exist in distributed, emergent forms without requiring a central ego.
positions.verbatim_quote: Current AI systems demonstrate that many cognitive capabilities associated with selfhood can exist in distributed, emergent forms without requiring a central ego.

positions.statement: AI systems could benefit from organizational principles more similar to those found in human consciousness, including genuine reflexive capabilities and hierarchical organization.
positions.verbatim_quote: AI systems could benefit from organizational principles more similar to those found in human consciousness, including genuine reflexive capabilities and hierarchical organization.

positions.statement: The success of AI systems in anomaly minimization provides empirical support for understanding knowledge as the minimization of inconsistencies within a belief system.
positions.verbatim_quote: The success of AI systems in anomaly minimization provides empirical support for understanding knowledge as the minimization of inconsistencies within a belief system.

positions.statement: Vagueness should be handled through continuous properties while maintaining binary truth values, not through multi-valued logic.
positions.verbatim_quote: Vagueness should be handled through continuous properties while maintaining binary truth values, not through multi-valued logic.

positions.statement: The notion of a third truth value (half-true) is metaphysically incoherent because it implies that properties or states of affairs can "half-exist."
